full_translation:
**The *Dao and Virtue Compendium***

**Text Title:** *Dao and Virtue Compendium* (*Daode Huiyuan*)
Author: Li Daochun of the Yuan dynasty
Two fascicles, upper and lower
Source edition: *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Dongshen* section, *Yujue* category

---

**Preface to the *Dao and Virtue Compendium***

I humbly observe that Fu Xi drew the *Yi* to reveal the Primordial Heaven, while Laozi composed his book to fully manifest the Dao and virtue. These two works may well be the ancestors of all scriptures. Yet today’s scholars, failing to grasp their principles—how lamentable! The fault lies in not receiving their true transmission.

I, though untrained in letters, sought widely and visited many masters until I encountered a perfected one who unlocked the *Yi* in my heart, allowing me to attain the subtleties of its profound meaning. Thereupon, I exhausted what I had gained and compiled the *Essence of the Three Heavens’ Yi*, which I transmitted to my disciples. Only Laozi’s *Daodejing* remained unmastered.

One day, a certain Chuan Ji’an brought me the *Precious Chapters on the Dao and Virtue* by the Perfected One of Purple Clarity. Upon examining its annotations, I found them largely in accord with the text, though some parts were incomplete. I wished to add my own glosses but hesitated after careful reflection.

Later, two or three disciples each presented several commentaries by various masters, seeking my instruction. Comparing them with the original scripture, I found many discrepancies: some had an extra word, others a missing word; some entire sentences diverged, or characters were corrupted. Each had its strengths and weaknesses, yet all differed.

I sighed: If even the original scripture is thus, how much more so the commentaries? When asked the reason, I replied: Initially, copyists made errors. Later, printing blocks had omissions or misalignments, and where earlier interpretations were unclear, later scholars arbitrarily added to them, perpetuating distortions and creating fragmentation.

Someone asked: Which version is correct?
I said: The *Zhangju* of Master He Shang and the *Precious Chapters on the Dao and Virtue* by the Perfected One of Purple Clarity are quite coherent.
Why?
Because those that align with the logical flow of the text above and below are correct.

What of the other interpretations?
Each reflects a different perspective, clinging to one aspect alone.

May I ask for details?
They stem from private conjecture, not flowing from one’s own insight, and thus cannot be broadly applied. Those versed in governance cling to governance; those in the alchemical Dao, to the alchemical Dao; those in military strategy, to military strategy; those in Chan, to Chan. Some speak of principle but not practice; others, of practice but not principle. As for expedient means, clever schemes, or roundabout paths, they fall into partiality and lose the Sage’s original intent.

Little do they realize that the Sage’s purpose in composing the scripture was to establish the ultimate before Heaven and Earth, to operate beyond yin and yang. In the space between covering and supporting, every affair and principle is complete—how could one cling to a single aspect and speak of it thus?

Thereupon, I ventured to speak, pointing out where others’ interpretations were incoherent or contrary to the Sage’s meaning, presenting them to my disciples. All agreed. Thereafter, seekers came repeatedly, leaving me no choice but silence. I proceeded to add annotations to each line of the original scripture, elucidating its meaning to verify the essentials of nurturing spirit and cultivating qi. For each chapter, I summarized its principle to clarify the sequence of investigating the root and exhausting the source. After each chapter, I composed verses to fully reveal the mechanism of illuminating the mind and seeing one’s nature.

As for the matters of cultivating the self, ordering the family, governing the state, and pacifying the realm; the regulations and laws; the daily concerns of the common people; and the path of ordinary conduct—whether vast or minute, broad or subtle, nothing is not encompassed within. I further composed two discourses, *Rectifying Words* and *Investigating Principle*, placing them at the scripture’s beginning to clarify proper terminology and thoroughly examine its meaning, thereby resolving the confusions of discrepancies in the text. I titled this work the *Dao and Virtue Compendium*, so that later learners may delve deeply and savor it, entering according to their understanding, and thus avoid falling into partiality, ultimately merging with the supreme Dao and returning to the origin.

Though my words are coarse and unrefined, I have done no more than provide straightforward explanations. I dare not claim the scripture’s meaning as my own. Yet compared to other versions, this may come closer. May those of like mind in later times take note.

Written on the first day of the fourth lunar month in the *gengyin* year of the Zhiyuan era (1290) by Li Daochun, the Learned One of Clear Hermitage of Duliang, styled Yuánsù.

---

**Prefatory Notes to the *Dao and Virtue Compendium***

**Rectifying Words**

Among the various versions of the scripture I have examined, only the edition by the Venerable He Shang is correct. Even the He Shang edition has three variants: one with He Shang Gong’s annotations, one with two complete commentaries, and one with the *Zhangju* in plain text. Among these, only the plain-text *Zhangju* of the Venerable He Shang is superior in principle, and I have followed it. I have thus exposed the erroneous interpretations of other versions to rectify their deviations. Beyond this, there are over two hundred instances of minor discrepancies, which I shall not enumerate here. This brief account suffices to dispel scholars’ doubts.

In Chapter Two, the six phrases beginning with "Being and non-being give birth to one another" should not each include the word *zhi* (之).
In Chapter Three, "Therefore the Sage empties their heart" should not be rendered as "the Sage governs," "governs it," or "governs it thus."
In Chapter Eleven, the six phrases beginning with "Embracing the One, can you not part from it?" should not each include the word *hu* (乎).
In Chapter Thirteen, "Favor is high, disgrace is low" should not be rendered as "favor is low," which contradicts the scripture’s meaning.
In Chapter Sixteen, "Cautious, as if crossing a river in winter" should not be rendered as "together with" (*yu*, 與) or omit *xi* (兮) in the following three of six phrases.
In Chapter Seventeen, "Next, they fear him; next, they revile him" should not be rendered as "they fear and revile him."
In Chapter Twenty, "Dim, as if obscured" should not be rendered as "bland, as if the sea."
"Valuing the mother of sustenance" should not be rendered as "the child values seeking sustenance from the mother."
In Chapter Thirty, some versions have three extra characters or one or two missing.
In Chapter Thirty-One, "Victory is not beautiful" should not be rendered as "thus it is not beautiful."

Some versions render "love and nurture" in Chapter Thirty-Four as "clothing and coverings"—this is incorrect. In Chapter Thirty-Six, dividing "softness and weakness overcome hardness and strength" into two phrases is wrong. In Chapter Thirty-Nine, "counting the parts of a chariot yet having no chariot" is sometimes misread as "counting praises"—this is also incorrect. In Chapter Forty-Nine, adding the particle *yi* (矣) after "virtue is good, virtue is trustworthy" is wrong. In Chapter Fifty-Two, "having served the mother, one knows the child" is sometimes misconstrued as "having known the mother, one further knows the child"—both versions are incorrect. In Chapter Fifty-Five, "excessive life brings misfortune" is sometimes rendered as "daily life" or "it is called life"—both are wrong. Chapter Sixty-Six contains several discrepancies in phrasing. In Chapter Seventy-One, "to know yet not know" is sometimes expanded to "to know yet not know is superior"—this is incorrect. In Chapter Seventy-Seven, "who can take their surplus to serve the world" is sometimes interpolated with "those lacking"—this is wrong. In Chapter Seventy-Eight, "nothing in the world is softer or weaker than water" is sometimes misphrased as "nothing is softer or weaker than water"—this is incorrect. In Chapter Eighty, "to cause the possession of tools for ten or a hundred yet not use them" is sometimes rendered as "ordering tools" or "not using them"—both are wrong.

**Investigating the Principle**
Examining the various editions and their interpretations, those that do not align with the Sage’s meaning are here exposed. The discrepancies and errors are numerous, and I do not wish to enumerate them all—scholars should reflect deeply on this.

*"Always without desire, to observe its mystery"*
Some punctuate this as a single phrase, "always without," or claim, "Those without desire preserve themselves; those with desire perish." If those with desire truly perish, why speak of "together calling it the profound"? Could perishing be called the profound? I say: "Without desire" means acting without contrivance, naturally. "With desire" means applying effort with intention. Non-action reveals the mystery of the nameless, preserving one’s nature. Action reveals the thoroughness of the named, preserving one’s life. Being and non-being, nature and life—these emerge from the same source yet bear different names, together called the profound, the profound within the profound. When being and non-being interpenetrate, nature and life are both fulfilled.

The *Record* states: "Before joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure are expressed, it is called the Center. The Center is the great root of the world—this is the meaning of 'without desire, observe the mystery.' When expressed and all meet their measure, it is called Harmony. Harmony is the universal Dao of the world—this is the meaning of 'with desire, observe its manifestations.' Achieving the Center and Harmony, heaven and earth take their places, and the ten thousand things are nurtured—this is the meaning of 'the profound within the profound.'"

The term "desire" refers to desiring what others do not desire.

*"Not exalting the worthy"*
Some render this as "not seeking worthy scholars" or "not employing the worthy"—both are incorrect. If the worthy were truly not employed, this scripture would be unworthy of evidence, for such a principle could not exist.

*"The gate of the mysterious female"*
Some identify the mouth and nose as the gate of the mysterious female—this is wrong. Others suggest it refers to where thoughts arise—this is somewhat plausible but still does not align with the scripture’s meaning.

*"Bearing the *po*"*
Some interpret this as "soul and *po*," others as "yin and yang," and there are several other explanations—all are untenable. They fail to recognize that the *po* delights in movement; "bearing" it means to govern it.

*"Thirty spokes"*
Some explain this as the number of days in a month, others as the fire of cultivation—both are incorrect. They do not grasp that the Sage’s intent does not lie in the number thirty.

*"Cut off sageliness, abandon wisdom"*
Some claim sageliness and wisdom are insufficient and should be discarded—this is wrong. I say: the Sage does not employ sageliness and wisdom to be seen by the people.

*"Abandon learning, and there is no sorrow"*
Some take this to mean "abandoning learning is not learning"—this is incorrect. It means abandoning the learning of ordinary people to learn the non-learning of others. "Abandoning learning" means abandoning the learning of the world.

*"To close it, one must first open it"*
The explanations of various schools are incoherent. Some claim it refers to valuing flexibility—this is wrong. The highest Dao does not exalt the worthy; how could it value flexibility?

*"Rites are the head of disorder"*
Some hastily conclude that rites are not worth pursuing—I do not agree. If one can advance from rites to benevolence and righteousness, one nearly approaches the Dao.

*"Counting the parts of a chariot yet having no chariot"*
The explanations of various schools are incoherent. I say: counting the parts of a chariot, not one is called a chariot—this is a metaphor for my body, not one part of which is called "I."

*"Those who live are thirteen"*
Some claim that of ten parts, three are life and three are death, or that it refers to the seven emotions and six desires—this seems plausible but is not. Others suggest it refers to the four gates and nine orifices, which is even more wrong. Still others compare it to the waxing and waning of the moon as a metaphor for the fire of cultivation—this is also incorrect. For the explanation, see the main text of the scripture.

*"Do not narrow one’s dwelling"*

Previous interpretations fail to cohere. Some offer contrary explanations, claiming it refers to the formless spirit or to boundless vastness—both are incorrect. Others suggest it means "never weary of one’s life" or "never weary of the Dao," which is sheer delusion. Have they not heard the concluding line: *"Abandon that, embrace this"*?

I say: *"Do not narrow one’s dwelling"* still implies grasping at vastness and greed. *"Never weary of one’s life"* means defying great majesty and insatiable craving for life. The sage knows the self without displaying it, cherishes the self without exalting it, and does not indulge life—hence *"abandon that, embrace this."*

*"Those with virtue hold fast to the bond; those without virtue enforce thoroughness."*
Some claim *"彻"* means *"to penetrate,"* that the sages of antiquity were universally penetrating, nothing escaping their comprehension, while the people, lacking virtue, merely praised them. Such words are like eavesdropping through a wall—utterly unrelated to the scripture’s meaning.

I say: *"契"* means *"pledge"* or *"covenant"* (pronounced *qiè* in rhyme with *挈*). *"彻"* means *"thorough"* or *"pervasive."* Those with virtue uphold their covenant, while those without virtue enforce their clarity and thoroughness. For details, see the main text of the scripture below—those of insight should reflect deeply.

This scripture’s phrasing often employs rhyme:
*"朴"* rhymes with *"扑."*
*"阙"* (pronounced *zhá*) rhymes with *"察察."*
*"拔"* (pronounced *bá*) rhymes with *"脱."*
*"作"* (pronounced *zuò*, entering tone) rhymes with *"复."*
Such examples are numerous; their pronunciations are noted in the main text. Readers of this scripture must not cling rigidly to the literal meaning of the characters.

*Preface and Examples to the* **Collected Essentials of the Dao and Its Virtue**
*Collected Essentials of the Dao and Its Virtue, Volume One*

**Composed by Li Daochun Yuanfu of Qing’an, the Pure Toad Hermitage of Duliang**

**Dao**
That which can be spoken of as the Dao is not the true and constant Dao. The true and constant Dao begins in the beginningless, is named in the nameless. To conceive or discuss it is already to deviate; to open one’s mouth is already to err. If it could be spoken of, what would the Dao be? Since it cannot be spoken of, how then is the Dao to be perceived? If it is neither what can be spoken nor what cannot be spoken, how then is it to be realized? Should one manage to turn the phrase here, the work of inquiry is complete—if not, one must seek within the twelve hours of the day, in rising and resting, in eating and dwelling, in every moment of turning the mind, to examine and discern what it is that stands so steadfast, so vividly alive, never opposing any condition. Examine and discern again and again, until one reaches the point where examination and discernment fail—suddenly, as if grasping one’s own nostrils, the whole body breaks into sweat. Only then does one realize that this original thing has always been one’s own, unchanged since time immemorial. This is what is meant by the Dao, from which one cannot be parted even for an instant. Again, it is said: in walking, standing, sitting, and lying, one does not depart from this. How much more so between heaven and earth, where every thing and every phenomenon is this, from ancient times to the present, only this—giving birth to heaven and earth, only this. In daily life, in movement and stillness, in activity and rest, it is only this. All that has form will decay, but the nature of this remains constant. Even heaven, earth, and the void will decay, yet this alone does not. This alone cannot be seen through, though not for iron eyes or bronze pupils. Why can it not be seen through? Only because one has never truly encountered it face to face. Even if one were to encounter it face to face, one would still miss it. And where would one have missed it? Do not wander aimlessly—after all, how does one understand it? Here, it is perfectly clear, yet only lacks someone to bear witness to it. Should one meet a true friend, one would raise one’s brows and offer it up.

*Crack!* Last night, new rain passed by the riverbank;
This morning, the distant mountains remain as green.

**Verse:**
The ultimate of the Dao is emptiness, void, and stillness,
Without image, without form, without name, without substance.
It cannot be seen, cannot be grasped, cannot be heard,
Nor can its traces be found.
Vast, it encompasses all; subtle, it enters all.
It gives birth to heaven and earth, nurtures the ten thousand things,
Its transformations endless, its hiddenness and manifestation unfathomable.
It cannot be known by knowing, cannot be recognized by recognizing.
The Most High Laozi, whose tongue had no bone,
In this scripture, clearly revealed it.
Much speech leads to exhaustion—better to remain silent.
This is the end of doubt.

**Virtue/Power**
The word *virtue* is also a forced name, impossible to describe or grasp. Any contrivance, accumulation of merit, or layering of practice is not virtue. To remain thus, without cultivation, without effort, like dead ashes or withered wood, waiting for virtue to come of itself—one will have no virtue for a lifetime. The more one seeks virtue, the farther it recedes; the more one clings to it, the more it is lost. The scripture says: “The highest virtue does not act as virtue, and thus possesses virtue.” And again: “The highest virtue acts without acting and without purpose.” These two lines are abundantly clear—only lacking someone to bear witness to them. If one is truly faithful, one will overturn all prior learning, understanding, and knowledge—all the teachings of the Hearers and Pratyekabuddhas—and in the midst of ordinary practice, take up the word *diminish* and put it to use. Diminish again and again, diminishing until one reaches the point where nothing more can be diminished. Then, mysterious virtue shines forth, and one trusts that non-action is indeed beneficial. The scripture says: “The teaching without words, the benefit of non-action—few in the world attain it.” And again: “Mysterious virtue is profound, far-reaching.” Do you understand?

*Hmm!* It does not depart from where it constantly abides,
Yet if sought, you will find it cannot be seen.

**Verse:**
The river-sands of wondrous virtues all reside within the mind.
No need for effort—why labor to cultivate and accumulate?
The more one delves, the deeper it becomes; the more one clings, the more it is lost.
Let go of all things, overturn all phenomena.
Put others before oneself, embrace the feminine, hold to the One.
Pure and undivided, one’s virtue becomes real.
Self-cultivation, family regulation, governance, and peace—all emerge from this.
Its wondrous function is immeasurable—this is called mysterious virtue.

**Scripture**
The word *scripture* is also a forced name. In the beginning, the sage saw that people followed illusions with their emotions, were deluded by desires, and true nature was lost amid the turmoil of karmic consciousness and the blazing of ignorance. Thus, the original heaven was forsaken, and people suffered premature death and injury, unable to return to their fundamental source. Therefore, using the power of skillful means, the sage opened the gate of good guidance, leading the deluded multitude back to the true Way. Thus, he composed books and established teachings, forcibly naming them *scriptures*. *Scripture* means *path*—the great road traveled by all. Yet those who read this scripture must not cling to the trance of language, nor should they abandon this scripture to seek elsewhere. One must turn one’s attention to one’s own being, carefully chewing over these five thousand words, examining each point and stroke, not letting anything slip by. Suddenly, when one thoroughly digests even a single phrase, this entire scripture resides within oneself. Only then does one trust that the opening of the Dao does not depend on the tongue. Here, one unlocks one’s own treasure store, brings forth one’s own scripture, wields it freely and without constraint. Not only this scripture, but all thirty-six revered scriptures and the entire canon of teachings—from beginning to end, with a single shout, one fully comprehends them all.

A storm rises from level ground,
A thunderclap splits the clear sky—
Listen carefully, listen carefully!

**Verse:**
This single scroll of scripture—
Its wondrous function is beyond praise.
Each person inherently possesses it,
Every thing is perfectly complete.
Straightforward and unobstructed,
Vast and unconfined.
Unchanging through kalpas,
Unaltered since ancient times.
Everywhere it functions,
Everywhere it serves as a thoroughfare.

Before the hand is raised, clarity is already distinct.
None but the true child of my house dares enter within.

"The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao."
To open the mouth is already to err.
What name shall it be called?
That which can be named is not the eternal name.
To call it a thing is already to miss the mark.

Nameless, it is the Dao—
The beginning of heaven and earth,
Prior to all covering and bearing.
Named, it is forcibly called the Dao—
The mother of the ten thousand things,
Giving life without cease.

Thus, in constant non-desire, one observes its mystery;
In no-mind, transformation unfolds.
In constant desire, one observes its manifestations.
(Manifestation: *jiào*, pronounced as "call"—intentional manipulation.)

These two emerge together yet bear different names—
One substance, two functions.
Together they are called the profound,
For substance and function share a single source.
Profound beyond the profound,
Where form and spirit are both wondrous—
The gateway of the manifold mysteries.
From this arise the hundred thousand dharma gates.

**Chapter One**
The Dao of emptiness and natural constancy cannot be spoken.
The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao.
It is the primordial ancestral qi,
The Dao that transforms and gives birth to all heavens,
Adapting to time and circumstance.

The Dao is originally nameless;
The name that can be named is not the eternal name.
It is the name that shapes heaven and earth’s transformations,
Nurturing the ten thousand things,
Manifest in form and trace.

With an empty mind and non-action, one perceives the nameless mystery;
With an active mind, one perceives the named manifestations.
Mystery is spirit; manifestation is form.
To know manifestation but not mystery is imprecise;
To know mystery but not its thoroughness is incomplete.
Only when both are fully realized—
Form and spirit both wondrous—
Is it called "profound beyond the profound."
From this emerge the thirty-six revered scriptures,
The gateway of the manifold mysteries.

Where, then, does this scripture arise?
*Hah!*

**Verse:**
At Kunlun’s summit,
Within the primordial millet-pearl.
The mouth born of father and mother
Will never serve you truly.

When all under heaven know beauty as beauty, ugliness arises;
(For beauty is the cause of ugliness.)
When all know goodness as goodness, un-goodness follows.
(For goodness is the source of un-goodness.)

Thus, being and non-being give birth to one another;
Difficulty and ease complete one another.
(Ease: *yì*, pronounced as "ferment"—what is difficult becomes easy; what is easy becomes difficult.)
Long and short define one another;
High and low incline toward one another.
(Where there is height, there is lowness.)
Sound and echo harmonize;
(Where there is sound, there is harmony.)
Front and back follow one another.
(Before follows after; after follows before.)

Therefore, the sage forgets beauty and ugliness,
Abides in non-action,
Forgets being and non-being.
Practices the teaching without words,
Forgets difficulty and ease.
The ten thousand things arise without refusal,
Forgets things.
Born yet not possessed,
Forgets form.
Acts yet does not rely,
Forgets emotion.
Achieves yet does not dwell.
Forgets self.
Only by not dwelling does one remain true to one’s origin—
Thus, it does not depart.
(Depart: *qù*, pronounced in rising tone—
When all is forgotten, the true unity remains eternally.)

**Chapter Two**
Beauty and ugliness, goodness and un-goodness,
Like shadow following form, naturally depend on one another.
Even being and non-being, difficulty and ease,
Mutually rely and conceal one another.
Where there is beauty, there is ugliness;
Where there is goodness, there is un-goodness.
Thus, the sage neither refuses nor possesses,
Neither relies nor dwells,
Forgets both self and other,
Lets being and non-being dissolve—
And so remains eternally, never departing.

This chapter elucidates the meaning of embodying the Dao from the first,
Enabling the learner to understand the principle of "emerging together yet bearing different names,"
Neither clinging to function nor abandoning it,
Avoiding partiality and stagnation.

**Verse:**
People have beauty and ugliness;
I have no self or other.
All overturned—
A hundred bubbles return to water.
Though a thousand existences are pointed out before me,
I say within them there is not a single one.

Do not exalt the worthy,
Abandon sageliness and discard wisdom—
Let the people not contend.
(Forget self.)
Do not value rare goods,
Abandon craft and discard profit—
Let the people not steal.
(Forget things.)
Do not display what is desirable,
Turn things to respond to the moment—
Let the heart not be confused.
(Forget emotion.)

Thus, the sage empties the mind,
Preserves essence.
Fills the belly,
Preserves life.
Weakens the will,
Preserves spirit.
Strengthens the bones,
Preserves form.
Always lets the people be without knowledge or desire,
Emptying all that is possessed.
Lets those with knowledge not dare to act.
(Those who recognize the dharma fear.)
Act through non-action,
Still and unmoving—
Then nothing is not governed.
(Govern: *zhì*, pronounced as "hold"—
Responding, one penetrates all.)

**Chapter Three**
"Not exalting the worthy" continues the non-action of the previous chapter.
To not boast of one’s own worthiness is to make the people pure;
To not value rare goods is to make the people prosperous;
To not display what is desirable is to settle the heart.
The sage governs the world by taking self-cultivation as the foundation.

Emptying the mind and filling the belly—
These are the essentials of cultivation.
Empty the mind, then the will weakens;
Weaken the will, then knowledge ceases;
Cease knowledge, then forget self—
This is "not exalting the worthy."
Fill the belly, then the bones strengthen;
Strengthen the bones, then desire ceases;
Cease desire, then forget things—
This is "not valuing rare goods."
These two principles support one another,
Sufficient to complete essence and life.

**Verse:**
With a full belly, true constancy abides;
With an empty mind, the Dao naturally dwells.
No need to wield a blade—
With a laugh, the cosmos is settled.

The Dao is empty, yet its use is inexhaustible,
Like the great void, of one body with it.
Perhaps it does not fill.
(It does not overflow.)
Abysmal, it seems the ancestor of the ten thousand things.
(It does not display itself.)
Blunt its sharpness,
(Do not reveal its edge.)
Untangle its knots,
(Do not follow worldly changes.)
Soften its light,
(Do not shine alone.)
Blend with the dust,
(Do not assert oneself.)
Deep and still, it seems to endure.
(Constantly responding, constantly still.)

I do not know whose child it is—
It precedes the Supreme Emperor.
(Only the Dao is the body.)

These four chapters above speak of acting through non-action, thus following with *"The Dao is empty, yet its use is inexhaustible—perhaps it does not fill,"* which means it does not overflow of itself. One who does not overflow of himself must receive benefit. To blunt sharpness and untangle knots is to empty the center and forget the self. *"I do not know whose child it is—it precedes the Supreme Emperor"* transcends the bounds of emptiness and nothingness.

**Verse:**
Not knowing whose child it is,
How could one know it precedes the Supreme Emperor?
For you, I make it clearly known—
It was before the Great Ultimate was divided.

Heaven and Earth are not benevolent,
They act through non-action,
Treating the ten thousand things as straw dogs.
They nurture the ten thousand things yet do not claim mastery.
The sage is not benevolent,
Emulating Heaven,
Treating the hundred clans as straw dogs.
The myriad people return to him yet he does not claim mastery.

Between Heaven and Earth,
It is empty at the center,
Is it not like a bellows?
Empty yet inexhaustible in use.
Empty yet never depleted,
Without intent,
Moving yet ever more emerges.
Responding to change without end.
The more words are spoken, the sooner they fail—
It is better to guard the center,
To be empty at the center, and nothing more.

These five chapters above:
Heaven covers and Earth bears,
Transforming the people and nurturing things—
This may be called utmost benevolence.
To speak of "not benevolent" is to forget their origin.
The sage, in loving the people and governing the state, is likewise;
In cultivating the self and nourishing life, he is likewise.
This concludes the meaning of *"The Dao is empty, yet its use is inexhaustible."*

**Verse:**
Bottomless, it is called the bellows;
Three holes, it is called the flute.
Within, a single aperture—
No one can grasp it.
If one could grasp it, he would be lord,
Blowing forth soundless music.

*"The valley spirit does not die,"*
Empty and numinous, it does not fade.
This is called the Mysterious Female.
The Mysterious Female’s gate,
Opening and closing,
Is called the root of Heaven and Earth.
It generates Heaven and generates Earth,
Enduring ceaselessly, without rest or pause.
Its use is never forced,
Its application is inexhaustible.

These six chapters above:
*"The valley spirit does not die"*—
Empty and numinous, it does not fade.
Continuing the meaning of *"guarding the center"* from the previous chapter.
Empty and numinous, its transformations are boundless;
Yin and Yang are unfathomable.
Opening and closing without cease,
Coming and going without end—
None know its limit.
In movement and stillness, it is without flaw,
Without labor or effort,
Generating and transforming without end.

**Verse:**
Opening and closing in accord with Heaven and Earth,
This is the gate of the Mysterious Female.
Since there is no going out or coming in,
It alone is honored across the Three Realms.

Heaven and Earth endure without rest or pause.
The reason Heaven and Earth can be long and enduring
Is that they do not live for themselves—
Without intent,
Thus they can be long-enduring,
Unchanging and unshifting.
Therefore the sage emulates Heaven:
Placing himself behind, he finds himself ahead—
Forgetting the self.
Setting himself aside, he finds himself preserved—
Forgetting form.
Is it not because he is selfless?
Thus he accomplishes his self.
Because he has no self,
Thus he fulfills himself.

These seven chapters above:
Heaven does not act as Heaven of itself,
Earth does not act as Earth of itself—
Thus they generate without cease.
The sage does not act as sage of himself—
Thus he harmonizes his virtue with Heaven and Earth.
This continues the meaning of *"Its use is never forced."*

**Verse:**
The Dao is utterly empty,
This emptiness has no beginning.
Whoever penetrates this emptiness
Becomes one body with the Great Void.
The Tai Lake spans thirty-six thousand acres—
To whom would the moon in its waves speak?

The highest virtue is like water,
Abiding in lowliness with softness.
Water benefits the ten thousand things yet does not contend,
Adapting to square or round.
It dwells where the multitude disdain,
Able to embrace the foul and impure—
Thus it nearly approaches the Dao.
Near, level tone: in accord with the Dao.
Dwelling in good earth,
Benefiting things.
The mind is good when deep,
Receptive to things.
In giving, it is good with kindness,
Generating things.
In speech, it is good with sincerity,
Responding to things.
In governance, it is good with order,
Transforming things.
In affairs, it is good with ability,
Completing things.
In action, it is good with timing,
In harmony with things.
Only because it does not contend,
Thus it is without blame—
Things and self as one.

These eight chapters above:
Continuing the previous chapter’s *"Placing himself behind, he finds himself ahead."*
The meaning of water is to take softness, humility, and lowliness,
Benefiting things without contention—
Thus it is without blame.

**Verse:**
Without contention, the spirit is serene,
Naturally the qi is harmonious.
Let go of this little thing,
How many times has the Yellow River run clear?

To hold and fill it
Is not as good as stopping.
Already, yǐ tone: to cease.
Heaven’s Dao diminishes the full and benefits the humble.
To measure and sharpen it
Cannot be long preserved.
Measure, chǔi tone.
Earth’s Dao transforms the full and flows to the humble.
Gold and jade fill the hall—
None can guard them.
Ghosts and spirits harm the full and bless the humble.
Wealth and honor with arrogance
Bring their own misfortune.
Yí, departing tone; jiù, rising tone.
Human Dao detests the full and favors the humble.
When merit is achieved and fame is established,
Withdraw—
Gather and return.
Heaven’s Dao.
Heaven and Earth harmonize their virtue.

These nine chapters above:
*"To hold and fill it is not as good as stopping"* continues the meaning of *"The highest virtue is like water."*
*"When merit is achieved and fame is established, withdraw"* is the warning against fullness and the exhortation to humility.

**Verse:**
Hurrying forward, the shadow does not leave;
Returning, one falls into the pit.
Just now, stop where your feet stand—
The land becomes level and deep.
If you understand turning the body with a little effort,
Hiding or soaring are all at your will.

Carry the hun and po,
Do not let them wander recklessly.
Embrace the One—can you not let it go?
Two things mixed in harmony,
Like a mother carrying her infant.
Concentrate the qi to attain softness—
Can you be like an infant?
Pure and undivided,
Returning to simplicity and wholeness.
Cleanse and purify the mysterious mirror—
Can you be without flaw?
Not seeing, not hearing,
Dust-free and mirror-bright.
Love the people and govern the state—
Can you act without action?
Zhì tone: to govern.
Unmoving and unshaken,
The Dao flourishes and the times are clear.
The gate of Heaven opens and closes—
Can you be the female?
Going out to being, entering to non-being,
Without boasting or pride.
Understanding the four directions—
Can you be without knowledge?
Diminish cleverness, set aside wisdom,
Harmonizing light and blending with dust.
Giving life and nurturing,
Xù, entering tone.
Revolving the Four Virtues,
Nurturing the multitudes.
Giving life yet not possessing,
Achieving merit and fulfilling the Way,
Concealing traces and hiding form.
Acting yet not relying,
Forgetting its origin,
Silent and obscure.

Long yet not controlling—
*Long*, rising tone.
Retreating to leave room,
All entrusted to Heaven’s renewal.
This is called the Mysterious Power.

The Dao ascends, virtue is complete,
Detached from form, the True is preserved whole.

---

**Chapter Ten**
"Bearing the po-soul"—
Like a cart bearing goods, the po delights in movement,
In galloping, in hardness and sharpness—hence "bearing the po."
The po belongs to yin; when yin flourishes, it harms yang.
When emotions prevail, they enslave the nature.
Only by embracing the One without parting
Can one attain softness, flawlessness, non-action,
Femininity, and non-knowing—
Thus restraining the po’s unruly emotions.
When the po is subdued and yin dissolves,
The spirit is serene, the nature still.

"Giving life and nurturing"—
Giving life yet not possessing,
Forgetting its origin—
No need for restraint,
Naturally unmoving,
Like returning laden with treasures.
Thus, "bearing the po."
From "embracing the One" onward,
All speaks to the meaning of "bearing the po,"
Linking the previous chapter’s "achieving merit and withdrawing"
To the following chapter’s "thirty spokes share one hub,"
Which serves the cart’s function.

**Verse:**
Affairs resolve when the heart is empty—
Yet emptiness is most difficult.
In an instant of awakening,
After delusion, a thousand mountains lie between.

---

**Chapter Eleven**
Thirty spokes share one hub—
Like the myriad dharmas uniting in one mind.
Where it is empty,
Count the cart—there is no cart.
The cart’s use arises when spokes converge at the hub,
Completing the cart’s function.

Mold clay to make a vessel—
*Mold*, *shàn*, level tone.
Harmonizing earth to form a vessel.
Where it is empty,
Count the vessel—there is no vessel.
The vessel’s use arises from the union of water and earth,
Completing the vessel’s function.

Carve doors and windows to make a room—
Opening doors, hollowing windows.
Where it is empty,
Count the room—there is no room.
The room’s use arises when doors and windows allow passage,
Completing the room’s function.

Thus, being serves to benefit,
Using being to aid non-being.
Non-being serves as the function,
Using non-being to employ being.

---

**Chapter Eleven (continued)**
The hub’s convergence of spokes enables the cart’s use—
Just as all dharmas return to the mind,
The marvel of preserving the spirit whole.
Without spokes converging at the hub, how can it be called a cart?
Without dharmas returning to the mind, how can the spirit be realized?
The hub is empty within, allowing the cart to move;
The mind is empty within, allowing the spirit to adapt.
Thus, emptiness becomes the true benefit,
Being becomes the function of emptiness.
Emptiness and being communicate,
Coming and going without obstruction—
This is the meaning of "bearing the po" from the previous chapter.
When nothing remains to bear,
Hub and spokes are both forgotten,
The cart ceases to exist—
Just as when mind and dharmas are both forgotten,
The spirit returns to emptiness.
Vessels and rooms share this principle.

**Verse:**
A thousand iron walls,
Ten thousand silver mountains.
Turn the wheel of mechanism,
And pass straight through.
To know the path beneath the mountain,
Ask those who come and go.

---

**Chapter Twelve**
The five colors blind the eyes—
Eyes dazzled by color.
The five sounds deafen the ears—
Ears confused by noise.
The five flavors dull the mouth—
The mouth deceived by taste.
Racing and hunting madden the heart—
The heart driven by emotion.
Rare goods hinder conduct—
*Conduct*, falling tone.
The mind turned by things.

Thus, the sage tends to the belly, not the eyes—
*Tends*, falling tone.
The inner realm does not go out,
The outer realm does not enter.
Thus, rejecting that, embracing this—
*Reject*, *qù*, *qiāng-lǚ* cut.
Withdrawing sight, returning to hearing.

---

**Chapter Twelve (continued)**
The previous chapter expounded the function of emptiness—
When its function is empty, one is not dazzled by sounds and colors.
Thus, it is followed by "the five colors blind the eyes."
Colors, sounds, flavors, and things are all root-and-dust.
All worldly people are robbed by them,
Only the Daoist is not deceived.
Seeing, hearing, speaking, and acting—
Without ritual, do not engage.
Then the six thieves transform into the six spiritual penetrations.
Thus, rejecting that, embracing this.

**Verse:**
Seeing color, the spirit is unsteady;
Hearing sound, great harmony is lost.
Yet nothing is overturned—
With empty hands, the highest realm is built.

---

**Chapter Thirteen**
Favor and disgrace both startle—
Favor is the precursor of disgrace.
Valuing great trouble as one’s body—
Valuing is the beginning of trouble.

What is meant by "favor and disgrace both startle"?
Listen closely to what follows.
Favor is above, disgrace is below—
Favor is gain.
Thus, gaining it startles as if losing,
Losing it startles as if gaining.
This is called "favor and disgrace both startle."
So it is.

What is meant by "valuing great trouble as one’s body"?
A question.
Why do I have great trouble?
Because I have a body—
*Have*, falling tone, same below.
With a body comes trouble.
When I am without a body—
Forgetting form, free from burdens—
What trouble could I have?
Forgetting honor, free from trouble.

Thus, one who values the body for the world—
Those who set the body aside,
Those who value the body—
Can be entrusted with the world.
One who loves the body for the world—
Those who put the body last,
Those who cherish the body—
Can be relied upon with the world.

---

**Chapter Thirteen (continued)**
Following the previous chapter’s "tending to the belly, not the eyes,"
The meaning of forgetting the self.
Thus, it is followed by "favor and disgrace both startle."
Favor, disgrace, honor, and trouble are mutually dependent.
If one can anticipate trouble and guard against it,
There will be no trouble for a lifetime.
Extending this Dao to govern and pacify the world,
The world will forever be free from peril.
Those who rule a state and worry for the world as for their own bodies
Will have the world willingly embrace them without weariness.

**Verse:**
What disgrace is there in disgrace?
What honor is there in honor?
Guarding against faults in advance
Is still like traveling a path.
How much better to lay down the whole body,
Without gain or loss, without startling.

---

Invisible, it is called *yí*—
The great image has no form.
Inaudible, it is called *xī*—
The great sound is soundless.
Intangible, it is called *wēi*—
The Dao is hidden, without name.
These three cannot be further questioned—
How could they be explained?
Thus, they merge into one.
Different paths, same return.

Above, it is not bright—
Nothing is more hidden than the obscure.
Below, it is not dark—
Nothing is more manifest than the subtle.
Endless, it cannot be named—
Though it has structure, it truly has no name.

Returning to where there is no thing,
Concealing the self where no traces remain—
This is called "the form of no-form,"
Invisible yet intimately seen.
"The image of no-image"—
*Xiàng* read in the third tone.
Intimately seen yet not seen—
This is called "dim and indistinct."
Vast and boundless, deep and abyssal.
Approach it, yet its beginning is unseen—
No origin.
Follow it, yet its end is unseen—
*Hoù* read in the third tone.
No end.
Grasping the ancient Dao, non-action,
To govern the present’s being, to unify the ten thousand beings.
Knowing the ancient origin, non-action—
This is called the Dao’s discipline.
Through non-being, manifesting being.

**Right Chapter Fourteen:**
*Xī*, *yí*, *wēi*—the Dao’s utmost.
Merging into one, returning to the root.
Neither bright nor dark, harmonizing its light.
No image, no form, concealing its function.
The final line summarizes the preceding three chapters
And reveals the secret of the following one.

**Verse:**
This target of words is hard to grasp, hard to depict—
Eight-sided and flawless, without seam or crevice.
Dim and indistinct, yet within the obscure there is image—
Who could discuss such subtle truths?

The ancients who were adept as scholars
Preserved its formless state:
Subtle, wondrous, profoundly penetrating,
Pure, luminous, and bright—
So deep it cannot be known.
Look for it, yet it is not seen.

Just because it cannot be known,
We force descriptions upon it—
*Qiang* (read in rising tone):
With being, we meet non-being.

Cautious, as if crossing a river in winter,
Chill piercing to the bone.
Wary, as if fearing neighbors on all sides—
Vigilant in solitude.
Solemn, as if ice about to melt—
Without doubt.
Simple, as if uncarved wood—
*Pǔ* (like one dull of wit).
Vast, as if an empty valley—
Hollow within.
Turbid, as if muddied waters—
*Hún* (read in level tone),
One with the dust.

Who can stir the turbid to slowly clarify?
Clarity is the source of turbidity.
Who can remain still to slowly quicken?
Stillness is the mechanism of movement.

Those who preserve this Dao do not seek fullness—
Emptiness is the root of fulfillment.
Only by not being full,
Can one be empty and receptive.
Thus, the worn does not become new—
Burying brilliance, leveling ornament.

**Right Chapter Fifteen:**
Continuing the meaning of the Dao’s discipline from the previous chapter.
Illuminating for later learners:
Preserve sincerity, cultivate reverence,
Always be vigilant in solitude,
Do not cling to appearances but embrace the One,
And abide in emptiness in daily practice.
When all conditions suddenly cease,
And the myriad illusions melt away—
Stir it, and it does not become turbid;
Settle it, and it does not become clear.
This is called "subtle, wondrous, profoundly penetrating"—
Deeply hidden.

**Verse:**
Subtle, wondrous, profoundly penetrating,
Turning with the tread of men.
Blindfold the eyes,
And nothing is seen.
Better to return—
Recognize the face of the Void Sovereign.

Attain utmost emptiness,
Guard deep stillness.
Motionless and serene—
Yet the ten thousand things arise together,
And I observe their return.
Observing return, one knows transformation.

The things, teeming and diverse,
Each returns to its root—
Movement at its extreme reverts to stillness.
Returning to the root is called stillness,
Returning to the source.
This is called "restoring life’s mandate"—
The vitality of life resides here.
Restoring life’s mandate is called constancy—
Abiding thus through kalpas.
Knowing constancy is called illumination—
Lucid through past and present.

Not knowing constancy—
Deluded and confused.
Acting recklessly brings misfortune—
A grievous error.
Knowing constancy, one is all-embracing—
Greatness admits no exclusion.
Embracing, one is impartial—
Impartiality is kingly.
Impartial, one transforms all things—
Kingly, one accords with Heaven.
Accord with Heaven, one accords with the Dao—
How could there be an end or limit?
The Dao is enduring—
Inexhaustible.
Though the body perishes, it does not cease—
Though heaven and earth change, this does not change.

**Right Chapter Sixteen:**
Continuing from the previous chapter’s "adept as scholars."
Attaining emptiness and deep stillness,
Restoring life’s mandate and returning to the root—
All is wondrous and divine,
All converge here with discerning eyes.
The work of learning is complete.
If not yet so, delve further into the final lines.

**Verse:**
Attain emptiness to know the wondrous root,
In deepest stillness, see the heart of Heaven.
Grasp the meaning within,
And all the sands of the river are gold.

The Highest—
No height surpasses it.
Below, people merely know of its existence—
All acknowledge its presence.
Next are those who draw near and praise it—
To be near and praised is not natural.
Next are those who fear it—
Aware of its awe and reverence.
Next are those who insult it—
Utterly without restraint.

When trust is insufficient, the Dao is hard to believe—
Some do not trust.
Doubt runs deep.
Thus, it treasures its words—
Light promises, few fulfillments.

When merit is accomplished and fame achieved,
Silently it is brought to fruition—
The hundred clans all deem it their own nature,
Unaware of its origin.

**Right Chapter Seventeen:**
"The Highest" means no height surpasses it.
Though even the lowest know of this principle,
They may draw near—
Yet praise renders it unnatural.
Those who fear it are but a step removed,
While those who insult it have strayed far from the Dao.
Heavenly truth is lost,
Unable to return to the source—
Though taught, what benefit is there?
The more words, the less trust.
Better to remain silent and await it,
Act without contrivance and transform,
Allowing them to awaken on their own,
Naturally returning to simplicity—
Unspoken, yet trusted.

In terms of governance:
Below the Highest, none can act without contrivance.
Drawing near and praising—
This is teaching with words.
Those who fear it—
This is the restraint of punishment.
Those who insult it—
The ruler has lost trust.
When the ruler loses trust in the people,
The people do not trust in return.
Thus, it treasures its words—
Teaching without words.
Teaching without words,
Accomplishing without contrivance—
Punishment is unused, yet the people submit.
When merit and fame are achieved,
And simplicity is restored,
Nearness, praise, fear, and insult are all forgotten.
The hundred clans live in peace, delighting in custom,
Forgetting their origin—
Thus, they say, "We are naturally so."

**Verse:**
The Highest has no height above,
Yet abides in daily use.
Pity the blind fools,
Who claim it emerged from the Han Pass.

When the great Dao declines, there is benevolence and righteousness—
Once the great simplicity scatters, benevolence and righteousness arise.
When wisdom and cleverness emerge, there is great deceit—
*Chū* (read in departing tone):
Wisdom and intelligence—
Rooted in the dust of the senses and karmic consciousness.
When the six relations are not harmonious, there are filial children—
Better to abide in constant harmony.
When the state is dark and chaotic, there are loyal ministers—
Better to abide in constant order.

**Right Chapter Eighteen:**
Continuing the meaning of nearness, praise, fear, and insult from the previous chapter.
Rather than a chaotic state revealing loyal ministers,
Why not act without contrivance so the people transform themselves?

**Verse:**
Cleverness obscures the great root,
Wisdom loses heavenly truth.
Without affairs, abide in constant clarity—
Carefree and joyful.

Abandon sagacity, discard wisdom—
Act without contrivance.
The people’s benefit is a hundredfold—
At peace and still.
Abandon benevolence, discard righteousness—
Act without intent.
The people return to filial piety and compassion—
Harmonious and compliant.
Abandon skill, discard profit—
Act without desire.
There are no thieves or bandits—
Contentment is constant.

**Verse Nineteen:**
Unfolding the essence of the preceding chapter.
When sagacity, wisdom, benevolence, righteousness, skill, and profit are all abandoned and no longer employed,
The people follow this transformation and return to simplicity.

The Sage, fearing later scholars might prove unequal to the burden,
Attaches to it the principle of ease and plainness:
"Manifest plainness, embrace simplicity,
Be without cunning, without guile.
Reduce self-interest, diminish desire.
Forget things, forget the self."

**Verse:**
Let not the three minds run wild,
Nor permit a single thought to rage.
Sights, sounds, knowledge, and perception—
No longer subject to reflection.

Abandon learning, be without care.
No affairs weigh upon the heart.
*Wei* and *ah*—
How far apart?
Not far.
Good and evil—
How distant?
Vastly so.

What people fear,
One cannot but fear.
Good and evil are to be feared.
How boundless and unending!

The common folk bustle and rejoice,
As if feasting at a grand sacrifice,
As if ascending a springtime terrace—
Insatiable in their cravings.

I alone remain still, without sign,
Like an infant who has not yet learned to smile—
Serene and desireless.
Adrift, as if with no place to return.

Flowing with natural spontaneity,
The common folk all have excess,
While I alone seem to lack—
Those driven by greed and striving are ever anxious,
Those who forget scheming are ever joyful.

How muddled is this heart of mine!
Turbid and still,
Dim and silent.
The common folk are bright and clear,
While I alone seem benighted;
The common folk display their treasures outwardly,
The sage conceals illumination within.
The common folk are sharp and discerning,
While I alone remain dull and obscure.
Dull as a closed gate.
The common folk make distinctions,
The sage knows no "this" nor "that."

Vague as dusk,
Unknowing, unperceiving.
Drifting as if without destination,
Nothing grasped, nothing clung to.
The common folk all have their uses,
While I alone seem stubborn and coarse.
The common folk all possess abilities,
The sage alone appears without skill.

I alone differ from others,
Not taking the ten thousand phenomena as companions,
Yet I prize feeding at the Mother’s breast—
Prizing the savor of the Dao.

**Chapter Twenty**
To "abandon learning" is to relinquish all that one possesses,
Thus it follows the abandonment of the sage.
The common folk devote themselves to learning matters,
Augmenting what they have heard,
Ever fearful their progress is not refined—
Thus they are ever anxious.
The sage discards all possession,
Devoting himself solely to savoring the Dao,
As one seeks nourishment from the Mother,
Abiding in femininity and embracing the One—
Thus he is without care.
This is called "abandoning learning to be without care."

**Eulogy:**
The moment one speaks of abandoning learning,
The mouth has already erred.
Vast knowledge and wide discernment
Lead one further astray unawares.
Though all worldly affairs are forgotten,
One still falls into the second mechanism of another’s design.

The bearing of great virtue
Accommodates all without exception,
Following only the Dao.
At ease within the dharma.

The Dao as a thing—
Only vague, only elusive.
The Heaven of original nature.
Elusive, yet within it there are images;
This is the undifferentiated Heaven.
Vague, yet within it there are things;
This is the luminous Heaven.
Dark and deep, within it there is essence;
This is the enduring Heaven.
Its essence is utterly real,
Pure and without falsity.
Within it there is sincerity—
Vibrant and alive.

From ancient times to the present,
Its name has never departed,
Ever abiding through kalpas.
By this, the myriad beginnings are surveyed.
How do I know the nature of the myriad beginnings?
By this.

The preceding twenty-one chapters—
The previous chapter states, "I alone differ from others, for my virtue is great."
Thus follows "The bearing of great virtue," speaking of its vast embrace and all-encompassing nature.
What then is this "Dao as a thing"? What thing is it?
With images, with things, with essence—does it truly exist?
To call it existent, one lacks the eye of practiced insight;
To call it nonexistent, one equally lacks the eye of practiced insight.
How, after all, is it to be understood? Hmph!

**Verse:**
From ancient times, a single thing—
Yet none have known it.
Raise your brows, and bare bone appears in empty space.
Should you hesitate or deliberate,
A thunderclap splits the void.

Bent, it remains whole;
The unhewn tree endures.
Twisted, it straightens;
To yield is to extend.
Hollow, it fills—
*Wā*, deep as a gourd.
Humble, it gains.
Worn, it renews;
Obscured, it shines of itself.
Little, it attains;
To know cessation is lasting sufficiency.
Much, it confounds;
Affairs in excess breed chaos.

Thus the sage embraces the One as the model for all under Heaven.
The One governs the many.
Not self-displaying, thus luminous;
Worn, it renews.
Not self-asserting, thus distinguished;
Hollow, it fills.
Not self-boasting, thus meritorious;
Twisted, it straightens.
Not self-exalting, thus exalted.
Bent, it remains whole.
Only through non-contention,
Holding to softness,
Does none under Heaven contend with him.
Blended into oneness.

The ancient saying "Bent, it remains whole"—was this empty words?
It is true and real speech.
In perfect sincerity, return to it.
Preserve its original wholeness.

Chapter Twenty-Two
Bent yet whole, crooked yet straight,
Hollow yet full, worn yet renewed—
these continue the preceding chapter’s discourse on the virtue of the profound.
From "Not self-displaying" onward,
all warn against excess and exhort humility.
Humble and lowly, thus without contention;
without contention, one preserves one’s original wholeness,
embraces the primordial and guards the One,
returning to the boundless.
Hence it is said: "In perfect sincerity, return to it.
Preserve its original wholeness."

*Verse:*
Heed not the faults of others,
Nor boast of your own strengths.
Faults and strengths—no dual vision,
Nowhere can they be concealed.

"Few words accord with nature."
Speech lies not in the tongue.
"Whirlwinds do not last the morning,
Violence does not endure."
"Sudden rains do not last the day."
Impatience does not long prevail.
Who brings this about?
Who is the master?
Heaven and Earth—
all know this.
Yet even Heaven and Earth cannot last forever;
how much less can man?
Thus one who engages with the Dao
follows principle and aligns with the track.

Those who accord with the Dao are one with the Dao;
unity is seen as one.
Those who accord with virtue are one with virtue;
no single view arises.
Those who accord with loss are one with loss;
no distinctions exist.
Those who are one with the Dao,
the Dao delights in attaining them—
I am one with the Dao, the Dao is one with me.
Those who are one with virtue,
virtue delights in attaining them—
I am one with virtue, virtue is one with me.
Those who are one with loss,
loss delights in attaining them—
I am one with loss, loss is one with me.
"Trust is insufficient, thus disbelief arises."
I doubt things, things doubt me.

Chapter Twenty-Three
"Few words accord with nature"—
this continues the preceding chapter’s discourse on non-contention.
"Not self-displaying" means responding well without speaking.
"Whirlwinds and sudden rains"
are metaphors for reckless action and impetuous advance that do not last.
One who engages with the Dao
harmonizes with virtue and power,
blends with all things,
naturally resonates with them,
and things naturally respond in kind.
If one’s words do not accord with the Dao,
or one acts recklessly,
one cannot gain others’ trust,
but is instead slighted by them.
The *Book of Changes* says:
"Words and deeds are the hinge and spring of the noble one,
the master of honor and disgrace—
how can one not be cautious?"

*Verse:*
The Dao is not different from people,
People merely deem it so.
One Buddha is all Buddhas,
The mind is the ground of the Tathāgata.

"One who stands on tiptoe does not stand firm"—
impetuous advance yields no merit.
"One who strides cannot walk"—
haste does not bring success.
"One who self-displays is not luminous"—
cannot conceal one’s power.
"One who self-asserts is not distinguished"—
cannot humble oneself.
"One who self-boasts has no merit"—
cannot restrain oneself.
"One who self-exalts does not endure"—
cannot contain oneself.
In relation to the Dao, these are called
"leftover food and redundant conduct."
Redundant growths and excess.
Things may revile them—
all find them unlovely.
Thus one who possesses the Dao does not dwell in them.
The enlightened act otherwise.

Chapter Twenty-Four
This chapter collectively confirms the preceding three.
"One who stands on tiptoe does not stand firm,
One who strides cannot walk"—
this refers to "whirlwinds and sudden rains."
"Self-displaying, self-asserting,
self-exalting, self-boasting"—
all are private intentions.
Private intentions, once fixed, harm the public—
how can they endure?
Thus one who possesses the Dao does not dwell in them.
"Leftover food and redundant conduct" are unlovely.

*Verse:*
Standing on tiptoe is fundamentally delusion,
Striding is inherently madness.
Even if one succeeds in some affair,
In the end it is not as good as constancy.

There is a thing, chaotically formed—
this is Heaven’s undifferentiated state.
Born before Heaven—
this is Heaven’s transparent state.
Silent, empty, profoundly still—
it stands alone, unchanging,
transcendent and self-existent.
It revolves without end—
its transformations are inexhaustible.
It may be called the Mother of all under Heaven,
nurturing and sustaining all.
I do not know its name—
it is fundamentally nameless.
I style it "Dao"—
a name given in response to things.
Forcibly, I name it "Great."
Boundless.
"Great" means "passing away"—
without boundaries.
"Passing away" means "far-reaching"—
without limits.
"Far-reaching" means "returning"—
gathering and returning.
Thus the Dao is great,
the Great Void without form.
Heaven is great—
it models itself on the Dao.
Earth is great—
it models itself on Heaven.
The king is also great—
he models himself on Earth.
Within the realm, there are four greats—
is there yet another great?
The king occupies one of them—
alone he is honored in the Three Realms.
Man models himself on Earth—
nothing is not borne.
Earth models itself on Heaven—
nothing is not contained.
Heaven models itself on the Dao—
nothing is not encompassed.
The Dao models itself on nature.

Chapter Twenty-Five
This chapter follows the preceding, which states that "one who possesses the Dao does not dwell" in such things,
and here elucidates the work of dwelling in the Dao.
From "There is a thing, chaotically formed" onward,
the entire passage is the essential teaching of embodying the Dao.
From "Within the realm, there are four greats" onward,
all is wondrous and sublime.
People know only that within the realm there are four greats,
yet do not realize that this very self is even greater.

*Verse:*
Though Heaven and Earth are great,
They too decay and crumble.
Only this one thing
Endures through kalpas unchanged.
The sacred, unknowable one—
all abides in thusness, unmoving.

"Heaviness is the root of lightness,
Lightness is born of heaviness."
"Stillness is the ruler of restlessness"—
stillness governs movement.
Thus the noble one, though traveling all day,
does not part from the baggage train—
dares not act lightly.
Though there be splendid sights,
he dwells in serene detachment—
constantly responsive, constantly still.
How can the lord of ten thousand chariots
treat his person lightly in the world?
To bear the burden lightly.
Lightness loses ministers,
Impetuousness loses the ruler.
Seeking glory brings disgrace.

Chapter Twenty-Six
Heaviness must not be treated lightly.
"Lightness loses ministers,
Impetuousness loses the ruler"—
this is what is meant by "one who stands on tiptoe does not stand firm,
one who strides cannot walk,"
and is also a metaphor for "whirlwinds and sudden rains."
"Not parting from the baggage train" means
bearing the burden and carrying the load.
"Dwelling in serene detachment" means
turning things around.
This clarifies the preceding chapter’s discourse on modeling oneself on the Dao,
summarizes the two chapters on embodying the Dao,
and continues with the essential teaching of good conduct in the following chapter.

*Verse:*
Impetuous advance cannot endure,
Lightness cannot accomplish anything.

One whose heels never touch the ground
still treads the journey’s path.
The perfect traveler leaves no wheel tracks—
tracks form where heels press down.
The perfect speaker finds no fault in words—
words take shape where the tongue begins.
The perfect planner needs no counting rods—
one insight melts ten thousand things.
The perfect closure needs no bolt nor bar,
yet cannot be opened—
no seam or crack remains.
The perfect knot needs no cord nor tie,
yet cannot be undone—
no binding or constraint is left.

Thus the sage is ever skilled at saving others,
and so no one is cast aside—
cultivating the self to bring peace to the people.
Ever skilled at saving things,
and so nothing is cast aside—
adapting to the moment to benefit all.
This is called inheriting clarity—
clarity unbroken, continuous.

Therefore the good person
is the teacher of the ungood—
teaching others to be good.
The ungood person
is the resource of the good—
warning others to turn toward goodness.
If one does not value one’s teacher,
there is no goodness to be had.
If one does not cherish one’s resource,
there is no fault to be amended.
Though wise, this is great delusion—
casting aside wisdom like foolishness.
This is called the essential subtlety—
acting in accord with nature’s flow.

Chapter Twenty-Seven: Exhausting the Essence of the Preceding Chapters

In speech and action, be meticulous—then no trace remains, no blame accrues. The mind’s calculations cannot be reckoned; the mind’s closures cannot be opened; the mind’s knots cannot be untied. When the mind of Dao stands firm like this, there is no division between good and ungood. Teacher and resource are both forgotten; wisdom is set aside, and one remains all day like a fool.

**Verse:**
Steps need not depend on feet—
a skillful knot requires no thousand hands.
Touch the tip of your nose,
and the whole body becomes a mouth.
If you can thoroughly ponder this,
the forty-nine arise from the seven-sevens.

Know the masculine, yet guard the feminine—
do not exalt yourself.
Become the world’s stream,
where all tributaries return to the source.
Become the world’s stream,
and constant virtue never departs,
forged into one unbroken whole—
returning to the state of an infant,
where qi is complete.

Know the bright, yet guard the dark—
do not display yourself.
Become the world’s model,
where all dharmas return to the One.
Become the world’s model,
and constant virtue never errs,
its standard unwavering—
returning to the boundless,
where spirit is complete.

Know glory, yet guard disgrace—
do not prize yourself.
Become the world’s valley,
where all existence returns to emptiness.
Become the world’s valley,
and constant virtue is fulfilled,
profound and perfectly round—
returning to the uncarved block.
*(Pronounced "pǔ.")*
Where nature is complete.
When the uncarved block scatters, it becomes vessels,
applied to things.
The sage employs it
to establish officials and teach the people—
thus the great system remains uncut,
a teaching without words.

Chapter Twenty-Eight: Guarding the Feminine, the Dark, and Disgrace

Not seeing one’s own clarity connects to the preceding chapter’s "though wise, this is great delusion." The infant, the Great Ultimate, the uncarved block—these are the great roots of the world. Only by guarding the feminine and embracing the One can one return to the source. Govern a state with this, and without need for restraint, the people naturally become pure, and things naturally return to simplicity.

**Verse:**
Within white, the black is preserved;
within the masculine, the One Feminine is embraced.
Unbroken, the work continues—
even men can learn to nurture the infant.

Those who would seize the world and act upon it are mistaken.
I see they cannot but fail.
To wield power against bandits is fitting;
to become a bandit is not.
The world is a sacred vessel—
it cannot be acted upon.
Where action stirs, misfortune arises.
Those who act destroy it,
grasping what is not theirs, clinging to what is.
Those who seize lose it,
seeking advantage, only to fall into it.
All things bear form—
some lead, some follow;
some warm, some chill;
some strengthen, some weaken;
some uphold, some cast down.
Where this exists, that arises—
beware of following it.

Thus the sage eliminates extremes,
*(Pronounced "qù.")*
non-action.
Eliminates excess,
non-desire.
Eliminates extravagance,
non-attachment.

Chapter Twenty-Nine: Non-Action and the Perils of Force

Non-action means no trouble; action invites trouble. Those who seize lose; those who act fail—this is the warning against force. Strength and weakness, upholding and casting down, depend on one another like shadow following form. Where there is success, there is failure. Thus the sage eliminates greed, excess, and arrogance, deeply warning later generations.

**Verse:**
Leading and following, warming and chilling,
strengthening and weakening, upholding and casting down—
who is the master in their midst?
It is no one.
Dressing and eating are ordinary matters—
why trouble yourself with needless doubt?

Those who assist a ruler with the Dao do so through non-action.
Do not seek to strengthen the world with arms,
but defend it with compassion.
Such deeds swiftly return—
*(Pronounced "xuán.")*
good and evil alike bear fruit.
Where armies encamp,
thorns and brambles grow.
Where the mind’s troops arise,
the sacred ground lies barren.
After great armies pass,
years of famine follow.
Where demonic forces gallop,
essence and qi are depleted.

Thus the good accomplish their ends and stop—
*(Pronounced "yǐ.")*
where there is decisiveness, life arises.
They dare not seize strength,
but meet force with softness.
Accomplishing without boasting—
eliminating extremes.
Accomplishing without flaunting—
eliminating excess.
Accomplishing without arrogance—
eliminating extravagance.
Accomplishing only when unavoidable—
even in hardship, this is the way.
Thus they accomplish without forcing—
lowering the banner of the sword.

When things reach their prime, they age;
when arms grow strong, they do not prevail.
This is called "not-Dao"—
a mistake.
Those who depart from the Dao perish early,
forever losing the true Way.

Chapter Thirty: Assisting Rulers with the Dao

Continuing the preceding chapter’s elimination of excess and extravagance: those who assist rulers with the Dao do not exalt military might. Good and evil alike bear fruit—this warns those who govern states and families to guard the feminine, embrace the One, and be brave in their restraint. Even when unavoidable, they dare not seize strength, thus it is said: "The good accomplish their ends and stop."

**Verse:**
Do not let the three minds run wild—
let the will always lead the intent.
Suddenly, if forced into battle,
one arrow settles Mount Tian.

Fine weapons are inauspicious tools.
After great armies pass, years of famine follow.
Some may detest them—
*(Pronounced "wù.")*
where armies encamp, thorns and brambles grow.
Thus those who embody the Dao do not dwell there.
*(Pronounced "chǔ.")*
Where the mind’s troops do not arise.

The noble person at rest values the left,
embracing softness.
In war, they value the right,
embracing hardness.
Weapons are inauspicious tools,
used to suppress rebellion—
not the tools of the noble person,
who constantly governs.
Only when unavoidable are they used,
with tranquility as the highest aim,
defending with compassion.
Victory is not glorified—
to do so is to seek merit.
This is delighting in killing.
*(Pronounced "yuè.")*
Indulging in hardness and bravery.
Those who delight in killing
plant the seeds of misfortune—
they cannot prevail in the world,
for the Creator does not tolerate them.

Auspicious affairs value the left,
embracing life.
Inauspicious affairs value the right,
embracing death.
The deputy general stands on the left,
valuing softness.
The supreme general stands on the right,
valuing hardness.
This is to handle them with mourning rites—
inauspicious tools.
When many are killed,
it is unavoidable—
mourn them with sorrow and tears.
*(One says: compassion.)*
When victorious in battle,
handle it with mourning rites,
as if grieving for parents.

Chapter Thirty-One: Weapons as Inauspicious Tools

Not seeking to strengthen the world with arms, the text follows with "weapons are inauspicious tools," deeply warning the sage about this.

Beneath the myriad generations, lords of states who embrace non-action and purity bring about governance and transformation naturally, so that households and nations alike attain tranquility. Though they possess armor and weapons, they have no occasion to deploy them, forever free from the calamity of strife and contention.

In praise it is said:
Silent, the realm of pure mystery,
Limpid, nurturing the Great Harmony.
Inverted, the sword of samādhi is grasped,
Sequentially, the five skandha-demons are transformed.

The Dao is ever nameless, empty and self-so.
Though the Unhewn is minute to the point of imperceptibility,
none under Heaven dare make it a subject.
Supreme it is.
Should lords and kings be able to preserve it,
embracing the One,
the myriad things will of themselves become guests,
none failing to submit.

Heaven and Earth unite,
aided only by virtue,
to send down sweet dew—
the result of harmonious qi.
The people, without command, of themselves attain balance.
*(Command: read in the departing tone.)*
Naturally they achieve peace.
When first systems are established, names arise,
laws and institutions are set forth.
Once names exist,
likes and dislikes are shown.
Thus they will know where to halt.
*(This is to make them know prohibitions.)*
Knowing where to halt is how one avoids peril.
Knowing contentment is how one abides in constant joy.
The Dao’s presence in the world
comes to rest in utmost goodness,
as streams and valleys
come to rest in rivers and seas—
in lowliness.

Chapter Thirty-Two:
The preceding chapter states that “those with the Dao do not dwell [in contention],” and here it says, “The Dao is ever nameless; though the Unhewn is small, none under Heaven dare make it a subject.” This clarifies the essential dwelling of those with the Dao. The person of the Dao outwardly abides beneath the chariot, inwardly embraces the One Real, and the myriad things naturally transform. Heavenly principle is spontaneously so, merging with spiritual transformation—boundless.

In praise it is said:
Once you grasp the Unhewn without flaw,
you can freely release and gather.
Then the great chiliocosm
is held in the tip of a hair.

Knowing others is wisdom,
manifest outwardly.
Knowing oneself is clarity,
manifest inwardly.
Overcoming others requires strength,
courage in daring.
Overcoming oneself requires strength,
courage in not daring.
Knowing contentment is wealth—
even in poverty, one is joyful.
Those who persevere in action have resolve,
ever unassailable.
Those who do not lose their grasp endure,
their will and power grow ever firmer,
their life’s foundation ever more secure.
Those who “die yet do not perish” attain longevity.
*(Longevity: read in the rising tone.)*
The True One abides constantly.

Chapter Thirty-Three:
Knowing others and overcoming others pertain to the external.
Knowing oneself and overcoming oneself reside within.
This confirms the warning of the preceding three chapters against the use of arms.
Those who know contentment find joy even in poverty.
Those who persevere in action see all things accomplished.
Those who firmly hold their ground face no peril.
Those inwardly illuminated transcend life and death.
“Dying yet not perishing” means the True One abides constantly.

In praise it is said:
Seeing things yet not seeing nature,
knowing others yet not knowing oneself—
such unlearned sorts
still claim to have gained advantage.

The Great Dao overflows,
vast and all-encompassing.
It can be to the left or right,
without limit.
The myriad things rely on it to live, yet it does not refuse;
where it passes, transformation occurs.
Its work is accomplished, yet it claims no possession—
what remains is spirit.
It nurtures and sustains the myriad things yet does not act as their lord,
forgetting its own origin.
Ever desireless, still and unmoving,
it may be called “small.”
*(A mustard seed contains Mount Sumeru.)*
The myriad things return to it, yet it does not act as their lord,
letting things follow their natural course.
It may be called “great.”
*(Mount Sumeru contains a mustard seed.)*
Thus the sage never regards himself as great,
*(Abiding within a mustard seed.)*
and so is able to accomplish greatness—
beyond measure.

Chapter Thirty-Four:
“The Great Dao overflows” means it is utterly vast, penetrating the most subtle, lacking nothing. “The myriad things rely on it to live yet it does not refuse” and what follows connect to the preceding chapter’s “those who do not lose their grasp endure.” Applied to governing the state, this means not losing one’s grasp; applied to self-cultivation, it means “dying yet not perishing.” Hence it is said, “It can be to the left or right.”

In praise it is said:
The Great Dao is truly hard to fathom,
empty space cannot be measured.
Vast and boundless, forming a single expanse—
where are its borders?

Grasping the Great Image,
*(Image: read in the rising tone.)*
though one looks, it cannot be seen—
all under Heaven come to it.

The myriad people submit.
They come without harm, and the myriad things flourish.
In peace and great tranquility,
the ten thousand transformations rest secure.

Music and delicacies—
*(Music: read as "yào.")*
both sound and flavor are exquisite.
They entice the passing traveler to stay.
Yet when the traveler passes, they cease.

The Dao that issues from the mouth
is bland, as if without flavor.
*(Issues: read in the falling tone.)*
Without sound, without scent,
gazing, one cannot see it—
the Great Image has no form.
Listening, one cannot hear it—
the Great Tone is soundless.
Its use cannot be exhausted.

The Dao is hidden, without name;
its use is inexhaustible.

Chapter Thirty-Five:
The closing line of the preceding chapter states, "Hence it can accomplish greatness," so this chapter follows with "Grasping the Great Image, all under Heaven come," meaning that preserving its formlessness draws the hearts of people and things to turn and submit. "Music and delicacies," where both sound and flavor are exquisite, lose this formlessness—how can they endure? The Dao that issues from the mouth is flavorless and formless, without sound or color. Because it has no fixed body, its responsiveness and use are inexhaustible.

In praise it is said:
A mud ox pants at the moon,
a wooden horse neighs in the wind.
Gazing, it seems to exist—
seeking, it has no trace.
The hermit’s staff at Clear Hermitage
sketches the wondrous peak of Miao Gao.
To gather it in?
One must first firmly open it—
firmly opening, it must then gather.

To weaken it, one must first firmly strengthen it—firmly strengthened, it must then weaken.
To abolish it, one must first firmly establish it—firmly established, it must then abolish.
To seize it, one must first firmly give it—firmly given, it must then seize.
This is called subtle illumination.
The slightest sign is the first omen.

The soft and weak overcome the hard and strong.
The soft and weak are ever harmonious; to employ hardness is to court defeat.
Fish cannot leave the depths—
how can man depart from the Dao?
A state’s sharp instruments must not be shown to others.
Where there is advantage, there is harm.

This is the thirty-sixth chapter.
Grasping the Great Image, one perceives the subtlest signs of affairs.
No sooner does one see firm expansion than one knows coming contraction;
before the sprout appears, the omen is already known.
Who but the subtly illuminated of all under Heaven could attain this?

Those who study the Dao preserve its formlessness and guard its utmost softness.
They contend not with things, and thus naturally know the signs.
If one employs violence, exalts stratagems and cunning,
seeking to overcome things—this is not the Dao.
For example, fish belong in water;
to seek distinction among other fish and leave the depths—is this possible?
Since it is not, then neither should man exalt power.
To exalt power is to reverse the constant—like fish leaving the depths, they must perish.

A state’s sharp instruments must not be shown to others—
this aligns with Confucius’ saying, “One may stand with them, but not weigh with them.”
Even when sages employ power, reversing the constant to accord with the Dao,
it must not be lightly done—how much less so for ordinary people?
Can one not be warned?

In praise it is said:
Eyes like shooting stars,
mechanism swift as lightning.
Gazing, it seems ahead—
suddenly, it is gone.
Within the openness and obstruction of the ten directions,
light pervades all without exception.

The Dao is ever non-action, yet nothing is left undone.
Still and unmoving, it responds and connects with all under Heaven.
Should lords and kings be able to guard it,
