the myriad things will transform of themselves.
Above, they transform those below as wind.
When transformation stirs and desires arise,
I will quell them with the nameless uncarved block.

*Act* (pronounced in the entering tone).
Without desire on my part, the people naturally return to simplicity.
The nameless uncarved block also will have no desire.
I value stillness, and the people naturally rectify themselves.
Without desire, through stillness,
the wise are made not to dare act.
All under Heaven will naturally rectify itself.

Act through non-action—
then nothing will be left ungoverned.

This is the thirty-seventh chapter.
The true and constant Dao is fundamentally non-action;
action is not the constant Dao.
This connects to the previous chapter’s subtle illumination.
Heaven and Earth act not, yet the myriad things are born and completed.
The sage acts not, yet the myriad people are at peace.
In terms of self-cultivation:
without any contrivance, in moments of stillness preserve its formlessness.
At the slightest movement, one must first awaken—
once awakened, quell it with the nameless uncarved block.
The uncarved block has no form, and is also called nameless—meaning emptiness.
The Dao is non-action; the uncarved block is nameless; the heart is without desire—
then one naturally returns to stillness.
Stillness upon stillness—
all under Heaven will naturally rectify itself.

In praise it is said:
All action is illusion;
non-action, too, falls into emptiness.
Transcending both paths,
one unfolds the essence of the lineage.

The highest virtue does not act as virtue—
thus its virtue is all the greater.

The lesser virtue does not lose virtue—
thus it clings to its own virtue.
Therefore, it has no virtue,
and its virtue is ever more lost.

The highest virtue acts without acting and without contrivance,
still and unmoving,
yet responsive and perfectly attuned.
The lesser virtue acts with contrivance,
seeking resonance through virtue,
ever scheming and striving.

The highest benevolence acts without contrivance,
bestowing kindness upon all things,
yet fundamentally without action.
The highest righteousness acts with contrivance,
engaging with things through righteousness,
ever scheming and striving.
The highest propriety acts, yet none respond—
seeking to order all things through ritual,
yet never truly ordering them.
One thrusts forth an arm to pull them back,
but the more one pulls, the less they align.

Thus, when the Dao is lost, virtue arises—close to the Dao.
When virtue is lost, benevolence arises—close to virtue.
When benevolence is lost, righteousness arises—close to benevolence.
When righteousness is lost, propriety arises—close to righteousness.
Yet propriety marks the thinning of sincerity,
the erosion of loyalty and trust,
the beginning of chaos.
It fails to order.
Foreknowledge is but the flower of the Dao,
seeking novelty without substance—
the beginning of folly,
the loss of the Dao.

Therefore, the great person dwells in depth, not in shallowness,
values substance and truth, not recognition.
Abides in reality, not in its blossoms,
upholds sincerity, not propriety.
Thus, one discards that and embraces this—
forsakes delusion to follow truth.

**Chapter Thirty-Eight**
The preceding chapter spoke of the Dao’s constant non-action,
so this follows with the highest virtue’s non-virtue.
The highest virtue acts without acting, thus aligning with the Dao.
The lesser virtue acts with contrivance, thus misaligning with the Dao.
Benevolence and righteousness remain close to virtue,
serving as steps toward the Dao.
Propriety, however, is rife with contrivance and lacks substance—
seeking to order all things through ritual,
yet things grow ever more disordered.
For all contrivance ultimately leads to loss.
Even clinging without loss may gradually lead to refinement,
returning from benevolence and righteousness to virtue,
from virtue to the Dao,
and thus attaining non-action.

Foreknowledge is but cleverness,
and cleverness marks the beginning of the Dao’s loss.
Thus it is called the flower of the Dao—
those who possess the Dao do not dwell in it.

In praise it is said:
Before transcending the Three Realms,
how can one escape the Five Constants?
The Five Constants dissolve into formlessness,
as one strides alone to meet the August Void.

Of old, those who attained the One—
attaining the One, all things were complete.
Heaven attained the One and became clear,
profoundly still and constant.
Earth attained the One and became tranquil,
silent and unmoving.
Spirits attained the One and became numinous,
merging into truth.
Valleys attained the One and became full,
abundant and overflowing.
The myriad things attained the One and came to life,
naturally flourishing.
Lords and kings attained the One and became the standard for all under Heaven,
serene and firmly established.
Their attainment was the One.

If Heaven lacked clarity, it would fear splitting—
the stars and constellations would lose their order.
If Earth lacked tranquility, it would fear erupting—
mountains and peaks would crumble.
If spirits lacked numinosity, they would fear fading—
yin and yang would lose their harmony.
If valleys lacked fullness, they would fear exhaustion—
blocked and impassable.
If the myriad things lacked life, they would fear extinction—
the harmonious qi would dissipate.
If lords and kings lacked integrity, their loftiness and nobility would fear collapse—
their states and families would face peril.

Thus, nobility takes humility as its root—this is the One.
Loftiness takes lowliness as its foundation—this is the One.
Lords and kings call themselves "orphaned," "widowed," and "destitute,"
ever embracing the One.
Is this not taking humility as their root?
The One is the master of the ten thousand images—
is it not so?
How could it be otherwise?

Thus, when counting carts, there is no single cart—*shu*, pronounced *suo*.
When counting *wo*, there is no *wo*.
One does not wish to be as polished as jade, or as cold as stone.
Noble and base are both forgotten.

**Chapter Thirty-Nine**
The previous chapter spoke of discarding that to take this—meaning to discard the superficial and take the root.
What is the root? The One.
The One is the beginning of Heaven and Earth, the mother of the myriad things, the application of the Great Dao.
If lords and kings could guard it, the myriad things would naturally return to it.
Calling oneself "orphaned," "widowed," and "destitute" is to remain humble and not forget the root.
Not wishing to be as polished as jade or as cold as stone, forgetting noble and base—only embracing the One.
The name "counting carts" has no single cart.
The name "counting *wo*" has no single *wo*.
When the axle and wheels unite, it is called a cart.
When the four elements unite, it is called *wo*.

The ode says:
Obtaining the One is not called wondrous,
Returning to emptiness is not yet the Mysterious.
Knowing a dream is a dream within dreaming,
Beyond Heaven, do not seek Heaven.

The reversal is the movement of the Dao—
When the numinous One emerges, it is drawn back.
The weak is the application of the Dao.
Focused *qi* achieves softness.

The myriad things arise from *you* (having).
*You* has a name—it is the mother of the myriad things.
*You* arises from *wu* (non-being).
*Wu* has no name—it is the beginning of Heaven and Earth.

**Chapter Forty**
The reversal is the movement of the Dao—continuing the previous chapter’s teaching that nobility takes humility as its root.
The myriad things arise from *you*, *you* from *wu*—this is the teaching of counting carts without a cart.
Yet how many scholars do not grasp this principle truly.

Moreover, how does the Dao express the essence of *you* and *wu*?
Observe the ode:
Having form is not *you*,
Formless is not *wu*.
Neither *you* nor *wu* can stand alone—
Still, this is to fall into one-sidedness.
Only within the interplay of *you* and *wu* does one find the path—
Then one knows the Master’s hidden beard.

The superior person hears the Dao and diligently acts upon it;
The superior person resolves and unifies it all at once.

**Chapter Forty-One**
The middle scholar hears the Dao—sometimes as if it exists, sometimes as if it does not.
The mediocre and below hear much but believe little.
The lowly scholar hears the Dao and laughs at it.
Why do they not believe? Only because it is too clear.
If one does not laugh, it is not truly the Dao.
After great confusion, there must be great awakening.

Thus it is said:
At first hearing, the two fragments reveal the liver’s depths.
The Dao, though bright, is veiled in bloom—
Advancing in the Dao seems like retreat,
Looking forward and backward.
The Dao blends like harmony, like dust in the light.
Virtue’s height is like a valley—
Empty, it receives all.
Great whiteness seems like shame—
Lowly, it tends itself.
Broad virtue seems insufficient—
Full yet not overflowing.
Established virtue seems like theft—
*Thief*, pronounced *yú*, rhymes with *yú* (渝).
Sealed yet not exposed.
True substance, like *yú*, adapts without measure.
The greatest square has no corners—
No sharp angles revealed.
Great vessels mature late—
No claim to their own achievement.
Great sound is rare—
Strike it, and it responds.
Great form is shapeless.
Nothing is more hidden than what is concealed.
The Dao is hidden, nameless—
Nothing is more manifest than the subtle.

Only the Dao
Lends itself well and brings completion.
Loyalty and reciprocity—nothing more.

---

The previous chapter spoke of *you* and *wu* generating each other—
A teaching only the noble can doubt.
Thus, it follows with the superior scholar hearing the Dao.
The Dao, though veiled, though seeming retreat, though blending, though hidden like theft,
Cannot be seen—
Hence the reason for laughter upon hearing it.
Only the noble, with nature pure and empty,
Can transcend and enter directly—
Silent yet believed, effortless yet accomplished.

The mediocre and below cannot help but waver between doubt and belief;
The lowly and unworthy do not merely disbelieve—they laugh and scorn it.

*"Lends itself well and brings completion"* means:
Lending to the lowly’s laughter and scorn,
While completing the superior’s diligent practice.

Even the lowly and unworthy—
Once awakened at the start,
Can turn back to goodness.
Why should anyone be abandoned for their failings?

The ode says:
The supreme Dao is originally easy,
Yet human hearts claim it difficult.
The middle scholar still debates,
The lowly turns dull-witted.
No dull-witted star exists—
Weigh it, and the thing is on the scale.

The Dao generates One—
The void generates One *qi*.
One generates Two—
One *qi* divides into yin and yang.
Two generates Three—
Yin forms the Three Powers.
Three generates the myriad things.
The Three Powers generate myriad forms.
The myriad things bear yin and embrace yang,
Taking form from Heaven, shape from Earth.
The harmonizing *qi* is the middle.
Examine the *qi* of middle harmony.

What people detest—
The solitary, the orphaned, the unpaired,
The cornerless—
Is what rulers prize.
They call themselves solitary and orphaned.
Thus, all things have form.
Sometimes, diminishing benefits,
The humble receive gain.
Sometimes, adding causes loss—
The full must overturn.
What people teach is always for goodness—
Yet it is also my righteous teaching.
I am also like this.

The mighty and overbearing shall not meet their end.
The strong and powerful are doomed to perish.
I shall take this as my guiding principle.

The unvirtuous become the foundation for the virtuous.

**Chapter Forty-Two:**
One is the mother of all things.
What people detest—this One without pair,
The solitary, the orphaned, the unpaired—
The great lords and nobles do not forget their roots,
And thus call themselves solitary and orphaned,
In humility and self-effacement.

Those who are humble and self-effacing shall surely receive benefit,
While the strong and powerful shall surely invite calamity.

The Sage establishes this teaching,
To warn people to restrain themselves and practice humility,
To see what is unvirtuous and inwardly reflect upon it.

**Ode:**
To love victory is to often meet adversity,
To practice humility is to long endure peace.
Gentleness and harmony are daily virtues,
In every place, the realm of kings and mountains.

The utmost softness in the world
Overcomes the utmost hardness in the world.
Softness can erode hardness.
There is nothing that cannot enter where there are no gaps.
Piercing metal, penetrating stone.

Thus, I know the benefit of *wuwei*.
Humility brings benefit.
Teaching without words,
Silent yet trusted.
The benefit of *wuwei* is achieved through *wuwei*.
Few in the world can attain this.
Those who understand harmony are rare.

**Chapter 43:**
The previous chapter spoke of the lonely and widowed who do not turn their wheels [of action], the utmost humility. Hence, it follows with the utmost softness.
It means that softness overcomes hardness, that loss contains benefit, and that loss upon loss reaches *wuwei* [non-action].
Without speaking, yet trustworthy; the benefit of *wuwei*, few in the world attain.
**Ode:**
When met with opposition, do not compete,
When matters pass, let the heart remain cool.
This very realm of coolness,
Where even the heavens and earth cannot conceal it.
Which is closer—name or body?
A high name brings dishonor to the body.
Which is more abundant—body or wealth?
Excess wealth brings harm to oneself.
Which is more harmful—gain or loss?
Gained favor invites dishonor.
Thus, the more one loves, the greater the expense,
The more one covets others’ possessions, the more one clings to them.
The more one hoards, the greater the loss.
Seeking advantage only brings misfortune.
Knowing sufficiency brings no dishonor; sufficiency stops greed.
Knowing restraint brings no peril; fearing restraint averts calamity.
Thus, one may endure long.
Knowing sufficiency is always sufficiency.

**Chapter 44:**
The previous chapter spoke of the benefit of *wuwei*, meaning that action brings loss.
Hence, it follows with: *Which is closer—name or body?*
Name, wealth, gain, and loss are all rooted in action; they cannot endure long.
Only knowing sufficiency and restraint can endure long.
**Ode:**
All things in the world are transient,
None can last eternally.
Tame the restless monkey-mind,
Listen to the lion’s roar.
If one can unleash the treasure within the family,
Then the spring blooms like birdsong in mountain flowers.
The greatest attainment seems incomplete,
Yet its use knows no exhaustion. (*弊* rhymes with *鳖*)
Not self-displaying, hence unbroken.
The greatest abundance seems to overflow,
Yet its use is inexhaustible.
Not self-satisfied, hence without end.
The greatest uprightness seems to bend,
Yet it does not flaunt.
The greatest skill seems clumsy,
Yet it does not rely on artifice.
The greatest discernment seems inarticulate,
Yet it shines without glare.
Agitation overcomes coldness—
The reckless burn.
Calm overcomes heat—
The tranquil cool.
Purity and stillness are the Dao of the world.
If people can abide in purity and stillness,
All under heaven will return to them.

**Chapter 45:**
The previous chapter spoke of purity and stillness as the Dao of the world, so it follows with: *The greatest attainment seems incomplete...*
Those with virtue in excess yet action in deficit live long,
Those with wealth in excess yet action in deficit are despised.
The greatest attainment seems incomplete,
The greatest abundance seems to overflow,
Even to the utmost bending, clumsiness, and inarticulateness—
All are virtue in excess yet action in deficit,
Their use is inexhaustible.
Thus, they are the Dao of the world.
**Ode:**
Human nature knows gathering and scattering,
The world’s ways have rise and decline.
Only the True Constant endures,
Unchanged from ancient to modern.
To transform the world there is a method:
Emotions follow nature.
To curb the warhorses with dung,
The mind-horse is idle, the spirit-sprout flourishes.
When the world lacks the Dao,
Nature follows emotions.
Warhorses are born in the suburbs.
The mind-horse rages, the heart’s ground is desolate.
No guilt is greater than craving,
The root of dishonor.
No calamity is greater than not knowing sufficiency,
The trap that ensnares the body.
No blame is greater than desiring gain,
The origin of self-destruction.
Thus, knowing sufficiency is always sufficiency.
The contented poor find joy in their lot.

**Chapter 46:**
The previous chapter spoke of purity and stillness as the Dao of the world, so it follows with: *The world’s ways have rise and decline...*
Not stepping outside yet knowing the world—
This speaks of the Daoist who knows the inner yet ignores the outer, continuing the previous chapter’s meaning.
To know the inner yet ignore the outer
Is to know nothing yet see nothing.
If one only knows the outer and sees the outer while forgetting the inner,
Then one’s knowledge and vision are shallow and narrow.
**Ode:**
Morning I wander the Southern Peak,
Evening I rest in the Azure Mound.
Swiftly a thousand miles,
Yet never have I strayed from it.
Tread iron shoes to no avail—
The sought is found without effort.
To study is to daily increase,
To practice the Dao is to daily decrease.
Decrease upon decrease,
All loss is exhausted.
Until reaching *wuwei* [non-action],
Where nothing more can be lost.
In *wuwei*, yet nothing is undone.
Nothing is unconquered.
To take the world, one must act with no affairs,
For affairs arise from the mind’s fixation.
When affairs arise, the mind’s fixation cannot be attained.
Thus, it is insufficient to take the world.
Action always has an end.

**Chapter 47:**
Not stepping outside yet knowing the world—
This is inner knowledge.
The farther one goes, the more distant,
Outer affairs.
Hence, it follows with: *To study is to daily increase...*
It means the unlearned seek only gain,
But those who practice the Dao decrease in all things.
The *Yijing* says: *Mountains below, marshes above—loss. The superior person restrains anger and checks desires.*
This is exactly so.
When even anger is extinguished and desire is lost,
Until reaching *wuwei* [non-action],
Then all under heaven is transformed and the world returns to order.
If one acts recklessly,
The people are disordered and difficult to govern.
Thus, it is insufficient to take the world.

**Chapter 49:**
The ode says:
*With learning, confusion grows at every turn,*
*Without action, all things fall into place.*
*When both learning and action are abandoned,*
*Loss and gain are left to others.*

Do not mock my humble, poverty-stricken appearance,
For from old it is said that thieves do not rob the poor.

The sage has no fixed mind,
No rigid method of action.
He takes the hearts of the people as his own.
He follows the Way’s spontaneous responses,
Adjusting to circumstances.

To the virtuous, I am virtuous;
I follow them and do virtuous deeds.
To the unvirtuous, I am also virtuous;
I guide them to return to virtue.
*Virtue’s power is complete*—
It fulfills their highest good.

To the faithful, I am faithful;
I follow them and do faithful deeds.
To the unfaithful, I am also faithful;
I guide them to return to faith.
*Faith’s power is complete*—
It fulfills their highest truth.

The sage moves through the world in reverence—
*惵惵* (*jùn-jùn*), trembling with care,
*兢兢业业* (*jìng-jìng yèyè*), diligent and unwavering—
Yet he blends the hearts of the people,
*浑* (*hún*), leveling them as one.
Different paths, the same end.
All the people turn their ears and eyes toward him;
His bearing is dignified, his deeds a model.
The sage nurtures them as children.
Under heaven, one great family.

The preceding chapter spoke of *wuwei* [non-action] taking the world,
So it follows with: *The sage has no fixed mind.*
By *no fixed mind*, it means
Following the Way’s spontaneous responses,
Never opposing the natural inclinations of the people.
Thus, the people obey the sage’s words,
Emulate the sage’s actions,
Follow the sage’s transformation,
And the world unites in one heart.

The ode says:
*To the faithful, I follow their faith,*
*To the virtuous, I follow their virtue.*
If one could truly understand this,
Yet still cling to inverted views—
*颠倒见* (*diāndào jiàn*, inverted perception)—
Then the Three Realms become one expanse,
And the ten directions merge into a single plane.
Emerging from birth, entering death,
Passing through the gates of anger and desire.

Those who live abandon anger and desire,
Yet thirteen in ten perish by water or fire.
Those who die indulge in anger and desire,
Yet thirteen in ten are spared by water or fire.
All life depends on water and fire.
To stir them toward death’s path,
Water and fire clash against them—
Also thirteen in ten.
*Water* completes its cycle in six,
*Fire* in seven.
Why so?
It is anger and desire that cause this.

「With its profound nurturing of life,
Anger and desire do not cease,
Greed for life is insatiable.
It is said that those who skillfully guard life
Have no anger or desire.

Traveling by land, they meet no tigers or rhinoceroses—
*兕* (*rì*, rhinoceros).
In self-reflection, they feel no guilt,
So what need for worry or fear?
Entering battle, they are not harmed by armor or weapons,
Their hearts unobstructed, so no dread exists.
The rhinoceros has no place to lodge its horn,
The tiger no place to set its claws,
Weapons no place to hold their blades.
If one does not cling to life,
How could there be death?
Why so?
The body is not mine to possess,
Death cannot harm me—
For I dwell in the realm of no-death.

Forgetting birth and death,
Thus the right fifty-first chapter:
The gentle and weak are those who guard life,
The strong and mighty are those who perish.
The gentle and weak can curb anger and desire,
While the strong and mighty are enslaved by them.
To curb anger, fire descends and is extinguished,
To restrain desire, water rises and is contained.
When water and fire are harmonized, life is sustained—
Hence they are called *those who guard life*.
Anger stirs the fire of ignorance,
Desire churns like ocean waves,
When water and fire clash, death ensues—
Hence they are called *those who perish*.
The strong and mighty greed for life without limit,
The gentle and weak regard death as returning home,
For they do not see death as death,
So what harm can tigers, rhinoceroses, armor, or weapons do to them?

In terms of the *Dan Dao* (Alchemical Dao),
When water and fire are harmonized, the *saintly embryo* (聖胎) congeals.
The ode says:
*Nirvana* (涅盘) is easy to grasp in the heart,
But discriminative wisdom is hard to discern.
Without discriminative wisdom,
How could there be death or life?
The *Dao* gives birth,
The *Yuan Shi* (元始) is the primal *qi* (祖气).
The *virtue/power* (德) nurtures it—
*Nurture* (畜), pronounced *xiù* (凶入声).
It transforms and gives birth to all the *Realms of Existence* (诸天).
It shapes all things—
In the heavens, it forms *images* (象).
By *effort* (势), it shapes forms on earth.
Thus all things, with their myriad forms,
Do not fail to honor the Dao and cherish virtue/power.
All arise from the Dao,
The Dao’s grandeur, virtue’s nobility—
Exceeding the ancients, surpassing the present.

None know their rank yet remain ever natural,
They do not speak of goodness in response.
Thus the Dao gives birth, nurtures, and preserves—
*Qi* (神) is complete.
It grows and fosters—
*Qi* (气) is complete.
It matures and perfects—
*Essence* (精) is complete.
It nourishes and shelters—
Form is complete.
Life is given yet not possessed,
Forgetting the *mechanisms* (机).
Action is taken yet not relied upon,
Forgetting the *affections* (情).
It grows yet is never slaughtered,
Forgetting all things—
This is called *mysterious virtue/power* (玄德),
In harmony with the Dao.

Thus the right fifty-first chapter:
Those who skillfully guard life
Know the realm of no-death,
Hence they follow with the words of *Dao-giving-birth*.
The Dao is formless,
Yet through giving birth to the heavens and earth, its form becomes visible.
The Dao is nameless,
Yet through fostering all things, its name can be established.
All things with their forms
Receive their mandate from the heavens,
Take shape from the earth,
Draw *qi* from the *Central Harmony* (中和),
All are the Dao’s manifestations—
Thus all things honor the Dao and cherish virtue/power.

The ode says:
*The Dao that can be spoken is not the true Dao*,
*The Way of non-action yet has action*.
I clearly explain it for you,
Yet all waters flow westward.
The night arrives, and the *chaos* (混沌) is plucked from the earth,
All forms and patterns remain unknown.
The world has a beginning,
Nameless—
The beginning of the heavens and earth.
They call it the *mother of the world*.
With a name—
The *mother of all things*.
Knowing its mother,
Knowing the root—
Knowing its root,
Its children reveal its end.
Knowing its children,
Knowing its future—
Returning to its mother,
Attaining the root—
The body remains unharmed,
Ever present.
Seal its *joy* (兑),
The inner realm does not escape.
Close its *gate* (门),
The outer realm does not enter.
A lifetime without exertion—
Not laboring yet governing.
Open its joy,
The inner realm emerges,
Accomplishing its affairs—
The outer realm enters.
A lifetime without salvation—
Forever losing the true Dao.

Seeing the small as *illumination* (明),
Knowing the subtle and minute (*few* and *microscopic*).
Guarding gentleness as *strength* (强).
Softness can erode hardness.
Using its *light* (光),
All things come and are illuminated.
Returning to its illumination, letting go and gathering—
No harm befalls the body.
*Letting go* (遗), pronounced *wèi* (音谓).
Beware of following others’ paths.
This is called *embracing constancy* (袭常).」

The Way gives birth—
This is the origin of the Way’s speech,
Thus it follows the beginning of all things beneath Heaven.

The final sentence is most urgent—
Those who cultivate the True Dao must turn here to the True Eye,
Lest they stray past it.

The ode proclaims:
*"Not gathering, not releasing,*
*The highest is attainable,*
*Pure and clear by nature,*
*The original form."*

Further inquiry: How is the First Principle?
All speech about the Way is slander.

Let me know—
Before action, there is awareness.
Walk the Great Dao:
Do nothing,
Yet fear only what is given.
Those who recognize the Law tremble.

The Great Dao is vast and level,
Smooth and straight,
Yet people prefer shortcuts.
*Good*—pronounced *xiào* (去声).
They take risks for luck.

When affairs are excessive, chaos follows.
*Chao*—pronounced *cháo* (音潮).
Fields lie barren, sacred lands abandoned.
Granaries are empty—
Sacred lands exhausted.
Wearing ornate robes—greed.
Wielding sharp blades—anger.
Disdaining food and drink—delusion.
Wealth in excess—desire never ceases.
This is called *robber’s pride*.

The Three Poisons stir unrest—
This is not the Way. Indeed, it is error.

The **Fifty-Third Chapter** (of the *Right* section) follows the previous chapter’s *"Climb the Constant"*—meaning the secret application of the Constant Dao—hence it continues with *"Let me know before action, there is awareness."*

With awareness, one can directly uphold and secretly apply it; without awareness, one cannot secretly apply it and acts recklessly. The mind is obscured by internal defilements and external karma and perception, compounded by ignorance, while the Three Poisons agitate—this is not the Dao, indeed it is error.

The verse praises:
*"Toying with cleverness ends in clumsiness,*
*Excessive troubles bring early decay.*
*Gold and jade fill the hall,*
*Yet how can they be kept always?*
If daily life is reversed in action,
All dust and sand of earth become treasure.*

*The well-built does not uproot,*
*Uproot—pronounced **bá** (音跋).*
*Roots deep.*
*The well-embraced does not fall,*
*Base firm.*
*Descendants’ sacrifices never cease,*
*Enduring.*

*Cultivate it in the self—self refined,*
*Its virtue becomes true;*
*Fully true.*
*Cultivate it in the family—family harmonized,*
*Its virtue overflows;*
*Abundant.*
*Cultivate it in the village—village refined,*
*Its virtue endures;*
*Long-lasting.*
*Cultivate it in the realm—realm governed,*
*Its virtue is profound;*
*Thick and rich.*
*Cultivate it in the world—world at peace,*
*Its virtue is universal.*
*The Dao flourishes.*

Thus, observe the self with the self—within, there is a single defilement, its virtue is not true.
Observe the family with the family—there is one discord, its virtue lacks abundance.
Observe the village with the village—there is one not transformed, its virtue does not endure.
Observe the realm with the realm—there is one not virtuous, its virtue is not profound.
Observe the world with the world—there is one petty man, its virtue is not universal.

How do I know the world is thus?
By this.
*Turn inward and examine oneself.*

**Chapter 54**

The preceding chapter states: *"Let me thus know with clarity—when knowledge arises, the Dao-heart is steadfast, unshaken in its holding, hence it follows."* For what is well-established cannot be uprooted.

With this, one cultivates the self, observes the heart, and examines nature—when the heart is settled, the self is refined.
With this, one governs the realm, observes the people, and examines oneself—when the people are transformed, the realm is governed.

If Heaven’s order has even one flaw, then it is because one’s own governance and transformation are flawed.
As the *Book of Documents* says: *"When the people err, it lies with one man."*
This is what is meant.

Reflecting inward, if the heart harbors even a speck of defilement or attachment, then it is because my innate nature has not yet been illuminated.

**Ode:**
To observe the realm is no simple task,
To observe the self—its meaning runs yet deeper.
When the sea dries, its depths are revealed,
But when a man dies, his heart remains unknown.

Rich in virtue, he withdraws into seclusion—
Like the infant.
Pure and undivided.
Venomous creatures do not sting him,
Fierce beasts do not seize him,
Raptors do not strike him.

(*Shì* [螫], pronounced *shì* [释]. *Jué* [攫] and *yǎn* [玃], both pronounced *jué* [厥缚切].)

「I lose myself in things, and things lose themselves in me.
My bones are frail, my sinews soft, yet my grasp is firm.
(*Sīn* [筋], pronounced *jīn* [斤].)
My spirit is whole.
I do not know the union of male and female yet *yīn* [绞] arises,
(*Yīn* [绞], even tone.)
My essence is whole—
the utmost of essence.
Natural and unrestrained.
I wail all day yet my voice does not grow hoarse—
even tone.
My *qi* is whole.
The utmost of harmony.
Knowing harmony, I call it constant—
this is the Dao’s undifferentiated unity.
Knowing constancy, I call it clarity—
this is the Dao’s boundless openness.

To nurture life is to invite misfortune;
to increase is to bring loss.
When the heart commands *qi*, it becomes strong.
When *qi* moves, it becomes rigid.
When things grow robust, they age;
when rigid, they easily break.
This is called *not the Dao*.
(*Cuò* [错].)
Not the Dao is already premature death.
To lose one’s innate truth.

**Chapter 55:**
The well-founded is unshaken—
the depth of virtue.
Thus, I follow it with the verse:
*"To hold the primordial face,
First preserve the infant’s heart.
This heart ever unobscured,
Reveals the golden body of dharma.
The wise do not speak,
Silence accomplishes all.
Speakers do not know—
The threefold mystery of the tongue.
Close the mouth of speech,
No words escape.
Shut the gate of sight,
No forms enter.
Blunt the sharpness of strife,
No contention.
Unravel the tangled,
No affairs.
Harmonize its radiance,
No self remains.
Merge with the dust of things,
No others exist.
This is called *Mysterious Unity*.
One thread runs through all.
Thus, it cannot be grasped as near,
Forgetting emotion.
It cannot be cast aside as distant;
Forgetting form.
It cannot be exploited for gain,
Forgetting things.
It cannot be harmed by schemes,
Forgetting craft.
It cannot be prized as noble,
Forgetting possession.
It cannot be scorned as base,
Forgetting absence.
Thus, it is most noble in the world.
All forgetting exhausted, only true constancy remains."*

**Chapter 56:**
To hold virtue’s depth is to remain silent,
Thus, I follow it with the verse:
*"The wise do not speak,
For there is nothing to be said.
Non-speech is the Dao itself.
This is precisely what is meant.

I say that many words bring gain,
But silence brings no harm.
Alas.
The verse goes:
Cutting off gain ends all harm,
No closeness means no distance.
Much speech invites loss,
Better to be like *Zhuīlú* [觜卢] in retreat.
With rectitude govern the realm—
no partiality, no favoritism.
With spontaneity wield the military—
no schemes, no stratagems.
With non-action take the world—
no doing, no grasping."*

**Chapter 57:**
How do I know this to be so?
By this:
Nature penetrates *li* [理] and melts with *róng* [融].
The world abounds with taboos and prohibitions,
Yet the people grow ever poorer.
The delusions of desire for gain.

The people hoard many tools of profit,
And the state becomes ever more corrupt.
The dazzle of rare commodities.

Men indulge in cunning arts,
And strange objects proliferate.
The shift toward superficial tricks.

Laws and decrees grow ever more explicit,
And thieves and robbers abound.
Law begets deceit from above.
Thus, the sage says:
*"I act without doing, yet the people transform themselves;
I do not prize schemes and stratagems.
I cherish stillness, yet the people align themselves;
I do not use tools of profit.
I act without affairs, yet the people grow wealthy;
I do not honor rare commodities.
I have no desires, yet the people return to simplicity.*
Simplicity—*pǔ* [朴], pronounced *chú-bó* [蒲卜].
To govern with rectitude.

**Chapter 58:**
The previous chapter spoke of *non-speech by the wise*,
And thus attained its rectitude.
Hence, I follow with *governing with rectitude*.

Taboos abound, tools of profit abound,
Cunning arts abound, laws and decrees abound—
All these are not rectitude.
When the ruler has no taboos, the people thrive;
Cutting off schemes and stratagems, the people transform themselves;
Lightening taxes and levies, the people grow wealthy;
Guiding them with virtue, the people return to simplicity.
Acting without doing, without affairs,
Without desire, cherishing stillness—
All these are rectitude.
Govern with this, and the seas will be calm, the rivers clear;
Practice the Dao with this, and the Dao will flourish, the times prosper;
Cultivate oneself with this, and the *qi* will solidify, the spirit congeal.
One person rectified, ten thousand people rectified;
One heart rectified, ten thousand transformations rectified;
One self rectified, ten thousand affairs rectified.
Great is the power of rectitude!
The verse says:
*"Fixing one’s mind brings endless error,
Non-action again falls void.
Since the heart’s path is severed,
Every day is spring breeze.
His governance is tranquil and broad,
Tranquil as the gate’s closing.
Non-action brings ease and abundance.
His people are pure and sincere,
Simple and unadorned, with virtue overflowing.
His governance is keen and strict,
With action, stern and precise.
His people are hollow and greedy,
Hollow as *quē* [缺], pronounced *yà* [轧].
Avid and insatiable, their ruin is near.
Disaster, disaster!—
Fortune depends upon it.
Fear disaster, and fortune will surely come.
Fortune, fortune!—
Disaster lies hidden within.
Neglect fortune, and disaster will surely arise.
Who knows its limits?
Disaster and fortune have no gates—
Only people invite them by themselves.
Is it not rectitude that is lacking?
Only rectitude can be upheld.
Rectitude becomes strange,
Relying on rectitude makes it strange.
Goodness becomes demonic,
Pride in goodness makes it demonic.
The people’s confusion opposes the Dao,
And their error grows with time.
Their confusion becomes distant and never returns.
Thus, the sage is square yet does not cut,
Square in his rectitude, letting his heart transform itself.
Modest yet not defiled,
Pure in his virtue, letting the people transform themselves.
Upright yet not unrestrained,
Firm in his conduct, letting things transform themselves.
Bright yet not blinding,
Holding and nurturing his light, the world transforms itself.*

**Chapter 59:**
The previous chapter continued the meaning of *governing with tranquil breadth*.
In governing people and serving Heaven, nothing surpasses frugality.
Speaking of the state, it means lightening punishments and levies, reducing taxes;
Speaking of the self, it means moderating speech and actions, regulating drink and food;
Speaking of the heart, it means lightening thought and worry, severing sight and hearing.
Exhausting one’s heart, nurturing one’s nature—
This is how one serves Heaven.
The verse says:
*"To live is to govern affairs, to govern affairs is to live;

Clouds linger at the ridge’s peak, idle yet never fully clear,

To govern a great state, as to poach a small fish—
Disturb it, and it will fall apart.
With the Dao to rule the world, if one disturbs it, chaos follows.
Poach it, and it will spoil.
The ghosts are not numinous,
The yin-demons bow their heads.
Not that the ghosts are not numinous,
But that their numinosity does not harm people.
Evil does not intrude upon rectitude.
Not that their numinosity does not harm people,
For the sage also does not harm people.
Great measures do not cut.
When the two do not harm each other, form and spirit both attain perfection.
Thus, virtue returns to its source, and the Dao resonates in harmony."*

**Chapter 60:**
To govern with rectitude,
His governance is tranquil and broad,
In governing people and serving Heaven—
All these speak of governing a great state.
A small fish—*xiǎo xiān* [小鲜], the delicate, tiny fish.
Like poaching a small fish, disturbing it makes it spoil—
Saying that to govern the world in peace,
Disturbing it brings chaos.

To rectify one’s heart with non-action,
To nurture one’s nature with clarity and stillness,
To humble oneself in self-cultivation—
Then the people’s hearts will be content and obedient,
And the world will return to its source.

「To act without harming others,
The world achieves peace.
The fierce and violent have no means to wield their power,
And the spirits lose their fearsome nature.

As for transforming the violent into the virtuous,
Even those with great strength lack the intent to harm.
The sage does not impose punishment upon the petty,
And the ruler and ruled exchange virtue in harmony—
Hence, the two do not harm each other.

In cultivating oneself,
Clarity, purity, and non-action as the foundation,
Then passions and desires are severed,
And the hidden malevolence dissipates.
The body remains, and life endures;
The vital essence restores itself,
And the spirit is whole—
This is the Dao of eternal longevity and enduring vision.

**Ode:**
*From the source, success is seen—
Why twist and strain?*
*Once a spark ignites,
Even a speck in the eye is a burden.*
*A single stroke of insight,
A thousand years of striking the donkey’s stake.*
*The great state flows downward—
The highest virtue is like water.*
*Where the world converges,
Many lofty things attach to the low.*
*The world’s receptivity—
Many strong things cling to the yielding.*
*The yielding ever overcomes the rigid with stillness,
Stillness as the lord of agitation.*
*To be still is to be low—
All movement attaches to the still.*
*Thus, the great state yields to the small,
And takes the small;
The small serves the great,
And yields to the great.*
*Or the great yields to take the small—

*Or the great yields and takes—
The small must be absorbed by the great.*
*The great state seeks only to embrace and nurture the people,*
*Nurturing, the harsh entering as sound.*
*The humble and lowly welcome the inferior,*
*The small state seeks only to submit and serve others,*
*The humble and obedient follow the superior.*
*The two—superior yielding, inferior obeying—
Each attains what it desires,*
Each fulfills its proper role.*
*Thus, the great ought to be low—

**Chapter 63:**
To act with non-action,
To reveal the essence of all things.
Non-action encompasses all actions;
Affairs without affairs achieve all things;
Tastes without tastes are profound and enduring.
These three are the mysteries of the Dao.

The great arises from the small,
The many from the few,
Retaliation comes through virtue.
To plan for difficulty in the easy—
The easy is fragile and easily broken;
To build greatness from the minute—
The subtle is easily dispersed.
The world’s most difficult tasks begin with the easy,
From the subtle to the manifest;
The world’s greatest undertakings begin with the minute,
Accumulating small to great.

Thus, the sage never seeks to be great,
The sage does not claim sainthood.
Therefore, he accomplishes true greatness.
True sainthood lies with the people.

The sage finds difficulty in the easy,
And does not lightly reveal it.
Thus, he never faces true difficulty.
What is gained with difficulty is lost with difficulty.

**Chapter 62:**
Non-action reveals the Dao’s essence—
The mysteries of all things.

To act with non-action,
To manage affairs without interference—
Tastes without indulgence,
Its flavor is subtle and lasting.
These three are the Dao’s mysteries.

The great emerges from the small,
The many from the few,
Retaliation comes through virtue.
To plan for difficulty in the easy—
The easy is fragile and easily broken;
To build greatness from the minute—
The subtle is easily dispersed.
The sage’s achievements are vast,
Yet he does not claim greatness.

Heaven does not claim to be heaven—
What makes heaven is the myriad things;
The sage does not claim to be sage—
What makes the sage is the people.
Because he does not claim sainthood,
He attains true sainthood.
To be great must begin with the small,
To ascend must begin with the low—
Difficult tasks are easily accomplished,
Easy tasks are difficult to complete.

**Chapter 61:**
Continuing the *Jìzhǐ* chapter’s meaning of virtue’s exchange.
The lowly, like water’s descent,
Draws all waters to itself.
The yielding overcomes the rigid,
Stillness overcomes movement.
The sage humbles himself in self-cultivation,
Remains tranquil in response to things—
Then the world transforms and attains perfection.
The superior yields to the inferior below,
The inferior yields and follows the superior above,
Superior yielding, inferior obeying—
Virtue’s exchange returns to its source.

In cultivating oneself,
The more one lowers the heart, the higher the Dao ascends,
The more one retreats, the greater virtue advances,
Humility and reverence bring radiance,
Lowliness cannot be surpassed—
Thus it is said: *The great ought to be low.*»

**Ode:**
*Busy all day, rushing about—
Turn back, and you’re home.*
*Once enlightened, there’s nothing to do,*
*No chaos to entangle like hemp.*
*To practice non-action,*
*To conceal the spirit within the spirit,*
*To manage affairs without interference,*
*To conceal the heart within the heart,*
*To savor without indulgence,*
*To conceal the form within the form.*
*Great or small, much or little,*
*Act in reverse, oppose the natural order.*
*Repay resentment with virtue—*
*Not fixed in others.*
*Plan for difficulty in the easy—*
*The easy is fragile and easily broken,*
*To build greatness from the minute—*
*The subtle is easily dispersed.*
*The world’s most difficult tasks begin with the easy,*
*From the subtle to the manifest,*
*The world’s greatest undertakings begin with the minute,*
*Accumulating small to great.*
*Thus, the sage never seeks to be great,*
*The sage does not claim sainthood.*
*Therefore, he accomplishes true greatness.*
*True sainthood lies with the people.*
*Light promises must be few in trust—*
*Gained easily, lost easily.*
*Many easy things bring many difficulties,*
*Light and easy things are hard to complete.*
*Thus, the sage regards even the easy as difficult,*
*And does not lightly reveal it.*
*Thus, he never faces true difficulty.*
*What is gained with difficulty is lost with difficulty.*

The easy is not lightly shown,
For lightly shown, men neglect it—
Thus the sage regards it as difficult.

What is gained with difficulty is lost with difficulty,
And only what is not lightly taken will endure without trial.

*Ode:*
To speak of ease is not ease,
To speak of difficulty is not difficulty.
Within its subtlety lies its marvel—
The North Star gazing southward.

What is secure is easily held.
*Ease, with falling tone.*
*As below.*

Reside in ease yet fear danger.
What is yet unseen is easily planned—
Act, and plan at the beginning.
What is fragile is easily broken—
Plan difficulty from ease.
What is subtle is easily dispersed—
Plan greatness from the minute.
Act before it exists,
Prevent disaster before it arises.
Order before chaos,
Order before existence.

A tree in arms’ embrace grows from a hair’s end—
From the subtle to the manifest.
A nine-tiered tower rises from a clod of earth—
Accumulating small to great.
A thousand-li journey begins beneath one’s feet—
From near to far.

The doer undoes it—
Vigilance lies in the beginning.
The grasper loses it—
Vigilance ensures no loss.

Thus the sage, with no action, meets no defeat,
With no grasping, meets no loss.
Holding fast yet never abandoning—
Therefore, when the people act,
They have something to apply.
Yet often near completion, they fail,
Not vigilant at the start—
How then can there be an end?

To treat the end as the beginning,
Then no task shall fail.
The original heart unclouded—
How then can there be failure?

Thus the sage desires not to desire,
Desires that others not desire.
Does not prize hard-won goods—
Transforming things.
Teaches those who do not learn,
Correcting the errors of the many—
Shifting virtue.
Aids the natural unfolding of all things,
Yet dares not act.
The wise fear the law.

*Chapter Sixty-Four*
Continuing the meaning above:
What is secure is easily held—
Speaking of planning at the start,
Cultivated minds correct the heart before thought,
Restrain emotion before encountering things,
Then the heart is easily rectified,
Emotion easily severed.

If governance comes after chaos,
If disaster is warded off after its sprouting—
Is this not difficult?
Accumulating small to great—
Once lost, it cannot be reclaimed.
Thus the *Yijing* warns: *Tread on frost, expect solid ice.*
The *Commentary* says:
*A minister kills his lord, a son kills his father—*
Not the work of a single morning or evening,
But a gradual descent,
From failing to discern early enough.
The *Strike* says:
*Evil not accumulated cannot destroy life.*
Again it says:
*Evil accumulated cannot be undone.*
How can one not be warned?

If one awakens only after deviation,
And with earnest effort returns—
Still, it is not as good as resolving before form takes shape,
Without labor, restored.
Thus it is said:
*The subtle is easily dispersed,*
*The unseen is easily planned.*

Again it says:
*The doer undoes,*
*The grasper loses.*
The warning is yet more urgent.

The sage teaches those who do not learn,
Desires that others not desire,
With no grasping, no action,
Consistent from beginning to end,
Forever without peril.

If one attains this understanding,
Vigilant at the start—
How then can there be failure or loss?

Before a thing sprouts,
All signs appear—
Know it, and do not act;
Act, and do not lose.

Only the Precious Nine—
Exhausting this Way—
Could it be only Yanzi?

*Ode:*
*A hair’s deviation, a thousand-li’s loss.*
Rush back swiftly, yet still second.
Pressing the horse late to rein,
The boat at the river’s heart, mending too late.

The ancient skilled ruler
Did not enlighten the people—
Not knowing, not knowing.
He would deceive them.
His governance was dim.
The people are hard to govern,
For their cleverness is too much.
His governance was sharp.
To rule with cleverness is the state’s ruin;
To guide with cleverness leaves the people insufficient.
Not to rule with cleverness is the state’s blessing;
To guide with virtue leaves the people with abundance.
These two are the standards.
*Standard, pronounced as "kǎi" (口骇切).*
Widely inclusive, yet lawful—no people.
Always knowing the standard,
Abandoning the short for the long.
This is called *Mysterious Virtue.*
In accord with the Way.
Mysterious Virtue is profound and distant,
The more one explores, the deeper it grows,
The more one seeks, the farther it stretches.
It reverses with things,
Not consorting with all laws.
Only then does it reach the Great Harmony.
Going counter, yet aligning with transformation.

*Chapter Sixty-Five*
What is secure is easily held—
The swift return to goodness.
Thus the next best ruler
Does not enlighten the people.
Speaking of no-action’s breadth,
Peacefully governing the world—
The people’s blessing.
With action’s strictness,
Dominating the people—
The state’s ruin.
The people are hard to govern,
For they are too involved in affairs.
Thus the sage governs with no-action’s clarity and stillness,
So that the wise dare not act.
Though contrary to things,
Long accustomed to nature,
The people thrive, reaping a hundredfold blessings,
The world harmonized, achieving Great Harmony’s transformation.
Exhausting this Way—
This is called *Mysterious Virtue.*

*Ode:*
All conditioned things,
Three thousand six hundred gates.
Examined from the start,
All are but distractions of the spirit.
Only I embrace the nameless Primordial,
Endless demons bow in surrender.
The sea and rivers rule all valleys
Because they are lowly.
With their skill in descending,
Great states flow downward—
Thus they rule all valleys.
Different paths, same return.
Therefore the sage, desiring to lead the people,
Speaks to them in humility.
Desiring to precede the people,
He places himself behind.
Self-mastery.
Thus the sage, though above, does not burden the people—
The people forget their labor.
Though before them, he does not harm the people—
The people forget their deaths.
Thus the world willingly follows without tiring.
*Follow, pronounced as "lè" (音洛).*
With virtue, hearts are truly served.
Because he does not contend—
Humility and yielding—
Thus none under heaven can contend with him.
The world is at peace.

*Chapter Sixty-Six*
The skilled ruler humbles himself to tend his own nature,
Thus next, likening himself to the sea ruling all valleys—
The meaning of *Supreme Goodness as Water.*
Speaking to the people in humility,
The people forget their labor;

「With the body yielding to the people,
The people forget their deaths—
All through the resonance of *Dao* and virtue.

The true cultivator, humbling himself to tend his nature,
Thus refines his own being.

*Ode:*
Supreme Goodness as Water,
Benefiting all without end.
Piercing gold, traversing stone,
Silently flowing past obstacles.
With intent, he holds the moon for a thousand miles—
Without intent, he sends the traveler on the wind’s sail.

The world all says my *Dao* is vast,
All things push to honor me.
Seeming unworthy.
When faced, I conceal it.

Only the great has no equal—
Thus seeming unworthy.
Seeming what?
If worthy for long, it is trifling.
Once comparable, it is not great.

I possess three treasures, worthless in exchange:
Guard them carefully:
First, *cì*—compassion, benevolence.
Second, *jiǎn*—frugality, moderation.
Third, not daring to lead the world—
Humility, withdrawal.

*Cì* makes one courageous—
Nothing is unconquered.
*Jiǎn* makes one expansive—
Nothing is lacking.
Not daring to lead the world,
Thus one fulfills his role as vessel and leader—
None resist.

Now abandoning *cì* and courage—
It is harshness and violence.
Abandoning *jiǎn* and expansiveness—
It is greed and desire.
Abandoning withdrawal for precedence—
It is tyranny and force.
Death.
The followers of death.

*Cì* is *rén*—
In war, it conquers; the armies of the benevolent cannot be matched.
In defense, it is steadfast.
Benevolence guards.
Heaven aids those it would save,
With virtue as its support.
With *cì* as its shield.
The great virtue of Heaven and Earth is *shēng*—life;
The sage upholds his station with *rén*—benevolence.

*Chapter Sixty-Seven*
The lower the body, the higher the virtue—
Thus the sea rules all valleys.
The sage follows this,
So the world all honors him as great.
Unworthy words have no equal—
Again, humble speech.
Compassionate, forbearing, humble, withdrawn,
Frugal, modest, lowly—
Thus seeming unworthy.

The common crowd all extols vastness, force, and the violent courage of blood and *qi*—

The single character *cì*—
In war, it conquers;
In defense, it is unshaken.
The benevolent have no rival—
True courage.

*Ode:*
Do not drink the water of ignorance,
Cease generating distinctions.
Dispersed clouds clear the azure sky—
Ten thousand *li* of equal heaven.

The skilled warrior is not martial—
Compassionate, forbearing.
The skilled fighter does not rage—
Rage, pronounced as *nú* (音弩), rhymes with *wǔ* (武).
Soft and yielding.
The skilled victor does not contend—
Humility, yielding.
The skilled user of men is lowly—
Modest, deferential.
This is called the virtue of non-contention—
Supreme humility.
This is called using others’ strength—
Supreme softness.
This is called aligning with Heaven—
Supreme compassion.
The ancient perfect harmony with the *Dao*.

*Chapter Sixty-Eight*
Not martial, not enraged, not contending—
Expanding the meaning of *unworthy*.
The virtue of non-contention,
Using others’ strength—

Practicing this for self-cultivation,

*Ode:*
Neither literary nor martial,
Neither gain nor loss.
Touching one’s nose,
Sweat pours from the body.
Plainly beneath the eyes—
Yet separated by mountains in discussion.

There is a saying about warfare:
I do not dare be host but am guest—
Compassionate, forbearing.
I do not dare advance an inch but retreat a *chǐ*—
Humility, withdrawal.
This is called *no-action*—
No-action, pronounced as *háng* (下音杭).
Not martial.
No arms—
No arms, pronounced as *rǎng* (如羊切).
Not enraged.
Yet unconquered—
Not contending.
No weapons—
Lowly.
No greater calamity than underestimating the enemy,
Daring courage leads to slaughter.
Underestimating the enemy nearly loses my treasures.
Strong and tyrannical are the followers of death.
Thus when armies clash,
The first to engage is victorious.
The benevolent’s armies—
Unmatched under Heaven.

*Chapter Sixty-Nine*
Continuing the meaning of *not martial* from the last chapter.
From *no-action* to *compassion triumphs*—
All are expressions of non-rage and non-contention.

*Ode:*
Loving victory ends in defeat,
Only compassion guards what is achieved.
No need for blades to wield,
The world celebrates peace.

My words are easy to know—
Compassion and forbearance alone.
Easy to practice—
Frugality and moderation alone.
Yet none under Heaven can know—
Faith is insufficient.
None can practice—
Strength is insufficient.

Words have their root—
Speaking reveals the *Dao*.
Deeds have their master—
Actions display the *Dao*.
Only the ignorant remain blind—
Thus they do not know me.
Seeing is unclear.
Few know me—
Who is the true connoisseur?
Those who follow me are precious—
Who dares to bear the responsibility?
Thus the sage wears coarse cloth while harboring jade.
Internally treasuring *Dao* and virtue,
Externally acting lowly and humble.

*Chapter Seventy*
The previous chapter spoke of *compassion triumphs*—
Thus followed by *easy to know, easy to practice*.
Yet the world cannot know or practice—
Faith is insufficient.
Asking those who believe,

Strength is insufficient.
Thus the sage wears coarse cloth while harboring jade,

*Ode:*
The Supreme *Dao* is not difficult to know,
Yet human hearts cling to delusion.
A hundred tangled knots dissolve—
Suddenly reaching Caoqi.
Autumn moon, spring flowers—boundless meaning,
Only you know its depth.

Knowing the unknown—
True knowing.
Unknown yet knowing—
Illness.
False knowing.
Only the sick fear knowing—
Thus the unsick have no false knowing.
The sage is unsick,
Knowing yet seeming unknowing.
Because he fears false knowing,
He forgets what he knows.
Thus unsick—
Knowing all without knowing.

*Chapter Seventy-One*
*Knowing the unknown* above—
Continuing from the last chapter’s *easy to know*.
The sage knows all yet does not claim to know—
True knowing.
The world knows nothing yet claims to know—
False knowing, thus *illness*.
If one knows false knowing as illness
And fears that illness,
Then the illness of false knowing is cured.
The sage remains unsick
Because he fears his excess of knowing—
Thus he is unsick.

**Chapter Seventy-Two**

*Ode:*
He who flaunts his black beard’s redness,
Who boasts of hollowed lips in Daoist chanting—
If one can truly grasp this,
Then enlightenment awaits not a donkey’s lifetime.

The people fear not the awe of virtue,
Nor restraint—
Then great calamity descends.
One reaps what one sows.
To dwell without constraint,
To indulge in unrestrained desires—
To crave life without moderation.
*Ulian*, level tone.
Life’s excess is boundless.
Only he who does not crave
Errs in excess.
Thus, he who does not crave
Errs in excess.
Hence, the sage reverses this:
Knowing himself yet not displaying,
He does not indulge his passions.
Loving himself yet not esteeming,
He does not overvalue his life.
Thus, he discards that and takes this.
*Qu*, pronounced *Jianglü* cut.

*The people fear not the awe of virtue* above—
Continuing from the last chapter’s *unknowing the knowing as illness*,
*unknowing as knowing*—
Thus they lack restraint.
Hence follows the *Ode: The people fear not the awe of virtue*.
Common folk do not fear great virtue,
Dwelling without constraint,
Craving life without moderation,
Still seeking breadth and excess in life.
Not knowing moderation brings ruin—
Thus it is said, *great calamity descends*.
Those of the Dao reverse this.

*Ode:*
Bitter gourd’s root is bitter to the core,
Sweet melon’s rind is sweet through to the stem.
Pitiful are those who cling to desire—
They know flavor yet not moderation.
Boldness in daring leads to slaughter,
The overbearing are doomed to die.
Boldness in not daring brings life,
The yielding are kin to vitality.
Knowing these two,
Some profit, some harm—
Life and death intertwined.
What Heaven abhors,
*Wu*, pronounced *Wülü* cut,
The Creator does not endure.
Who knows its reason?
Knowing, one does not dare.
Thus the sage finds it hard.
He does not lightly reveal.
Heaven’s Dao:
Without strife, yet triumphs,
Without contention, yet prevails.
Unspoken yet answers well,
Great sound is faint—
Harmony brings response.
Unsummoned yet comes,
Silent and motionless—
Stirred, it flows.
*Shànrán* yet well-plotted.
*Shàn*, pronounced *Zhàn*.
Following nature’s course,
It conquers all.
Heaven’s net vast and sweeping,
Encompassing all without exclusion.
Though sparse, it misses none.
Though wide and open,
No thing can escape.

**Chapter Seventy-Three (Continuing from the previous chapter):**
The people do not fear authority,
For the world does not fear the law,
Daring to revel in boldness—
The root of self-destruction.

Boldness in not daring brings life,
Boldness in daring is but the vigor of blood and breath—
Boldness in not daring is the courage of virtue and principle.

**Ode:**
Daring to be bold, ever light in death,
A stubborn ox fears no whip.
Observe the reckless and base—
How many times their nostrils are pierced.

The people do not fear death,
Unrestrained, they chase illusions.
How can one deter them with fear of death?
It is like embracing firewood to quench flames.

If the people were made to fear death,
And those who act strangely were punished,
By appealing to their own desires—
I would seize and execute them,
Not letting any escape.
Who would dare?
Who would dare to defy?

Those who habitually wield the sword,
Heaven does not tolerate deceit.
He who substitutes for the executioner,
Is not the proper one to wield the blade.
This is called *dài dàjiǎo zhǔo*—
A carpenter’s apprentice wielding the adze.
The work does not concern him.

He who substitutes for the master carpenter,
Is like a gatekeeper wielding the axe—
Few escape unharmed.
He invites his own ruin.

「Chapter 74 (Continuing the theme of daring to defy death from the previous chapter):
The people do not fear death—
This is because the governance and moral cultivation of the ruler are not good,

When the people lose their sustenance,
They seek to fulfill their lives,
And thus do not fear death.

Moreover, if the ruler adds harsh punishments and prohibitions,
Forcing the people to fear death,
