chunks.original_text: 任运自然。 众人皆有余，而我独若遗，贪务者，常忧。 忘机者，常乐。 我愚人之心也哉，沌沌兮。 昏昏默默。 俗人昭昭，我独若昏； 俗人见藏於外，圣人藏明於内。 俗人察察，我独闷闷。 闷音门。 俗人有分别，圣人无彼此。 忽兮若晦，晦，上声。 不识不知。 漂兮若无所止。 无物无执。 众人皆有以，我独顽似鄙。 众人皆有能，圣人独无能。 我独异於人，不与万法为侣。 而贵食母。 贵在味道。 右二十章　绝学者，绝其所有也。 故次之绝圣人后。 俗人务学於事，益其所闻，惟恐进学不精，故常忧。 圣人弃绝所有，惟务於味道，如求食於母，守雌抱一而已，故无忧也。 是谓绝学无忧。 颂曰：才言绝学，开口便错。 广识多知，转转不觉。 人间万事都忘却，犹落他家第二机。 孔德之容，无所不容。 惟道是从。 於法自在。 道之为物，惟恍惟忽。 本然之天。 忽兮恍，其中有象； 此天混然。 恍兮忽，其中有物。 此天洞然。 窈兮冥，其中有精； 此天常存。 其精甚真，纯一无伪。 其中有信。 活泼泼地。 自古及今，其名不去，去，羌吕切。 历劫常存。 以阅众甫。 万物资始。 吾何以知众甫之然哉？ 以此。
chunks.translated_text:
Flowing with natural spontaneity,
The common folk all have excess,
While I alone seem to lack—
Those driven by greed and striving are ever anxious,
Those who forget scheming are ever joyful.

How muddled is this heart of mine!
Turbid and still,
Dim and silent.
The common folk are bright and clear,
While I alone seem benighted;
The common folk display their treasures outwardly,
The sage conceals illumination within.
The common folk are sharp and discerning,
While I alone remain dull and obscure.
Dull as a closed gate.
The common folk make distinctions,
The sage knows no "this" nor "that."

Vague as dusk,
Unknowing, unperceiving.
Drifting as if without destination,
Nothing grasped, nothing clung to.
The common folk all have their uses,
While I alone seem stubborn and coarse.
The common folk all possess abilities,
The sage alone appears without skill.

I alone differ from others,
Not taking the ten thousand phenomena as companions,
Yet I prize feeding at the Mother’s breast—
Prizing the savor of the Dao.

**Chapter Twenty**
To "abandon learning" is to relinquish all that one possesses,
Thus it follows the abandonment of the sage.
The common folk devote themselves to learning matters,
Augmenting what they have heard,
Ever fearful their progress is not refined—
Thus they are ever anxious.
The sage discards all possession,
Devoting himself solely to savoring the Dao,
As one seeks nourishment from the Mother,
Abiding in femininity and embracing the One—
Thus he is without care.
This is called "abandoning learning to be without care."

**Eulogy:**
The moment one speaks of abandoning learning,
The mouth has already erred.
Vast knowledge and wide discernment
Lead one further astray unawares.
Though all worldly affairs are forgotten,
One still falls into the second mechanism of another’s design.

The bearing of great virtue
Accommodates all without exception,
Following only the Dao.
At ease within the dharma.

The Dao as a thing—
Only vague, only elusive.
The Heaven of original nature.
Elusive, yet within it there are images;
This is the undifferentiated Heaven.
Vague, yet within it there are things;
This is the luminous Heaven.
Dark and deep, within it there is essence;
This is the enduring Heaven.
Its essence is utterly real,
Pure and without falsity.
Within it there is sincerity—
Vibrant and alive.

From ancient times to the present,
Its name has never departed,
Ever abiding through kalpas.
By this, the myriad beginnings are surveyed.
How do I know the nature of the myriad beginnings?
By this.

chunks.original_text: 右二十一章　上章云我独异於人，德之大也。 故次之以孔德之容，言其广纳包容。 所谓道之为物，果何物乎？ 有象有物有精，果有乎？ 若谓有，未具参学眼，若谓无，亦未具参学眼，毕竟作么会咄。 颂曰：亘古一物，了无人识。 剔起眉毛，虚空露骨。 设若拟议，踌躇照管，当空霹雳。 曲则全，不材者寿。 枉则直，屈己者伸。 洼则盈，洼，乌瓜切。 谦则受益。 弊则新，晦则自明。 少则得，知止常足。 多则惑事繁则乱。 是以圣人抱一为天下式。 一能统众。 不自见，故明； 弊则新。 不自是，故彰； 洼则盈。 不自伐，故有功； 枉则直。 不自矜，故长。 曲则全。 夫惟不争，守柔。 故天下莫能与之争。 混而为一。 古之所谓曲则全者，岂虚言哉。 是真实语。 诚全而归之。 全其本然。
chunks.translated_text:
The preceding twenty-one chapters—
The previous chapter states, "I alone differ from others, for my virtue is great."
Thus follows "The bearing of great virtue," speaking of its vast embrace and all-encompassing nature.
What then is this "Dao as a thing"? What thing is it?
With images, with things, with essence—does it truly exist?
To call it existent, one lacks the eye of practiced insight;
To call it nonexistent, one equally lacks the eye of practiced insight.
How, after all, is it to be understood? Hmph!

**Verse:**
From ancient times, a single thing—
Yet none have known it.
Raise your brows, and bare bone appears in empty space.
Should you hesitate or deliberate,
A thunderclap splits the void.

Bent, it remains whole;
The unhewn tree endures.
Twisted, it straightens;
To yield is to extend.
Hollow, it fills—
*Wā*, deep as a gourd.
Humble, it gains.
Worn, it renews;
Obscured, it shines of itself.
Little, it attains;
To know cessation is lasting sufficiency.
Much, it confounds;
Affairs in excess breed chaos.

Thus the sage embraces the One as the model for all under Heaven.
The One governs the many.
Not self-displaying, thus luminous;
Worn, it renews.
Not self-asserting, thus distinguished;
Hollow, it fills.
Not self-boasting, thus meritorious;
Twisted, it straightens.
Not self-exalting, thus exalted.
Bent, it remains whole.
Only through non-contention,
Holding to softness,
Does none under Heaven contend with him.
Blended into oneness.

The ancient saying "Bent, it remains whole"—was this empty words?
It is true and real speech.
In perfect sincerity, return to it.
Preserve its original wholeness.

chunks.original_text: 右二十二章　曲全枉直，洼盈弊新，接上章孔德之义也。 不自见以下，皆戒盈劝谦之义也。 谦下故无争，无争则全其本然，抱元守一，复归无极也。 故曰诚全而归之。 颂曰：莫管他人短，休矜自己长。 短长无二见，遍界不能藏。 希言自然。 开口不在舌头上。 飘风不终朝，狂则不久。 骤雨不终日。 躁则不长。 孰为此者？ 是谁主宰。 天地。 众所共知。 天地尚不能久，天地尚尔。 而况人乎？ 不可躁暴。 故从事於道者，顺理合辙。 道者同於道，一体同观。 德者同于德，不生一见。 失者同於失。 无有分别。 同於道者，道亦乐得之，我同於道，道亦同我。 同於德者，德亦乐得之； 乐，音烙，上下并用。 我同於德，德亦同我。 同於失者，失亦乐得之。 我同於失，失亦同我。 信不足，有不信。 我疑於物物亦疑我。 右二十三章　希言自然，接上章不争之义。 谓不自见，是不言而善应。 飘风骤雨，言妄动躁进不久远之喻。 从事於道者，和顺於道德，混同於事物，自然感通於物，物亦自然相应也。 苟或言不合道，妄有作为，不能取信於人，反为人轻忽也。 《易系》云：言行，君子之枢机，荣辱之主也，可不慎乎。 颂曰：道不异於人，人自以为异。 一佛一切佛，心是如来地。 跂者不立，跂，音伎。 躁进无功。 跨者不行，欲速不达。 自见者不明，不能晦德。 自是者不彰，不能谦下自伐者无功，不能克己。 自矜者不长。 不能含容。 其於道也，曰余食赘行。 赘，朱芮切。 行，去声。 残饭赘疣。 物或恶之，恶，乌路切。 众所不美。 故有道者不处。 达者反是。 右二十四章　此章总证前三章。 跂者不立，跨者不行，即飘风练雨之谓也。 自见自是，自矜自伐，浑是私意。 私意确则害公，何可久也，故有道者不处。 余食赘行，不美也。 颂曰：跂立元为妄，跨行本是狂。 假饶成得事，到底不如常。 有物混成，此天混然。 先天而生，此天洞然。 寂兮寥兮湛然常寂。 独立不改，超然独存。 周行而不殆，运化无穷。 可以为天下母。 生育长养。 吾不知其名，本无名唤。 字之曰道，因物立名。 强为之名曰大。 强，上声。 无有限量。 大曰逝，无有疆界。 逝曰远，无有边际。 远曰反。 收拾归来。 故道大，太虚无体。 天大，法道。 地大，法天。 王亦大。 法地。 域中有四大，更有大么。 王居其一焉。 三界独称尊。 人法地，无不载。 地法天，无不容。 天法道，无不周。 道法自然。 右二十五章　接上章有道不处，於此发明处道之工夫也。 有物混成以下一节，全首章体道之要。 四大以下，纯是神妙。 人只知域中有四大，殊不知自己一物更人。 颂曰：天地虽大，亦有败壤。 唯有这个，历劫常在。 圣而不可知之者，尽在如如不动中。 重为轻根，轻生於重。 静为躁君。 静主於动。 是以君子终日行不离辎重。 不敢轻为。 虽有荣观，宴处超然。 常应常静。 奈何万乘之主，而以身轻天下。 担荷不起。 轻则失臣，轻进失身。 躁则失君。 贪荣取辱。 右二十六章　重者，不可轻忽也。 轻则失臣，躁则失君，犹跂者不立，跨者不行之谓，亦飘风骤雨之喻。 不离辎重，克负担荷也。 宴处超然，转物也。 明上章法道之义，总结二章体道之说，而续下章善行之要也。 颂曰：躁进那能久，轻为了不成。
chunks.translated_text:
Chapter Twenty-Two
Bent yet whole, crooked yet straight,
Hollow yet full, worn yet renewed—
these continue the preceding chapter’s discourse on the virtue of the profound.
From "Not self-displaying" onward,
all warn against excess and exhort humility.
Humble and lowly, thus without contention;
without contention, one preserves one’s original wholeness,
embraces the primordial and guards the One,
returning to the boundless.
Hence it is said: "In perfect sincerity, return to it.
Preserve its original wholeness."

*Verse:*
Heed not the faults of others,
Nor boast of your own strengths.
Faults and strengths—no dual vision,
Nowhere can they be concealed.

"Few words accord with nature."
Speech lies not in the tongue.
"Whirlwinds do not last the morning,
Violence does not endure."
"Sudden rains do not last the day."
Impatience does not long prevail.
Who brings this about?
Who is the master?
Heaven and Earth—
all know this.
Yet even Heaven and Earth cannot last forever;
how much less can man?
Thus one who engages with the Dao
follows principle and aligns with the track.

Those who accord with the Dao are one with the Dao;
unity is seen as one.
Those who accord with virtue are one with virtue;
no single view arises.
Those who accord with loss are one with loss;
no distinctions exist.
Those who are one with the Dao,
the Dao delights in attaining them—
I am one with the Dao, the Dao is one with me.
Those who are one with virtue,
virtue delights in attaining them—
I am one with virtue, virtue is one with me.
Those who are one with loss,
loss delights in attaining them—
I am one with loss, loss is one with me.
"Trust is insufficient, thus disbelief arises."
I doubt things, things doubt me.

Chapter Twenty-Three
"Few words accord with nature"—
this continues the preceding chapter’s discourse on non-contention.
"Not self-displaying" means responding well without speaking.
"Whirlwinds and sudden rains"
are metaphors for reckless action and impetuous advance that do not last.
One who engages with the Dao
harmonizes with virtue and power,
blends with all things,
naturally resonates with them,
and things naturally respond in kind.
If one’s words do not accord with the Dao,
or one acts recklessly,
one cannot gain others’ trust,
but is instead slighted by them.
The *Book of Changes* says:
"Words and deeds are the hinge and spring of the noble one,
the master of honor and disgrace—
how can one not be cautious?"

*Verse:*
The Dao is not different from people,
People merely deem it so.
One Buddha is all Buddhas,
The mind is the ground of the Tathāgata.

"One who stands on tiptoe does not stand firm"—
impetuous advance yields no merit.
"One who strides cannot walk"—
haste does not bring success.
"One who self-displays is not luminous"—
cannot conceal one’s power.
"One who self-asserts is not distinguished"—
cannot humble oneself.
"One who self-boasts has no merit"—
cannot restrain oneself.
"One who self-exalts does not endure"—
cannot contain oneself.
In relation to the Dao, these are called
"leftover food and redundant conduct."
Redundant growths and excess.
Things may revile them—
all find them unlovely.
Thus one who possesses the Dao does not dwell in them.
The enlightened act otherwise.

Chapter Twenty-Four
This chapter collectively confirms the preceding three.
"One who stands on tiptoe does not stand firm,
One who strides cannot walk"—
this refers to "whirlwinds and sudden rains."
"Self-displaying, self-asserting,
self-exalting, self-boasting"—
all are private intentions.
Private intentions, once fixed, harm the public—
how can they endure?
Thus one who possesses the Dao does not dwell in them.
"Leftover food and redundant conduct" are unlovely.

*Verse:*
Standing on tiptoe is fundamentally delusion,
Striding is inherently madness.
Even if one succeeds in some affair,
In the end it is not as good as constancy.

There is a thing, chaotically formed—
this is Heaven’s undifferentiated state.
Born before Heaven—
this is Heaven’s transparent state.
Silent, empty, profoundly still—
it stands alone, unchanging,
transcendent and self-existent.
It revolves without end—
its transformations are inexhaustible.
It may be called the Mother of all under Heaven,
nurturing and sustaining all.
I do not know its name—
it is fundamentally nameless.
I style it "Dao"—
a name given in response to things.
Forcibly, I name it "Great."
Boundless.
"Great" means "passing away"—
without boundaries.
"Passing away" means "far-reaching"—
without limits.
"Far-reaching" means "returning"—
gathering and returning.
Thus the Dao is great,
the Great Void without form.
Heaven is great—
it models itself on the Dao.
Earth is great—
it models itself on Heaven.
The king is also great—
he models himself on Earth.
Within the realm, there are four greats—
is there yet another great?
The king occupies one of them—
alone he is honored in the Three Realms.
Man models himself on Earth—
nothing is not borne.
Earth models itself on Heaven—
nothing is not contained.
Heaven models itself on the Dao—
nothing is not encompassed.
The Dao models itself on nature.

Chapter Twenty-Five
This chapter follows the preceding, which states that "one who possesses the Dao does not dwell" in such things,
and here elucidates the work of dwelling in the Dao.
From "There is a thing, chaotically formed" onward,
the entire passage is the essential teaching of embodying the Dao.
From "Within the realm, there are four greats" onward,
all is wondrous and sublime.
People know only that within the realm there are four greats,
yet do not realize that this very self is even greater.

*Verse:*
Though Heaven and Earth are great,
They too decay and crumble.
Only this one thing
Endures through kalpas unchanged.
The sacred, unknowable one—
all abides in thusness, unmoving.

"Heaviness is the root of lightness,
Lightness is born of heaviness."
"Stillness is the ruler of restlessness"—
stillness governs movement.
Thus the noble one, though traveling all day,
does not part from the baggage train—
dares not act lightly.
Though there be splendid sights,
he dwells in serene detachment—
constantly responsive, constantly still.
How can the lord of ten thousand chariots
treat his person lightly in the world?
To bear the burden lightly.
Lightness loses ministers,
Impetuousness loses the ruler.
Seeking glory brings disgrace.

Chapter Twenty-Six
Heaviness must not be treated lightly.
"Lightness loses ministers,
Impetuousness loses the ruler"—

"Not parting from the baggage train" means
bearing the burden and carrying the load.
"Dwelling in serene detachment" means
turning things around.

chunks.translated_text:
One whose heels never touch the ground
still treads the journey’s path.
The perfect traveler leaves no wheel tracks—
tracks form where heels press down.
The perfect speaker finds no fault in words—
words take shape where the tongue begins.
The perfect planner needs no counting rods—
one insight melts ten thousand things.
The perfect closure needs no bolt nor bar,
yet cannot be opened—
no seam or crack remains.
The perfect knot needs no cord nor tie,
yet cannot be undone—
no binding or constraint is left.

Thus the sage is ever skilled at saving others,
and so no one is cast aside—
cultivating the self to bring peace to the people.
Ever skilled at saving things,
and so nothing is cast aside—
adapting to the moment to benefit all.
This is called inheriting clarity—
clarity unbroken, continuous.

Therefore the good person
is the teacher of the ungood—
teaching others to be good.
The ungood person
is the resource of the good—
warning others to turn toward goodness.
If one does not value one’s teacher,
there is no goodness to be had.
If one does not cherish one’s resource,
there is no fault to be amended.
Though wise, this is great delusion—
casting aside wisdom like foolishness.
This is called the essential subtlety—
acting in accord with nature’s flow.

chunks.original_text: 右二十七章　尽前章之蕴。 谨於言行则无迹无谪，心之计其可算，心之闭其可开，心之结其可解，道心坚固如此，则无善不善之分。 师与资两忘，黜聪屏智，终日如愚。 颂曰：举步不在脚，善结非千手。 摸着鼻孔尖，通身都是口。 若能於此善参详，七七元来四十九。 知其雄，守其雌，不自大。 为天下溪。 万派归源。 为天下溪，常德不离，打成一片。 复归於婴儿。 炁全。 知其白，守其黑，不自见。 为天下式。 万法归一。 为天下式，常德不忒，准的不差。 复归於无极。 神全。 知其荣，守其辱，不自贵。 为天下谷。 万有归空。 为天下谷，常德乃足，湛然圆满。 复归於朴。 朴，音扑。 性全。 朴散则为器，施之於物。 圣人用之，以为官长设教化人。 故大制不割。 不言之教。 右二十八章　守雌守黑守辱，不见自己之明，接上章虽智大远之义。 婴儿太极太朴，天下之大本，惟守雌抱一，则能返本。 治国以此，不假裁制，民自淳而物自朴也。 颂曰：白里存乎黑，雄中抱一雌。 绵绵功不间，男解养婴儿。 将欲取天下而为之者，错。 吾见其不得已。 已音以。 利御寇，不利为寇。 天下神器，不可为也。 动着祸生。 为者败之，贪他底，着他底。 执者失之。 讨便宜，落便宜。 凡物一切有相。 或行或随，或煦或吹，或强或羸，或载或隳。 有此便有彼，切忌随他去。 是以圣人去甚，去，上声。 无为。 去奢，无欲。 去泰。 无执。 右二十九章　无为则无事，有为便有事。 执者失，为者败，有为之戒也。 强羸载隳，互相倚伏，如影随形，才有成便有败。 是以圣人去贪甚，去奢侈，去骄泰，深戒后世。 颂曰； 行随煦吹，强羸载隳，中间主宰，不知是谁。 着衣吃饭寻常事，何须特地却生疑。 以道佐人主者，无为。 不以兵强天下，以慈卫之。 其事好还。 还，音旋。 善恶皆报。 师之所处，刑棘生焉。 心兵起处，灵地荒芜。 大军之后，必有凶年。 魔军驰骋，精气耗散。 故善者果而已，已音以。 有断则生。 不敢以取强。 以柔待之。 果而勿矜，去甚。 果而勿伐，去奢。 果而勿骄，去泰。 果而不得已，颠沛必於是。 是果而勿强。 放倒剎竿。 物壮则老，兵强则不胜。 是谓不道，错。 不道早已。 永失真道。 右三十章　接上章去奢泰之义。 以道佐人主者，不尚兵武。 善恶皆有报，戒后世有国有家者，守雌抱一，勇於不敢。 至於不得已，亦不敢取强，故曰善者果而已。 颂曰：莫纵三心乱，常教志帅安。 忽然违野战，一箭定天山。 夫佳兵不祥之器，大兵之后，必有凶年。 物或恶之，恶，乌路切。 师之所处，荆棘生焉。 故有道者不处。 处，上声。 心兵不起。 君子居则贵左，主柔。 用兵则贵右。 主刚。 兵者不祥之器，武以讨叛。 非君子之器，君子常治。 不得已而用之，恬澹为上。 以慈卫之。 胜而不美，不得已。 而美之者，要功也。 是乐杀人。 乐，五教切。 肆其刚勇。 夫乐杀人者，为之种祸。 不可得志於天下。 造物不容。 吉事尚左，主生。 凶事尚右。 主杀。 偏将军居左，尚柔。 上将军居右，尚刚。 言以丧礼处之。 不祥之器。 杀人众多，不得已。 悲衰泣之。 一曰慈。 战胜，以丧礼处之。 如丧考妣。 右三十一章　不以兵强天下，故次之以兵者不祥之器，圣人於此深戒。
chunks.translated_text:
Chapter Twenty-Seven: Exhausting the Essence of the Preceding Chapters

In speech and action, be meticulous—then no trace remains, no blame accrues. The mind’s calculations cannot be reckoned; the mind’s closures cannot be opened; the mind’s knots cannot be untied. When the mind of Dao stands firm like this, there is no division between good and ungood. Teacher and resource are both forgotten; wisdom is set aside, and one remains all day like a fool.

**Verse:**
Steps need not depend on feet—
a skillful knot requires no thousand hands.
Touch the tip of your nose,
and the whole body becomes a mouth.
If you can thoroughly ponder this,
the forty-nine arise from the seven-sevens.

Know the masculine, yet guard the feminine—
do not exalt yourself.
Become the world’s stream,
where all tributaries return to the source.
Become the world’s stream,
and constant virtue never departs,
forged into one unbroken whole—
returning to the state of an infant,
where qi is complete.

Know the bright, yet guard the dark—
do not display yourself.
Become the world’s model,
where all dharmas return to the One.
Become the world’s model,
and constant virtue never errs,
its standard unwavering—
returning to the boundless,
where spirit is complete.

Know glory, yet guard disgrace—
do not prize yourself.
Become the world’s valley,
where all existence returns to emptiness.
Become the world’s valley,
and constant virtue is fulfilled,
profound and perfectly round—
returning to the uncarved block.
*(Pronounced "pǔ.")*
Where nature is complete.
When the uncarved block scatters, it becomes vessels,
applied to things.
The sage employs it
to establish officials and teach the people—
thus the great system remains uncut,
a teaching without words.

Chapter Twenty-Eight: Guarding the Feminine, the Dark, and Disgrace

Not seeing one’s own clarity connects to the preceding chapter’s "though wise, this is great delusion." The infant, the Great Ultimate, the uncarved block—these are the great roots of the world. Only by guarding the feminine and embracing the One can one return to the source. Govern a state with this, and without need for restraint, the people naturally become pure, and things naturally return to simplicity.

**Verse:**
Within white, the black is preserved;
within the masculine, the One Feminine is embraced.
Unbroken, the work continues—
even men can learn to nurture the infant.

Those who would seize the world and act upon it are mistaken.
I see they cannot but fail.
To wield power against bandits is fitting;
to become a bandit is not.
The world is a sacred vessel—
it cannot be acted upon.
Where action stirs, misfortune arises.
Those who act destroy it,
grasping what is not theirs, clinging to what is.
Those who seize lose it,
seeking advantage, only to fall into it.
All things bear form—
some lead, some follow;
some warm, some chill;
some strengthen, some weaken;
some uphold, some cast down.
Where this exists, that arises—
beware of following it.

Thus the sage eliminates extremes,
*(Pronounced "qù.")*
non-action.
Eliminates excess,
non-desire.
Eliminates extravagance,
non-attachment.

Chapter Twenty-Nine: Non-Action and the Perils of Force

Non-action means no trouble; action invites trouble. Those who seize lose; those who act fail—this is the warning against force. Strength and weakness, upholding and casting down, depend on one another like shadow following form. Where there is success, there is failure. Thus the sage eliminates greed, excess, and arrogance, deeply warning later generations.

**Verse:**
Leading and following, warming and chilling,
strengthening and weakening, upholding and casting down—
who is the master in their midst?
It is no one.
Dressing and eating are ordinary matters—
why trouble yourself with needless doubt?

Those who assist a ruler with the Dao do so through non-action.
Do not seek to strengthen the world with arms,
but defend it with compassion.
Such deeds swiftly return—
*(Pronounced "xuán.")*
good and evil alike bear fruit.
Where armies encamp,
thorns and brambles grow.
Where the mind’s troops arise,
the sacred ground lies barren.
After great armies pass,
years of famine follow.
Where demonic forces gallop,
essence and qi are depleted.

Thus the good accomplish their ends and stop—
*(Pronounced "yǐ.")*
where there is decisiveness, life arises.
They dare not seize strength,
but meet force with softness.
Accomplishing without boasting—
eliminating extremes.
Accomplishing without flaunting—
eliminating excess.
Accomplishing without arrogance—
eliminating extravagance.
Accomplishing only when unavoidable—
even in hardship, this is the way.
Thus they accomplish without forcing—
lowering the banner of the sword.

When things reach their prime, they age;
when arms grow strong, they do not prevail.
This is called "not-Dao"—
a mistake.
Those who depart from the Dao perish early,
forever losing the true Way.

Chapter Thirty: Assisting Rulers with the Dao

Continuing the preceding chapter’s elimination of excess and extravagance: those who assist rulers with the Dao do not exalt military might. Good and evil alike bear fruit—this warns those who govern states and families to guard the feminine, embrace the One, and be brave in their restraint. Even when unavoidable, they dare not seize strength, thus it is said: "The good accomplish their ends and stop."

**Verse:**
Do not let the three minds run wild—
let the will always lead the intent.
Suddenly, if forced into battle,
one arrow settles Mount Tian.

Fine weapons are inauspicious tools.
After great armies pass, years of famine follow.
Some may detest them—
*(Pronounced "wù.")*
where armies encamp, thorns and brambles grow.
Thus those who embody the Dao do not dwell there.
*(Pronounced "chǔ.")*
Where the mind’s troops do not arise.

The noble person at rest values the left,
embracing softness.
In war, they value the right,
embracing hardness.
Weapons are inauspicious tools,
used to suppress rebellion—
not the tools of the noble person,
who constantly governs.
Only when unavoidable are they used,
with tranquility as the highest aim,
defending with compassion.
Victory is not glorified—
to do so is to seek merit.
This is delighting in killing.
*(Pronounced "yuè.")*
Indulging in hardness and bravery.
Those who delight in killing
plant the seeds of misfortune—
they cannot prevail in the world,
for the Creator does not tolerate them.

Auspicious affairs value the left,
embracing life.
Inauspicious affairs value the right,
embracing death.
The deputy general stands on the left,
valuing softness.
The supreme general stands on the right,
valuing hardness.
This is to handle them with mourning rites—
inauspicious tools.
When many are killed,
it is unavoidable—
mourn them with sorrow and tears.
*(One says: compassion.)*
When victorious in battle,
handle it with mourning rites,
as if grieving for parents.

Chapter Thirty-One: Weapons as Inauspicious Tools

Not seeking to strengthen the world with arms, the text follows with "weapons are inauspicious tools," deeply warning the sage about this.

chunks.original_text: 万世之下，有国之君以无为清静，治化自然，家国咸宁。 虽有甲兵，无所陈之，永无争夺之患也。 颂曰：默默清玄境，澄澄养太和。 倒携三味剑，顺化五阴魔。 道常无名，虚无自然。 朴虽小至微。 天下不敢臣。 至尊。 侯王若能守，抱一。 万物将自宾。 无不服。 天地相合，惟德是辅。 以降甘露，和气所致。 民莫之令而自均。 令，去声。 自然和平。 始制有名，立法制度。 名亦既有，示之好恶。 夫亦将知止。 使之知禁。 知止，所以不殆。 知足故常乐。 譬道之在天下，止於至善。 犹川谷之於江海。 止於卑下。 右三十二章　上章云有道者不处，此云道常无名，朴虽小，天下不敢臣，发明有道者所处之要也。 有道之士外处车下，内抱一真，万物自然，化天理自然，合神变，无穷。 烦曰：会得无各朴，方能纵复收。 便将大千界，撮在一毫头。 知人者智，见於外。 自知者明。 见於内。 胜人者有力，勇於敢。 自胜者强。 勇於不敢。 知足者富贫亦乐。 强行者有志。 始终不殆。 不失其所守者久，志力愈坚，命基愈固。 死而不亡者寿。 寿，上声。 真一常存。 右三十三章　知人胜人，明於外也。 自知自胜，存於内也。 证前三章用武之戒也。 知足者贫亦乐，力行者无不见，固守者无危殆，内明者出生死。 死而不亡者，真一常存。 颂曰：见物不见性，知人不自知。 个般无学辈，犹道得便宜。 大道泛兮，广大悉备。 其可左右。 无限量。 万物恃之以生而不辞所过者化。 功成不名有，所存者神。 爱养万物而不为主。 忘其所自。 常无欲，寂然不动。 可名於小。 芥子纳须弥。 万物归之而不为主，任运自然。 可名於大。 须弥纳芥子。 是以圣人终不为大芥子里藏身。 故能成其大。 不可称量。 右三十四章　大道泛兮，谓极广大，尽精微，靡所不备也。 万物恃之以生而不辞以下，接上章不失其所守者久之义也。 以之治国则不失其所守，以之修己则死而不亡，故曰其可左右。 颂曰：大道诚难测，虚空不可量。 寥寥成一片，何处是封疆。 执大象，象，上声。 视之不见。 天下往。
chunks.translated_text:
Beneath the myriad generations, lords of states who embrace non-action and purity bring about governance and transformation naturally, so that households and nations alike attain tranquility. Though they possess armor and weapons, they have no occasion to deploy them, forever free from the calamity of strife and contention.

In praise it is said:
Silent, the realm of pure mystery,
Limpid, nurturing the Great Harmony.
Inverted, the sword of samādhi is grasped,
Sequentially, the five skandha-demons are transformed.

The Dao is ever nameless, empty and self-so.
Though the Unhewn is minute to the point of imperceptibility,
none under Heaven dare make it a subject.
Supreme it is.
Should lords and kings be able to preserve it,
embracing the One,
the myriad things will of themselves become guests,
none failing to submit.

Heaven and Earth unite,
aided only by virtue,
to send down sweet dew—
the result of harmonious qi.
The people, without command, of themselves attain balance.
*(Command: read in the departing tone.)*
Naturally they achieve peace.
When first systems are established, names arise,
laws and institutions are set forth.
Once names exist,
likes and dislikes are shown.
Thus they will know where to halt.
*(This is to make them know prohibitions.)*
Knowing where to halt is how one avoids peril.
Knowing contentment is how one abides in constant joy.
The Dao’s presence in the world
comes to rest in utmost goodness,
as streams and valleys
come to rest in rivers and seas—
in lowliness.

Chapter Thirty-Two:
The preceding chapter states that “those with the Dao do not dwell [in contention],” and here it says, “The Dao is ever nameless; though the Unhewn is small, none under Heaven dare make it a subject.” This clarifies the essential dwelling of those with the Dao. The person of the Dao outwardly abides beneath the chariot, inwardly embraces the One Real, and the myriad things naturally transform. Heavenly principle is spontaneously so, merging with spiritual transformation—boundless.

In praise it is said:
Once you grasp the Unhewn without flaw,
you can freely release and gather.
Then the great chiliocosm
is held in the tip of a hair.

Knowing others is wisdom,
manifest outwardly.
Knowing oneself is clarity,
manifest inwardly.
Overcoming others requires strength,
courage in daring.
Overcoming oneself requires strength,
courage in not daring.
Knowing contentment is wealth—
even in poverty, one is joyful.
Those who persevere in action have resolve,
ever unassailable.
Those who do not lose their grasp endure,
their will and power grow ever firmer,
their life’s foundation ever more secure.
Those who “die yet do not perish” attain longevity.
*(Longevity: read in the rising tone.)*
The True One abides constantly.

Chapter Thirty-Three:
Knowing others and overcoming others pertain to the external.
Knowing oneself and overcoming oneself reside within.
This confirms the warning of the preceding three chapters against the use of arms.
Those who know contentment find joy even in poverty.
Those who persevere in action see all things accomplished.
Those who firmly hold their ground face no peril.
Those inwardly illuminated transcend life and death.
“Dying yet not perishing” means the True One abides constantly.

In praise it is said:
Seeing things yet not seeing nature,
knowing others yet not knowing oneself—
such unlearned sorts
still claim to have gained advantage.

The Great Dao overflows,
vast and all-encompassing.
It can be to the left or right,
without limit.
The myriad things rely on it to live, yet it does not refuse;
where it passes, transformation occurs.
Its work is accomplished, yet it claims no possession—
what remains is spirit.
It nurtures and sustains the myriad things yet does not act as their lord,
forgetting its own origin.
Ever desireless, still and unmoving,
it may be called “small.”
*(A mustard seed contains Mount Sumeru.)*
The myriad things return to it, yet it does not act as their lord,
letting things follow their natural course.
It may be called “great.”
*(Mount Sumeru contains a mustard seed.)*
Thus the sage never regards himself as great,
*(Abiding within a mustard seed.)*
and so is able to accomplish greatness—
beyond measure.

Chapter Thirty-Four:
“The Great Dao overflows” means it is utterly vast, penetrating the most subtle, lacking nothing. “The myriad things rely on it to live yet it does not refuse” and what follows connect to the preceding chapter’s “those who do not lose their grasp endure.” Applied to governing the state, this means not losing one’s grasp; applied to self-cultivation, it means “dying yet not perishing.” Hence it is said, “It can be to the left or right.”

In praise it is said:
The Great Dao is truly hard to fathom,
empty space cannot be measured.
Vast and boundless, forming a single expanse—
where are its borders?

Grasping the Great Image,
*(Image: read in the rising tone.)*
though one looks, it cannot be seen—
all under Heaven come to it.

chunks.translated_text:
The myriad people submit.
They come without harm, and the myriad things flourish.
In peace and great tranquility,
the ten thousand transformations rest secure.

Music and delicacies—
*(Music: read as "yào.")*
both sound and flavor are exquisite.
They entice the passing traveler to stay.
Yet when the traveler passes, they cease.

The Dao that issues from the mouth
is bland, as if without flavor.
*(Issues: read in the falling tone.)*
Without sound, without scent,
gazing, one cannot see it—
the Great Image has no form.
Listening, one cannot hear it—
the Great Tone is soundless.
Its use cannot be exhausted.

The Dao is hidden, without name;
its use is inexhaustible.

Chapter Thirty-Five:
The closing line of the preceding chapter states, "Hence it can accomplish greatness," so this chapter follows with "Grasping the Great Image, all under Heaven come," meaning that preserving its formlessness draws the hearts of people and things to turn and submit. "Music and delicacies," where both sound and flavor are exquisite, lose this formlessness—how can they endure? The Dao that issues from the mouth is flavorless and formless, without sound or color. Because it has no fixed body, its responsiveness and use are inexhaustible.

In praise it is said:
A mud ox pants at the moon,
a wooden horse neighs in the wind.
Gazing, it seems to exist—
seeking, it has no trace.
The hermit’s staff at Clear Hermitage
sketches the wondrous peak of Miao Gao.
To gather it in?
One must first firmly open it—
firmly opening, it must then gather.

In praise it is said:
The Great Dao is truly hard to fathom,
empty space cannot be measured.
Vast and boundless, forming a single expanse—
where are its borders?

Grasping the Great Image,
*(Image: read in the rising tone.)*
though one looks, it cannot be seen—
all under Heaven come to it.

chunks.original_text: 将欲弱之，必固强之固强必弱。 将欲废之，必固兴之，固兴必废。 将欲夺之，必固与之。 固与必夺。 是谓微明。 几微先兆。 柔弱胜刚强。 柔弱常和，用刚必败。 鱼不可脱於渊，人安可离於道。 国之利器，不可以示人。 有利则有害。 右三十六章　执大象则能见事之几微。 才见固张，便知将歙，未萌先兆，未举先知，非天下之微明，其孰能及此。 学道之士，存其无象，守其至柔，与物无竞，则自然知几。 苟用刚暴，尚权谋智术，求其胜物，非道也哉。 比如鱼本水中物，求异群鱼欲脱於渊，可乎？ 既不可，则人亦不可尚权。 尚权者，反常也，如鱼离渊必死。 国之利器不可示人，即孔子所谓可与立不可与权同一义。 圣人用权，反常合道，尚不可轻为，而况常人乎？ 可不戒哉。 颂曰：眼若流星，机如掣电。 瞻之在前，忽然不见。 十方通塞中，光明无不遍。 道常无为，而无不为。 寂然不动，感通天下之故。 侯王若能守，万物将自化。 上以风化下。 化而欲作，吾将镇之以无名之朴。 作，做，入声。 我无欲而民自朴。 无名之朴，亦将不欲，我好静而民自正。 不欲以静，使夫知者不敢为。 天下将自正。 为无为。 则无不治。 右三十七章　真常之道本无为，有为即非常道，接上章微明之义。 天地无为，万物生成，圣人无为，万民安泰。 以修炼言之，都无作为，於安静之时存其无象，毫发之动便要先觉，既觉便以无名朴镇之。 朴本无形，又曰无名，谓空也。 道无为，朴无名，心无欲，则自然复静也。 静之又静，天下将自正。 颂曰：有作皆为幻，无为又落空。 两途俱不涉，当处阐宗风。 道德会元卷上竟 ＃1 此处疑有误。 道德会元卷下 都粱清庵莹蟾子李道纯元素述 上德不德，不尚己德。 是以有德其德愈大。
chunks.translated_text:
To weaken it, one must first firmly strengthen it—firmly strengthened, it must then weaken.
To abolish it, one must first firmly establish it—firmly established, it must then abolish.
To seize it, one must first firmly give it—firmly given, it must then seize.
This is called subtle illumination.
The slightest sign is the first omen.

The soft and weak overcome the hard and strong.
The soft and weak are ever harmonious; to employ hardness is to court defeat.
Fish cannot leave the depths—
how can man depart from the Dao?
A state’s sharp instruments must not be shown to others.
Where there is advantage, there is harm.

This is the thirty-sixth chapter.
Grasping the Great Image, one perceives the subtlest signs of affairs.
No sooner does one see firm expansion than one knows coming contraction;
before the sprout appears, the omen is already known.
Who but the subtly illuminated of all under Heaven could attain this?

Those who study the Dao preserve its formlessness and guard its utmost softness.
They contend not with things, and thus naturally know the signs.
If one employs violence, exalts stratagems and cunning,
seeking to overcome things—this is not the Dao.
For example, fish belong in water;
to seek distinction among other fish and leave the depths—is this possible?
Since it is not, then neither should man exalt power.
To exalt power is to reverse the constant—like fish leaving the depths, they must perish.

A state’s sharp instruments must not be shown to others—
this aligns with Confucius’ saying, “One may stand with them, but not weigh with them.”
Even when sages employ power, reversing the constant to accord with the Dao,
it must not be lightly done—how much less so for ordinary people?
Can one not be warned?

In praise it is said:
Eyes like shooting stars,
mechanism swift as lightning.
Gazing, it seems ahead—
suddenly, it is gone.
Within the openness and obstruction of the ten directions,
light pervades all without exception.

The Dao is ever non-action, yet nothing is left undone.
Still and unmoving, it responds and connects with all under Heaven.
Should lords and kings be able to guard it,
the myriad things will transform of themselves.
Above, they transform those below as wind.
When transformation stirs and desires arise,
I will quell them with the nameless uncarved block.

*Act* (pronounced in the entering tone).
Without desire on my part, the people naturally return to simplicity.
The nameless uncarved block also will have no desire.
I value stillness, and the people naturally rectify themselves.
Without desire, through stillness,
the wise are made not to dare act.
All under Heaven will naturally rectify itself.

Act through non-action—
then nothing will be left ungoverned.

This is the thirty-seventh chapter.
The true and constant Dao is fundamentally non-action;
action is not the constant Dao.
This connects to the previous chapter’s subtle illumination.
Heaven and Earth act not, yet the myriad things are born and completed.
The sage acts not, yet the myriad people are at peace.
In terms of self-cultivation:
without any contrivance, in moments of stillness preserve its formlessness.
At the slightest movement, one must first awaken—
once awakened, quell it with the nameless uncarved block.
The uncarved block has no form, and is also called nameless—meaning emptiness.
The Dao is non-action; the uncarved block is nameless; the heart is without desire—
then one naturally returns to stillness.
Stillness upon stillness—
all under Heaven will naturally rectify itself.

In praise it is said:
All action is illusion;
non-action, too, falls into emptiness.
Transcending both paths,
one unfolds the essence of the lineage.

chunks.original_text: 下德不失德，执着己德。 是以无德。 其德愈失。 上德无为而无以为，寂然不动，感而遂通。 下德为之而有以为。 以德求感，有所作为。 上仁为之而无以为，施仁及物，本无作为。 上义为之而有以为以义接物，有所作为。 上礼为之而莫之应，以礼齐物，终不能齐。 攘臂而仍之。 攘，如羊切。 力挽之，愈不齐。 故失道而后德，近道。 失德而后仁，近德。 失仁而后义，近仁。 失义而后礼。 近义。 夫礼者，不淳。 忠信之薄不厚。 乱之首也。 不齐。 前识者，道之华，求奇不实。 愚之始也。 失道。 是以大丈夫处其厚不处其薄，尚质实，不求识。 居其实不居其华。 尚诚实，不尚礼。 故去彼取此。 去，羌吕切。 舍妄从真。 右三十八章　上章云道常无为，故次之以上德不德。 上德无为，故合道。 下德有为，不合道。 仁义犹近德，可为进道之阶。 礼者，纯是作为多不实，以礼齐物，物转不齐。 盖有为终有失也。 执之不失，亦可渐入佳境，自仁义而反德，自德而反道，直造无为也。 前识者，智识也。 智识者，失道之始。 故曰道之华，有道者不处。 颂曰：未得超三界，如何出五常。 五常归罔象，独步谒虚皇。 昔之得一者，得一万事毕。 天得一以清，湛然常寂。 地得一以宁，寂然不动。 神得一以灵，混然成真。 谷得一以盈，绰然有余。 万物一以生，自然发育。 侯王得一以为天下贞。 泰然安固。 其致之，一也。 天无以清将恐裂，星辰失度。 地无以宁将恐发，山岳崩颓。 神无以灵将恐歇，阴阳失节。 谷无以盈将恐竭，闭塞不通。 万物无以生将恐灭，和气耗散。 侯王无以贞贵高将恐蹙家国危殆。 故贵以贱为本，一也。 高以下为基。 一也。 侯王自谓孤寡不毂，常抱其一。 此其以贱为本也。 一为万象主。 非乎？ 岂不然哉。
chunks.translated_text:
The lesser virtue does not lose virtue—
thus it clings to its own virtue.
Therefore, it has no virtue,
and its virtue is ever more lost.

The highest virtue acts without acting and without contrivance,
still and unmoving,
yet responsive and perfectly attuned.
The lesser virtue acts with contrivance,
seeking resonance through virtue,
ever scheming and striving.

The highest benevolence acts without contrivance,
bestowing kindness upon all things,
yet fundamentally without action.
The highest righteousness acts with contrivance,
engaging with things through righteousness,
ever scheming and striving.
The highest propriety acts, yet none respond—
seeking to order all things through ritual,
yet never truly ordering them.
One thrusts forth an arm to pull them back,
but the more one pulls, the less they align.

Thus, when the Dao is lost, virtue arises—close to the Dao.
When virtue is lost, benevolence arises—close to virtue.
When benevolence is lost, righteousness arises—close to benevolence.
When righteousness is lost, propriety arises—close to righteousness.
Yet propriety marks the thinning of sincerity,
the erosion of loyalty and trust,
the beginning of chaos.
It fails to order.
Foreknowledge is but the flower of the Dao,
seeking novelty without substance—
the beginning of folly,
the loss of the Dao.

Therefore, the great person dwells in depth, not in shallowness,
values substance and truth, not recognition.
Abides in reality, not in its blossoms,
upholds sincerity, not propriety.
Thus, one discards that and embraces this—
forsakes delusion to follow truth.

**Chapter Thirty-Eight**
The preceding chapter spoke of the Dao’s constant non-action,
so this follows with the highest virtue’s non-virtue.
The highest virtue acts without acting, thus aligning with the Dao.
The lesser virtue acts with contrivance, thus misaligning with the Dao.
Benevolence and righteousness remain close to virtue,
serving as steps toward the Dao.
Propriety, however, is rife with contrivance and lacks substance—
seeking to order all things through ritual,
yet things grow ever more disordered.
For all contrivance ultimately leads to loss.
Even clinging without loss may gradually lead to refinement,
returning from benevolence and righteousness to virtue,
from virtue to the Dao,
and thus attaining non-action.

Foreknowledge is but cleverness,
and cleverness marks the beginning of the Dao’s loss.
Thus it is called the flower of the Dao—
those who possess the Dao do not dwell in it.

In praise it is said:
Before transcending the Three Realms,
how can one escape the Five Constants?
The Five Constants dissolve into formlessness,
as one strides alone to meet the August Void.

Of old, those who attained the One—
attaining the One, all things were complete.
Heaven attained the One and became clear,
profoundly still and constant.
Earth attained the One and became tranquil,
silent and unmoving.
Spirits attained the One and became numinous,
merging into truth.
Valleys attained the One and became full,
abundant and overflowing.
The myriad things attained the One and came to life,
naturally flourishing.
Lords and kings attained the One and became the standard for all under Heaven,
serene and firmly established.
Their attainment was the One.

If Heaven lacked clarity, it would fear splitting—
the stars and constellations would lose their order.
If Earth lacked tranquility, it would fear erupting—
mountains and peaks would crumble.
If spirits lacked numinosity, they would fear fading—
yin and yang would lose their harmony.
If valleys lacked fullness, they would fear exhaustion—
blocked and impassable.
If the myriad things lacked life, they would fear extinction—
the harmonious qi would dissipate.
If lords and kings lacked integrity, their loftiness and nobility would fear collapse—
their states and families would face peril.

Thus, nobility takes humility as its root—this is the One.
Loftiness takes lowliness as its foundation—this is the One.
Lords and kings call themselves "orphaned," "widowed," and "destitute,"
ever embracing the One.
Is this not taking humility as their root?
The One is the master of the ten thousand images—
is it not so?
How could it be otherwise?

chunks.original_text: 故致数车无车，数，音所。 数我无我。 不欲碌碌如玉，落落如石。 贵贱两忘。 右三十九章　上章云去彼取此，谓去其末而取其本也。 本者何？ 一也。 一者，天地之始，万物之母，大道之用。 侯王若能守，万物自然归往也。 自谓孤寡不毂，自卑升高不忘本也。 不欲碌碌如玉、落落如石，贵贱两忘，惟抱一也。 数车之名件，无一名车者。 数我之一身，无一名我者。 毂辏合一则名车，四大合一则名我也。 颂曰：得一非为妙，还虚未是玄。 梦中知是梦，天外莫寻天。 反者道之动，神一出便收来。 弱者道之用。 专气致柔。 天下万物生於有，有名，万物之母。 有生於无。 无名，天地之始。 右四十章　反者道之动，接上章贵以贱为本也。 万物生於有，有生於无，即数车无车之说。 只这有无相生之理，多少学人不知端的。 且道如何是有无端的意？ 看颂日：有象非为有，无形未是无。 有无俱不立，犹是堕偏枯。 无有有无中得趣，方知胡子没髭须。 上士闻道，勤而行之； 上士一决一齐了。

Thus, when counting carts, there is no single cart—*shu*, pronounced *suo*.
When counting *wo*, there is no *wo*.
One does not wish to be as polished as jade, or as cold as stone.
Noble and base are both forgotten.

**Chapter Thirty-Nine**
The previous chapter spoke of discarding that to take this—meaning to discard the superficial and take the root.
What is the root? The One.
The One is the beginning of Heaven and Earth, the mother of the myriad things, the application of the Great Dao.
If lords and kings could guard it, the myriad things would naturally return to it.
Calling oneself "orphaned," "widowed," and "destitute" is to remain humble and not forget the root.
Not wishing to be as polished as jade or as cold as stone, forgetting noble and base—only embracing the One.
The name "counting carts" has no single cart.
The name "counting *wo*" has no single *wo*.
When the axle and wheels unite, it is called a cart.
When the four elements unite, it is called *wo*.

The ode says:
Obtaining the One is not called wondrous,
Returning to emptiness is not yet the Mysterious.
Knowing a dream is a dream within dreaming,
Beyond Heaven, do not seek Heaven.

The reversal is the movement of the Dao—
When the numinous One emerges, it is drawn back.
The weak is the application of the Dao.
Focused *qi* achieves softness.

The myriad things arise from *you* (having).
*You* has a name—it is the mother of the myriad things.
*You* arises from *wu* (non-being).
*Wu* has no name—it is the beginning of Heaven and Earth.

**Chapter Forty**
The reversal is the movement of the Dao—continuing the previous chapter’s teaching that nobility takes humility as its root.
The myriad things arise from *you*, *you* from *wu*—this is the teaching of counting carts without a cart.
Yet how many scholars do not grasp this principle truly.

Moreover, how does the Dao express the essence of *you* and *wu*?
Observe the ode:
Having form is not *you*,
Formless is not *wu*.
Neither *you* nor *wu* can stand alone—
Still, this is to fall into one-sidedness.
Only within the interplay of *you* and *wu* does one find the path—
Then one knows the Master’s hidden beard.

The superior person hears the Dao and diligently acts upon it;
The superior person resolves and unifies it all at once.

chunks.original_text: 中士闻道，若存若亡； 中下多闻多不信。 下士闻道，大笑之。 因何信不及，只为太分明。 不笑，不足以为道。 大迷之下，必有大悟。 故建言有之：才闻两片，露出肝肠。 明道若昧，含华隐曜。 进道若退，瞻前顾后。 夷道若类和光同尘。 上德若谷，虚以受人。 大白若辱，卑以自牧。 广德若不足满而不溢。 建德若偷，偷，音俞，叶渝。 密而不露。 质真若渝应变无方。 大方无隅，不露圭角。 大器晚成，不有其功。 大音希声，叩之即应。 大象无形。 莫见乎隐。 道隐无名，莫显乎微。 夫唯道，善贷且成。 忠恕而已。 右四十一章　上章云有无相生，非高上之士不容无疑，故次之以上士闻道。 夫道若昧、若退、若类、若偷、若渝，不可得而见，闻可笑之由。 惟高上之士禀性冲虚，故能超然直入，不言而信，无为而成之也。 中人以下未免半疑半信，下愚不肖者不惟不信，又且笑而侮之也。 善贷且成者，贷下士笑侮之过，而成上士勤行之功也。 虽下愚不肖，一觉其初，便可反善，人之不善，何弃之有。 颂曰：至道元容易，人心自谓难。 中人犹拟议，下士转颟顸。 莫颟顸星在，秤兮物在盘。 道生一，虚无生一气。 一生二，一气判阴阳。 二生三，阴肠成三才。 三生万物。 三才生万类。 万物负阴而抱阳，成象於天，成形於地。 冲气以为和。 察气於中和。 人之所恶，惟孤寡不毂，一无隅，众人之所忌。 而王公以为称。 自谓孤寡。 故物一切有象。 或损之而益，谦者受益。 或益之而损。 满者必覆。 人之所教，无非为善。 亦我义教之。 我亦如是。

**Chapter Forty-One**
The middle scholar hears the Dao—sometimes as if it exists, sometimes as if it does not.
The mediocre and below hear much but believe little.
The lowly scholar hears the Dao and laughs at it.
Why do they not believe? Only because it is too clear.
If one does not laugh, it is not truly the Dao.
After great confusion, there must be great awakening.

Thus it is said:
At first hearing, the two fragments reveal the liver’s depths.
The Dao, though bright, is veiled in bloom—
Advancing in the Dao seems like retreat,
Looking forward and backward.
The Dao blends like harmony, like dust in the light.
Virtue’s height is like a valley—
Empty, it receives all.
Great whiteness seems like shame—
Lowly, it tends itself.
Broad virtue seems insufficient—
Full yet not overflowing.
Established virtue seems like theft—
*Thief*, pronounced *yú*, rhymes with *yú* (渝).
Sealed yet not exposed.
True substance, like *yú*, adapts without measure.
The greatest square has no corners—
No sharp angles revealed.
Great vessels mature late—
No claim to their own achievement.
Great sound is rare—
Strike it, and it responds.
Great form is shapeless.
Nothing is more hidden than what is concealed.
The Dao is hidden, nameless—
Nothing is more manifest than the subtle.

Only the Dao
Lends itself well and brings completion.
Loyalty and reciprocity—nothing more.

---

The previous chapter spoke of *you* and *wu* generating each other—
A teaching only the noble can doubt.
Thus, it follows with the superior scholar hearing the Dao.
The Dao, though veiled, though seeming retreat, though blending, though hidden like theft,
Cannot be seen—
Hence the reason for laughter upon hearing it.
Only the noble, with nature pure and empty,
Can transcend and enter directly—
Silent yet believed, effortless yet accomplished.

The mediocre and below cannot help but waver between doubt and belief;
The lowly and unworthy do not merely disbelieve—they laugh and scorn it.

*"Lends itself well and brings completion"* means:
Lending to the lowly’s laughter and scorn,
While completing the superior’s diligent practice.

Even the lowly and unworthy—
Once awakened at the start,
Can turn back to goodness.
Why should anyone be abandoned for their failings?

The ode says:
The supreme Dao is originally easy,
Yet human hearts claim it difficult.
The middle scholar still debates,
The lowly turns dull-witted.
No dull-witted star exists—
Weigh it, and the thing is on the scale.

The Dao generates One—
The void generates One *qi*.
One generates Two—
One *qi* divides into yin and yang.
Two generates Three—
Yin forms the Three Powers.
Three generates the myriad things.
The Three Powers generate myriad forms.
The myriad things bear yin and embrace yang,
Taking form from Heaven, shape from Earth.
The harmonizing *qi* is the middle.
Examine the *qi* of middle harmony.

What people detest—
The solitary, the orphaned, the unpaired,
The cornerless—
Is what rulers prize.
They call themselves solitary and orphaned.
Thus, all things have form.
Sometimes, diminishing benefits,
The humble receive gain.
Sometimes, adding causes loss—
The full must overturn.
What people teach is always for goodness—
Yet it is also my righteous teaching.
I am also like this.

One is the mother of all things.

The solitary, the orphaned, the unpaired—

In humility and self-effacement.

**Ode:**
To love victory is to often meet adversity,

Gentleness and harmony are daily virtues,
In every place, the realm of kings and mountains.

The utmost softness in the world
Overcomes the utmost hardness in the world.
Softness can erode hardness.
There is nothing that cannot enter where there are no gaps.
Piercing metal, penetrating stone.

Thus, I know the benefit of *wuwei*.
Humility brings benefit.
Teaching without words,
Silent yet trusted.
The benefit of *wuwei* is achieved through *wuwei*.

chunks.original_text: 右四十三章　上章孤寡不毂，至谦也，故次之以至柔。 谓柔弱胜刚强，损中有益，损之又损，以至无为。 不言而可信，无为之益，世鲜及之。 颂曰：触来勿与竞，事过心清凉。 只这清凉境，乾坤不覆藏。 名与身，孰亲？ 名高辱身。 身与货，孰多？ 财多害己。 得与失，孰病？ 得宠思辱。 是故甚爱必大费，贪他底，着他底。 多藏必厚亡。 讨便宜，落便宜。 知足不辱，足止贪。 知止不殆，畏止祸。 可以长久。 知足常足。 右四十四章　上章无为之益，谓有为则有损也。 故次之以名与身孰亲。 名货得失皆有为也，终不长久。 惟知足知止，可以长久。 颂曰：世间一切有，到底不长久。 摄伏猕猴心，听取狮子吼。 若能运出家中宝，啼鸟山花一样春。 大成若缺，其用不弊，弊，叶韵作鳖。 不自显，故无坏。 大盈若冲，其用不穷。 不自满，故无尽。 大直若屈，直而不肆。 大巧若拙，为而不恃。 大辨若讷。 光而不曜。 躁胜寒，躁暴者焚。 静胜热，安静者凉。 清静为天下正。 人能常清静，天地悉皆归。 右四十五章 上章知足不辱，故次之以大成若缺。 德有余而为不足者寿，财有余而为不足者鄙。 大成若缺，大盈若冲，至於若屈若拙若讷，皆德有余而为不足，用之无尽也，故为天下正。 颂曰：人情多聚散，世道有兴衰。 惟有真常在，古今无改移。 化天下有道，情逐性。 却走马以粪，意马闲，灵苗秀。 天下无道，性逐情。 戎马生於郊。 意马狂，心地荒。 罪莫大於可欲，取辱之由。 祸莫大於不知足，陷身之端。 咎莫大於欲得。 杀身之本。 故知足之足，常足。 知足者贫亦乐。 右四十六章　上章清静为天下正，故次之以天下有道。 有道则清静，清静则天下正，天下正则罢兵事、务农事，故曰却走马以粪。 无道则不清静，不清静则天下不正，则用威武征伐，故曰戎马生於郊。 曰罪曰祸曰咎，皆欲心所致，故结句云知足常足，以修身言之。 清静则欲心止，欲心止则意大定，故曰却走马以粪。 不清静欲心不止，欲心不止则意马狂，故曰戎马生於郊。 颂曰：不见可欲，使心不乱。 急走回来，救得一半。 天下本无事，人心自着忙。 不出户，知天下； 反穷诸己。 不窥牖，见天道。 回光返照。 其出弥远，其知弥少。 外事有限。 是以圣人不行而至，不移一步到长安。 不见而名，不见一物即如来。 不为而成。 不动一毫成正觉。 右四十七章　不出户知天下，言有道之士知内不知外，接上章之义。 知内不知外，则无所不知，见内不见外，则无所不见。 若只知外见外而忘其内者，知见浅狭矣。 颂曰：朝游南岳，暮宿苍梧。 倏忽千里，不曾离渠。 踏破铁鞋无觅处，得来全不费工夫。 为学日益，精进。 为道日损，减损。 损之又损，一切损尽。 以至无为，无损可损。 无为而无不为。 无不克。 取天下常以无事，事向无心得。 及其有事，有心便不得。 不足以取天下。 有为终有尽。 右四十八章　不出户知天下，内知也。 其出弥远，外事也。 故次之为学日益。 言无学者求其增益，为道者事事减损。 《易》云：山下有泽损，君子以惩忿窒欲。 正谓此也。 至于无忿可惩，无欲可损，以至无为，则万民化而天下归往也。 苟或妄有作为，则民乱而难治，故曰不足以取天下。
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter 43:**
The previous chapter spoke of the lonely and widowed who do not turn their wheels [of action], the utmost humility. Hence, it follows with the utmost softness.
It means that softness overcomes hardness, that loss contains benefit, and that loss upon loss reaches *wuwei* [non-action].
Without speaking, yet trustworthy; the benefit of *wuwei*, few in the world attain.
**Ode:**
When met with opposition, do not compete,
When matters pass, let the heart remain cool.
This very realm of coolness,
Where even the heavens and earth cannot conceal it.
Which is closer—name or body?
A high name brings dishonor to the body.
Which is more abundant—body or wealth?
Excess wealth brings harm to oneself.
Which is more harmful—gain or loss?
Gained favor invites dishonor.
Thus, the more one loves, the greater the expense,
The more one covets others’ possessions, the more one clings to them.
The more one hoards, the greater the loss.
Seeking advantage only brings misfortune.
Knowing sufficiency brings no dishonor; sufficiency stops greed.
Knowing restraint brings no peril; fearing restraint averts calamity.
Thus, one may endure long.
Knowing sufficiency is always sufficiency.

**Chapter 44:**
The previous chapter spoke of the benefit of *wuwei*, meaning that action brings loss.
Hence, it follows with: *Which is closer—name or body?*
Name, wealth, gain, and loss are all rooted in action; they cannot endure long.
Only knowing sufficiency and restraint can endure long.
**Ode:**
All things in the world are transient,
None can last eternally.
Tame the restless monkey-mind,
Listen to the lion’s roar.
If one can unleash the treasure within the family,
Then the spring blooms like birdsong in mountain flowers.
The greatest attainment seems incomplete,
Yet its use knows no exhaustion. (*弊* rhymes with *鳖*)
Not self-displaying, hence unbroken.
The greatest abundance seems to overflow,
Yet its use is inexhaustible.
Not self-satisfied, hence without end.
The greatest uprightness seems to bend,
Yet it does not flaunt.
The greatest skill seems clumsy,
Yet it does not rely on artifice.
The greatest discernment seems inarticulate,
Yet it shines without glare.
Agitation overcomes coldness—
The reckless burn.
Calm overcomes heat—
The tranquil cool.
Purity and stillness are the Dao of the world.
If people can abide in purity and stillness,
All under heaven will return to them.

**Chapter 45:**
The previous chapter spoke of purity and stillness as the Dao of the world, so it follows with: *The greatest attainment seems incomplete...*
Those with virtue in excess yet action in deficit live long,
Those with wealth in excess yet action in deficit are despised.
The greatest attainment seems incomplete,
The greatest abundance seems to overflow,
Even to the utmost bending, clumsiness, and inarticulateness—
All are virtue in excess yet action in deficit,
Their use is inexhaustible.
Thus, they are the Dao of the world.
**Ode:**
Human nature knows gathering and scattering,
The world’s ways have rise and decline.
Only the True Constant endures,
Unchanged from ancient to modern.
To transform the world there is a method:
Emotions follow nature.
To curb the warhorses with dung,
The mind-horse is idle, the spirit-sprout flourishes.
When the world lacks the Dao,
Nature follows emotions.
Warhorses are born in the suburbs.
The mind-horse rages, the heart’s ground is desolate.
No guilt is greater than craving,
The root of dishonor.
No calamity is greater than not knowing sufficiency,
The trap that ensnares the body.
No blame is greater than desiring gain,
The origin of self-destruction.
Thus, knowing sufficiency is always sufficiency.
The contented poor find joy in their lot.

**Chapter 46:**
The previous chapter spoke of purity and stillness as the Dao of the world, so it follows with: *The world’s ways have rise and decline...*
Not stepping outside yet knowing the world—
This speaks of the Daoist who knows the inner yet ignores the outer, continuing the previous chapter’s meaning.
To know the inner yet ignore the outer
Is to know nothing yet see nothing.
If one only knows the outer and sees the outer while forgetting the inner,
Then one’s knowledge and vision are shallow and narrow.
**Ode:**
Morning I wander the Southern Peak,
Evening I rest in the Azure Mound.
Swiftly a thousand miles,
Yet never have I strayed from it.
Tread iron shoes to no avail—
The sought is found without effort.
To study is to daily increase,
To practice the Dao is to daily decrease.
Decrease upon decrease,
All loss is exhausted.
Until reaching *wuwei* [non-action],
Where nothing more can be lost.
In *wuwei*, yet nothing is undone.
Nothing is unconquered.
To take the world, one must act with no affairs,
For affairs arise from the mind’s fixation.
When affairs arise, the mind’s fixation cannot be attained.
Thus, it is insufficient to take the world.
Action always has an end.

**Chapter 47:**
Not stepping outside yet knowing the world—
This is inner knowledge.
The farther one goes, the more distant,
Outer affairs.
Hence, it follows with: *To study is to daily increase...*
It means the unlearned seek only gain,
But those who practice the Dao decrease in all things.
The *Yijing* says: *Mountains below, marshes above—loss. The superior person restrains anger and checks desires.*
This is exactly so.
When even anger is extinguished and desire is lost,
Until reaching *wuwei* [non-action],
Then all under heaven is transformed and the world returns to order.
If one acts recklessly,
The people are disordered and difficult to govern.
Thus, it is insufficient to take the world.

**Chapter 49:**
The ode says:
*With learning, confusion grows at every turn,*
*Without action, all things fall into place.*
*When both learning and action are abandoned,*
*Loss and gain are left to others.*

Do not mock my humble, poverty-stricken appearance,
For from old it is said that thieves do not rob the poor.

The sage has no fixed mind,
No rigid method of action.
He takes the hearts of the people as his own.
He follows the Way’s spontaneous responses,
Adjusting to circumstances.

To the virtuous, I am virtuous;
I follow them and do virtuous deeds.
To the unvirtuous, I am also virtuous;
I guide them to return to virtue.
*Virtue’s power is complete*—
It fulfills their highest good.

To the faithful, I am faithful;
I follow them and do faithful deeds.
To the unfaithful, I am also faithful;
I guide them to return to faith.
*Faith’s power is complete*—
It fulfills their highest truth.

The sage moves through the world in reverence—
*惵惵* (*jùn-jùn*), trembling with care,
*兢兢业业* (*jìng-jìng yèyè*), diligent and unwavering—
Yet he blends the hearts of the people,
*浑* (*hún*), leveling them as one.
Different paths, the same end.
All the people turn their ears and eyes toward him;
His bearing is dignified, his deeds a model.
The sage nurtures them as children.
Under heaven, one great family.

The preceding chapter spoke of *wuwei* [non-action] taking the world,
So it follows with: *The sage has no fixed mind.*
By *no fixed mind*, it means
Following the Way’s spontaneous responses,
Never opposing the natural inclinations of the people.
Thus, the people obey the sage’s words,
Emulate the sage’s actions,
Follow the sage’s transformation,
And the world unites in one heart.

The ode says:
*To the faithful, I follow their faith,*
*To the virtuous, I follow their virtue.*
If one could truly understand this,
Yet still cling to inverted views—
*颠倒见* (*diāndào jiàn*, inverted perception)—
Then the Three Realms become one expanse,
And the ten directions merge into a single plane.
Emerging from birth, entering death,
Passing through the gates of anger and desire.

Those who live abandon anger and desire,
Yet thirteen in ten perish by water or fire.
Those who die indulge in anger and desire,
Yet thirteen in ten are spared by water or fire.
All life depends on water and fire.
To stir them toward death’s path,
Water and fire clash against them—
Also thirteen in ten.
*Water* completes its cycle in six,
*Fire* in seven.
Why so?
It is anger and desire that cause this.

Anger and desire do not cease,
Greed for life is insatiable.
It is said that those who skillfully guard life
Have no anger or desire.

Traveling by land, they meet no tigers or rhinoceroses—
*兕* (*rì*, rhinoceros).
In self-reflection, they feel no guilt,
So what need for worry or fear?
Entering battle, they are not harmed by armor or weapons,
Their hearts unobstructed, so no dread exists.
The rhinoceros has no place to lodge its horn,
The tiger no place to set its claws,
Weapons no place to hold their blades.
If one does not cling to life,
How could there be death?
Why so?
The body is not mine to possess,
Death cannot harm me—
For I dwell in the realm of no-death.

Forgetting birth and death,
Thus the right fifty-first chapter:
The gentle and weak are those who guard life,
The strong and mighty are those who perish.
The gentle and weak can curb anger and desire,
While the strong and mighty are enslaved by them.
To curb anger, fire descends and is extinguished,
To restrain desire, water rises and is contained.
When water and fire are harmonized, life is sustained—
Hence they are called *those who guard life*.
Anger stirs the fire of ignorance,
Desire churns like ocean waves,
When water and fire clash, death ensues—
Hence they are called *those who perish*.
The strong and mighty greed for life without limit,
The gentle and weak regard death as returning home,
For they do not see death as death,
So what harm can tigers, rhinoceroses, armor, or weapons do to them?

In terms of the *Dan Dao* (Alchemical Dao),
When water and fire are harmonized, the *saintly embryo* (聖胎) congeals.
The ode says:
*Nirvana* (涅盘) is easy to grasp in the heart,
But discriminative wisdom is hard to discern.
Without discriminative wisdom,
How could there be death or life?
The *Dao* gives birth,
The *Yuan Shi* (元始) is the primal *qi* (祖气).
The *virtue/power* (德) nurtures it—
*Nurture* (畜), pronounced *xiù* (凶入声).
It transforms and gives birth to all the *Realms of Existence* (诸天).
It shapes all things—
In the heavens, it forms *images* (象).
By *effort* (势), it shapes forms on earth.
Thus all things, with their myriad forms,
Do not fail to honor the Dao and cherish virtue/power.
All arise from the Dao,
The Dao’s grandeur, virtue’s nobility—
Exceeding the ancients, surpassing the present.

None know their rank yet remain ever natural,
They do not speak of goodness in response.
Thus the Dao gives birth, nurtures, and preserves—
*Qi* (神) is complete.
It grows and fosters—
*Qi* (气) is complete.
It matures and perfects—
*Essence* (精) is complete.
It nourishes and shelters—
Form is complete.
Life is given yet not possessed,
Forgetting the *mechanisms* (机).
Action is taken yet not relied upon,
Forgetting the *affections* (情).
It grows yet is never slaughtered,
Forgetting all things—
This is called *mysterious virtue/power* (玄德),
In harmony with the Dao.

Thus the right fifty-first chapter:
Those who skillfully guard life
Know the realm of no-death,
Hence they follow with the words of *Dao-giving-birth*.
The Dao is formless,
Yet through giving birth to the heavens and earth, its form becomes visible.
The Dao is nameless,
Yet through fostering all things, its name can be established.
All things with their forms
Receive their mandate from the heavens,
Take shape from the earth,
Draw *qi* from the *Central Harmony* (中和),
All are the Dao’s manifestations—
Thus all things honor the Dao and cherish virtue/power.

The ode says:
*The Dao that can be spoken is not the true Dao*,
*The Way of non-action yet has action*.
I clearly explain it for you,
Yet all waters flow westward.
The night arrives, and the *chaos* (混沌) is plucked from the earth,
All forms and patterns remain unknown.
The world has a beginning,
Nameless—
The beginning of the heavens and earth.
They call it the *mother of the world*.
With a name—
The *mother of all things*.
Knowing its mother,
Knowing the root—
Knowing its root,
Its children reveal its end.
Knowing its children,
Knowing its future—
Returning to its mother,
Attaining the root—
The body remains unharmed,
Ever present.
Seal its *joy* (兑),
The inner realm does not escape.
Close its *gate* (门),
The outer realm does not enter.
A lifetime without exertion—
Not laboring yet governing.
Open its joy,
The inner realm emerges,
Accomplishing its affairs—
The outer realm enters.
A lifetime without salvation—
Forever losing the true Dao.

Seeing the small as *illumination* (明),
Knowing the subtle and minute (*few* and *microscopic*).
Guarding gentleness as *strength* (强).
Softness can erode hardness.
Using its *light* (光),
All things come and are illuminated.
Returning to its illumination, letting go and gathering—
No harm befalls the body.
*Letting go* (遗), pronounced *wèi* (音谓).
Beware of following others’ paths.
This is called *embracing constancy* (袭常).」

The Way gives birth—
This is the origin of the Way’s speech,
Thus it follows the beginning of all things beneath Heaven.

The final sentence is most urgent—
Those who cultivate the True Dao must turn here to the True Eye,

The ode proclaims:

*The highest is attainable,*
*Pure and clear by nature,*
*The original form."*

Further inquiry: How is the First Principle?
All speech about the Way is slander.

Let me know—
Before action, there is awareness.
Walk the Great Dao:
Do nothing,
Yet fear only what is given.
Those who recognize the Law tremble.

The Great Dao is vast and level,
Smooth and straight,
Yet people prefer shortcuts.
*Good*—pronounced *xiào* (去声).
They take risks for luck.

When affairs are excessive, chaos follows.
*Chao*—pronounced *cháo* (音潮).
Fields lie barren, sacred lands abandoned.
Granaries are empty—
Sacred lands exhausted.
Wearing ornate robes—greed.
Wielding sharp blades—anger.
Disdaining food and drink—delusion.
Wealth in excess—desire never ceases.
This is called *robber’s pride*.

The Three Poisons stir unrest—
This is not the Way. Indeed, it is error.

chunks.original_text: 右五十三章　上章云袭常，谓密用常道也，故次之以使我介然有所知。 有所知则能直下承当而密用，若无所知则不能密用，妄有作为。 内为根尘所蔽，外被业识所眩，兼无明，三毒为挠，非道也哉。 颂曰：弄巧成拙，多烦早老。 金玉满堂，焉能常保。 若於日用颠倒行，大地尘沙尽成宝。 善建者不拔，拔，音跋。 根深。 善抱者不脱，蒂固。 子孙祭祀不辍。 绵远。 修之於身，身修。 其德乃真； 全真。 修之於家，家齐。 其德有余； 宽裕。 修之於乡，乡修。 其德乃长； 久远。 修之於国，国治。 其德乃丰； 淳厚。 修之於天下，天下平。 其德乃普。 道泰。 故以身观身，内有一尘，其德不真。 以家观家，有一不顺，其德无余。 以乡观乡，有一不化，其德不长。 以国观国，有一不善，其德不丰。 以天下观天下。 有一小人，其德不普。 吾何以知天下之然哉？ 以此。 反求诸己。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Fifty-Third Chapter** (of the *Right* section) follows the previous chapter’s *"Climb the Constant"*—meaning the secret application of the Constant Dao—hence it continues with *"Let me know before action, there is awareness."*

With awareness, one can directly uphold and secretly apply it; without awareness, one cannot secretly apply it and acts recklessly. The mind is obscured by internal defilements and external karma and perception, compounded by ignorance, while the Three Poisons agitate—this is not the Dao, indeed it is error.

The verse praises:
*"Toying with cleverness ends in clumsiness,*
*Excessive troubles bring early decay.*
*Gold and jade fill the hall,*
*Yet how can they be kept always?*
If daily life is reversed in action,
All dust and sand of earth become treasure.*

*The well-built does not uproot,*
*Uproot—pronounced **bá** (音跋).*
*Roots deep.*
*The well-embraced does not fall,*
*Base firm.*
*Descendants’ sacrifices never cease,*
*Enduring.*

*Cultivate it in the self—self refined,*
*Its virtue becomes true;*
*Fully true.*
*Cultivate it in the family—family harmonized,*
*Its virtue overflows;*
*Abundant.*
*Cultivate it in the village—village refined,*
*Its virtue endures;*
*Long-lasting.*
*Cultivate it in the realm—realm governed,*
*Its virtue is profound;*
*Thick and rich.*
*Cultivate it in the world—world at peace,*
*Its virtue is universal.*
*The Dao flourishes.*

Thus, observe the self with the self—within, there is a single defilement, its virtue is not true.
Observe the family with the family—there is one discord, its virtue lacks abundance.
Observe the village with the village—there is one not transformed, its virtue does not endure.
Observe the realm with the realm—there is one not virtuous, its virtue is not profound.
Observe the world with the world—there is one petty man, its virtue is not universal.

How do I know the world is thus?
By this.
*Turn inward and examine oneself.*

chunks.original_text: 右五十四章　上章云使我介然有所知，有所知则道心坚固，不失其守，故次之．以善建者不拔也。 以之修身观心察性，心定则身之修也，以之治国观民察己，民化则国之治也。 天正有一不善，则是自己政化不善也。 《书》云：百姓有过，在于一人。 此之谓也。 反观诸己，心有一尘染着，则是我之性天未明也。 颂曰：观国非容易，观身意更深。 海枯终见底，人死不知心。 含德之厚，退藏於密。 比於赤子。 纯一不杂。 毒虫不螫，猛兽不攫，玃鸟不搏。 螫，音释。 攫、玃，并厥缚切。
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter 54**

The preceding chapter states: *"Let me thus know with clarity—when knowledge arises, the Dao-heart is steadfast, unshaken in its holding, hence it follows."* For what is well-established cannot be uprooted.

With this, one cultivates the self, observes the heart, and examines nature—when the heart is settled, the self is refined.
With this, one governs the realm, observes the people, and examines oneself—when the people are transformed, the realm is governed.

If Heaven’s order has even one flaw, then it is because one’s own governance and transformation are flawed.
As the *Book of Documents* says: *"When the people err, it lies with one man."*
This is what is meant.

Reflecting inward, if the heart harbors even a speck of defilement or attachment, then it is because my innate nature has not yet been illuminated.

**Ode:**
To observe the realm is no simple task,
To observe the self—its meaning runs yet deeper.
When the sea dries, its depths are revealed,
But when a man dies, his heart remains unknown.

Rich in virtue, he withdraws into seclusion—
Like the infant.
Pure and undivided.
Venomous creatures do not sting him,
Fierce beasts do not seize him,
Raptors do not strike him.

(*Shì* [螫], pronounced *shì* [释]. *Jué* [攫] and *yǎn* [玃], both pronounced *jué* [厥缚切].)

chunks.original_text: 我忘於物，物亦忘我。 骨弱筋柔而握固。 筋，音斤。 神全。 未知牝牡之合而作，，最平声。 精全。 精之至也。 自然。 终日号而不嘎号，平声。 气全。 和之至也。 柔和。 知和曰常，此天混然。 知常曰明，此天洞然。 益生不祥，益则有损。 心使气曰强。 气动则刚。 物壮则老，刚则易折。 是谓不道。 错。 不道早已。 丧失天真。 右五十五章　善建者不拔，德之厚也。 故次之以含德之厚比於赤子者，不失赤子之心也。 赤子之心纯一不杂，无害於物，物亦不能害。 不知有男女之别，其绞亦作，精气所至也，虽作而无心，故能全其至精。 终日号啼，其声不变，冲和所致也。 修身以此，则能全其本然，是谓含德之厚。 苟失其赤子之心， 作而心动，天真丧也。 赤子之心既发，便不自然，发而不远，而知觉亦可反常，故曰明。 苟不知觉而纵其所欲，日增日盛，精气耗散，故曰不祥。 血气既盛，又纵心而使之，愈盛也。 气血盛则形衰矣，是谓不道，不道则早已也。 颂曰：欲识混元面，先存赤子心。 此心常不昧，法体证黄金。 知者不言，默而成之。 言者不知。 口头三昧。 塞其兑，无言。 闭其门，无见。 挫其锐无争。 解其纷，无事。 和其光，无我。 同其尘，无人。 是谓玄同。 一以贯之。 故不可得而亲，忘情。 不可得而疏； 忘形。 不可得而利，忘物，不可得而害； 忘机。 不可得而贵，忘有。 不可得而贱。 忘无。 故为天下贵。 一切忘尽，真常独存。 右五十六章　含德之厚则能缄默，故次之以知者不言。 非不言也，无可得而说也。 尹真人云：非道不可言，不可言即道。 正谓此也。 予谓多言获利，不若默而无害也。 噫。 颂曰：绝利终无害，无亲便不疏。 多言应有失，争似觜卢都。 以正治国不偏不倚。 以奇用兵，无计无谋。 以无事取天下。 无为无执。
chunks.translated_text:
「I lose myself in things, and things lose themselves in me.
My bones are frail, my sinews soft, yet my grasp is firm.
(*Sīn* [筋], pronounced *jīn* [斤].)
My spirit is whole.
I do not know the union of male and female yet *yīn* [绞] arises,
(*Yīn* [绞], even tone.)
My essence is whole—
the utmost of essence.
Natural and unrestrained.
I wail all day yet my voice does not grow hoarse—
even tone.
My *qi* is whole.
The utmost of harmony.
Knowing harmony, I call it constant—
this is the Dao’s undifferentiated unity.
Knowing constancy, I call it clarity—
this is the Dao’s boundless openness.

To nurture life is to invite misfortune;
to increase is to bring loss.
When the heart commands *qi*, it becomes strong.
When *qi* moves, it becomes rigid.
When things grow robust, they age;
when rigid, they easily break.
This is called *not the Dao*.
(*Cuò* [错].)
Not the Dao is already premature death.
To lose one’s innate truth.

**Chapter 55:**
The well-founded is unshaken—
the depth of virtue.
Thus, I follow it with the verse:
*"To hold the primordial face,
First preserve the infant’s heart.
This heart ever unobscured,
Reveals the golden body of dharma.
The wise do not speak,
Silence accomplishes all.
Speakers do not know—
The threefold mystery of the tongue.
Close the mouth of speech,
No words escape.
Shut the gate of sight,
No forms enter.
Blunt the sharpness of strife,
No contention.
Unravel the tangled,
No affairs.
Harmonize its radiance,
No self remains.
Merge with the dust of things,
No others exist.
This is called *Mysterious Unity*.
One thread runs through all.
Thus, it cannot be grasped as near,
Forgetting emotion.
It cannot be cast aside as distant;
Forgetting form.
It cannot be exploited for gain,
Forgetting things.
It cannot be harmed by schemes,
Forgetting craft.
It cannot be prized as noble,
Forgetting possession.
It cannot be scorned as base,
Forgetting absence.
Thus, it is most noble in the world.
All forgetting exhausted, only true constancy remains."*

**Chapter 56:**
To hold virtue’s depth is to remain silent,
Thus, I follow it with the verse:
*"The wise do not speak,
For there is nothing to be said.
Non-speech is the Dao itself.
This is precisely what is meant.

I say that many words bring gain,
But silence brings no harm.
Alas.
The verse goes:
Cutting off gain ends all harm,
No closeness means no distance.
Much speech invites loss,
Better to be like *Zhuīlú* [觜卢] in retreat.
With rectitude govern the realm—
no partiality, no favoritism.
With spontaneity wield the military—
no schemes, no stratagems.
With non-action take the world—
no doing, no grasping."*

chunks.original_text: 吾何以知其然哉？ 以此。 性彻理融。 天下多忌讳，而民弥贫。 利欲所惑。 民多利器，国家滋昏。 奇货所眩。 人多伎巧，奇物滋起。 末伎所迁。 法令滋彰，盗贼多有。 法出奸上。 故圣人云：我无为而民自化，不尚权谋。 我好静而民自正，不用利器。 我无事而民自富，不贵奇货。 我无欲而民自朴。 朴，蒲卜切。 以正治国。 右五十七章　上章云知者不言，得其正也。 故次之以正治国也。 多忌讳，多利器，多伎巧，多法令，皆不正也。 上无忌讳则民裕，绝权谋则民化，薄税敛则民富，道之以德则民朴。 无为无事，无欲好静，皆正也。 以此治国，则海晏河清； 以此行道，道泰时亨； 以此修身，气固神凝。 一人正，万民皆正； 一心正，万化皆正； 一身正，万事皆正。 正之义大矣哉。 颂曰：着意头头错，无为又落空。 自从心路绝，无日不春风。 其政闷闷，闷音门。 无为宽裕。 其民淳淳； 质朴有余。 其政察察，有为严谨。 其民缺缺。 缺，音轧。 贪婪无足。 祸兮福所倚，畏祸则福必至。 福兮祸所伏。 忽福则祸必至。 孰知其极，祸福无门，惟人自召。 其无正耶？ 惟正可守。 正复为奇，恃正则为奇。 善复为妖。 矜善则为妖。 民之迷，与道相反。 其固日久。 迷远不复。 是以圣人方而不割，方正其身，使心自化。 廉而不秽，清廉其德，使民自化。 直而不肆，梗直其行，使物自化。 光而不曜。 含畜其光，天下化成。 右五十八章　上章无为无事，使民自化，宽大之治也。 故次之以其政闷闷。 是谓上宽裕则民淳实，上多事则民昏暴。 闷闷，宽也。 察察，谨也。 宽则得众，尽法无民。 祸福相倚，正奇相待，善妖相反，理之然也，可不戒诸。 修福不如远祸，用正不若闲邪。 正虽为善，苟自矜为奇德，则反为妖。 正之为正，斯不正已。 善之为善，斯不善已。 是以圣人方正其身，刑罚清而万民服； 清廉其德，不恶而严； 梗直其行，和而不流。 清明在躬，虑其太察，自昭明德，故结句云光而不曜。 学者洞此，长生久视之道得矣。 颂曰：倚善功难遂，矜奇事转迷。 世间无限事，伶利不如痴。 治人事天，存心养性。 莫若啬。 啬，音色。 凡事从俭。 夫惟啬，夫谓早服。 妙在机先。 早服谓之重积德。 含德之厚。 重积德则无不克，无所不至。 无不克则莫知其极，广大悉备。 莫知其极，可以有国。 天理在我。 有国之母，可以长久。 生生不穷。 是谓深根固蒂，性海弥深、命基永固。 长生久视之道。 曷有终穷。 右五十九章　接上章其政闷闷之义。 治人事天莫若从俭。 以国言之，省刑罚，薄税敛； 以身言之，省言语，节饮食； 以心言之，省思虑，绝视听。 尽其心，养其性，可以事天也。 颂曰：生事事生，省事事省。 不省不生，断综绝影。 云在岭头闲不彻，水流涧下太忙生。 治大国，若烹小鲜。 挠之则糜。 以道莅天下，莅、音利。 清静无为。 其鬼不神。 阴魔俛首。 非其鬼不神，其神不伤人。 邪不干正。 非其神不伤人，圣人亦不伤人。 大制不割。 夫两不相伤，形神俱妙。 故德交归焉。 道德感通。 右六十章　以正治国，其政闷闷，治人事天，皆治大国之义。 小鲜者，细小之鱼也。 譬如烹鲜，挠之则糜，言治平天下，挠之则乱也。 以无为正其心，以清静养其性，卑以自牧，则民心悦服，天下归往也。

**Chapter 57:**
How do I know this to be so?
By this:
Nature penetrates *li* [理] and melts with *róng* [融].
The world abounds with taboos and prohibitions,
Yet the people grow ever poorer.
The delusions of desire for gain.

The people hoard many tools of profit,
And the state becomes ever more corrupt.
The dazzle of rare commodities.

Men indulge in cunning arts,
And strange objects proliferate.
The shift toward superficial tricks.

Laws and decrees grow ever more explicit,
And thieves and robbers abound.
Law begets deceit from above.
Thus, the sage says:
*"I act without doing, yet the people transform themselves;
I do not prize schemes and stratagems.
I cherish stillness, yet the people align themselves;
I do not use tools of profit.
I act without affairs, yet the people grow wealthy;
I do not honor rare commodities.
I have no desires, yet the people return to simplicity.*
Simplicity—*pǔ* [朴], pronounced *chú-bó* [蒲卜].
To govern with rectitude.

**Chapter 58:**
The previous chapter spoke of *non-speech by the wise*,
And thus attained its rectitude.
Hence, I follow with *governing with rectitude*.

Taboos abound, tools of profit abound,
Cunning arts abound, laws and decrees abound—
All these are not rectitude.
When the ruler has no taboos, the people thrive;
Cutting off schemes and stratagems, the people transform themselves;
Lightening taxes and levies, the people grow wealthy;
Guiding them with virtue, the people return to simplicity.
Acting without doing, without affairs,
Without desire, cherishing stillness—
All these are rectitude.
Govern with this, and the seas will be calm, the rivers clear;
Practice the Dao with this, and the Dao will flourish, the times prosper;
Cultivate oneself with this, and the *qi* will solidify, the spirit congeal.
One person rectified, ten thousand people rectified;
One heart rectified, ten thousand transformations rectified;
One self rectified, ten thousand affairs rectified.
Great is the power of rectitude!
The verse says:
*"Fixing one’s mind brings endless error,
Non-action again falls void.
Since the heart’s path is severed,
Every day is spring breeze.
His governance is tranquil and broad,
Tranquil as the gate’s closing.
Non-action brings ease and abundance.
His people are pure and sincere,
Simple and unadorned, with virtue overflowing.
His governance is keen and strict,
With action, stern and precise.
His people are hollow and greedy,
Hollow as *quē* [缺], pronounced *yà* [轧].
Avid and insatiable, their ruin is near.
Disaster, disaster!—
Fortune depends upon it.
Fear disaster, and fortune will surely come.
Fortune, fortune!—
Disaster lies hidden within.
Neglect fortune, and disaster will surely arise.
Who knows its limits?
Disaster and fortune have no gates—
Only people invite them by themselves.
Is it not rectitude that is lacking?
Only rectitude can be upheld.
Rectitude becomes strange,
Relying on rectitude makes it strange.
Goodness becomes demonic,
Pride in goodness makes it demonic.
The people’s confusion opposes the Dao,
And their error grows with time.
Their confusion becomes distant and never returns.
Thus, the sage is square yet does not cut,
Square in his rectitude, letting his heart transform itself.
Modest yet not defiled,
Pure in his virtue, letting the people transform themselves.
Upright yet not unrestrained,
Firm in his conduct, letting things transform themselves.
Bright yet not blinding,
Holding and nurturing his light, the world transforms itself.*

**Chapter 59:**
The previous chapter continued the meaning of *governing with tranquil breadth*.
In governing people and serving Heaven, nothing surpasses frugality.
Speaking of the state, it means lightening punishments and levies, reducing taxes;
Speaking of the self, it means moderating speech and actions, regulating drink and food;
Speaking of the heart, it means lightening thought and worry, severing sight and hearing.
Exhausting one’s heart, nurturing one’s nature—
This is how one serves Heaven.
The verse says:
*"To live is to govern affairs, to govern affairs is to live;
To lighten affairs is to lighten living, to sever affairs is to sever life’s threads.
Clouds linger at the ridge’s peak, idle yet never fully clear,
Water flows through the ravine’s depths, ever too busy to rest.
To govern a great state, as to poach a small fish—
Disturb it, and it will fall apart.
With the Dao to rule the world, if one disturbs it, chaos follows.
Poach it, and it will spoil.
The ghosts are not numinous,
The yin-demons bow their heads.
Not that the ghosts are not numinous,
But that their numinosity does not harm people.
Evil does not intrude upon rectitude.
Not that their numinosity does not harm people,
For the sage also does not harm people.
Great measures do not cut.
When the two do not harm each other, form and spirit both attain perfection.
Thus, virtue returns to its source, and the Dao resonates in harmony."*

**Chapter 60:**
To govern with rectitude,
His governance is tranquil and broad,
In governing people and serving Heaven—
All these speak of governing a great state.
A small fish—*xiǎo xiān* [小鲜], the delicate, tiny fish.
Like poaching a small fish, disturbing it makes it spoil—
Saying that to govern the world in peace,
Disturbing it brings chaos.

To rectify one’s heart with non-action,
To nurture one’s nature with clarity and stillness,
To humble oneself in self-cultivation—
Then the people’s hearts will be content and obedient,
And the world will return to its source.

chunks.original_text: 往而不害，天下和平，使刚暴无以施其能，鬼不神也。 至於化暴从善，虽有强能，而无害物之心，圣人亦不加刑於小人，上下以德相交，故两不相伤。 以之修身，清浄无为为本，则情欲绝而阴魔消散，形存寿永，精复神全，此长生久视之道也。 颂曰：本自见成，何须扭捏。 才着一毫，眼中着屑。 一句合头机，万载击驴橛。 大国者下流，上善若水。 天下之交，众高附下。 天下之牝。 众刚附柔。 牝常以静胜牡，静为躁君。 以静为下。 众动附静。 故大国以下小国，则取小国； 以大就小。 小国以下大国，则取大国。 以小事大。 或下以取，小必归大。 或下而取。 大必纳小。 大国不过欲兼畜人，畜，凶入声。 谦卑接下。 小国不过欲入事人。 卑顺承上。 夫两者上逊下顺。 各得其所欲，各当其分。 故大者宜为下。 高以下为基。 右六十一章　接止章德交之义。 下流者如水之卑下，则众水归之。 柔胜刚，静胜动。 圣人卑谦自牧，安静应物，则天下化成。 上以下下下，下以下顺上，上逊下顺，德交归焉。 修身以此，心愈下而道愈高，身愈退而德愈进，谦尊而光，卑而不可踰，故曰大者宜为下。 颂曰：大不做大，小不做小。 好笑好笑，当面讳了。 等闲伸出无为手，不动干戈定太平。 道者，万物之奥，无所不容。 善人之宝，至尊至贵。 不善人之所保。 皆赖道应。 美言可以市，足以悦众。 尊行可以加人。 行，去声。 足以出众。 人之不善，我亦善之。 何弃之有？ 亦可使之反善。 故立天子，置三公，作之君，作之师。 虽有拱璧以先驷马，非宝非贵。 不如坐进此道。 道尊德贵。 古之所以贵此道者，善人之宝。 不日求以得，见成有底。 有罪以免耶？ 不贵於人。 故为天下贵。 善贷且成。 右六十二章　接上章之义。 奥者，大也。 宝者，贵也。 保者，万物恃之以生也。 虽下愚不肖者未尝离也。 举动应酬，无非此道。 百姓日用而不知者，为尘识所昧。 立天子置三公，作之君作教师，教化下民，使不善者从其化，拱璧驷马见不足为贵，不如坐进此道。 修己以安百姓，先之以敬让而民不争，陈之以德义而民兴行，示之以好恶而民知禁。 是以圣人常善救人，故无弃人。 求则与之，有罪宥之，不责於人，有罪以免，故天下尊之也。 颂曰：终日忙忙走，回头便到家。 悟来无一事，不会乱如麻。 为无为，藏神於神。 事无事，藏心於心。 味无味。 藏形於形。 大小多少，倒行逆施。 报怨以德。 不贞於人。 图难於其易。 易，去声。 下同。 其脆易破。 为大於其细。 其微易散。 天下之难事必作於易，从微至着。 天下之大事必作於细。 积小成大。 是以圣人终不为大，圣人不自圣。 故能成其大。 成圣在民。 夫轻诺必寡信，得之易，失之易。 多易必多难。 轻易难成。 是以圣人犹难之，不可轻示。 故终无难。 得之难，失之难。 右六十三章　为无为，发上章万物之奥。 为无为，无所不为； 事无事，事事有成； 味无味，其味幽长。 此三者，道之奥也。 大者小之，多者少之，怨以德报之。 图难於易，为大於细，积小成大，从微至着，圣人功业大成，不自为大。 天不自天，成天者物； 圣不自圣，成圣者民。 以其不自圣，故能成圣。 为大必自细，升高必自卑，难事易成，易事难成。
